string.name: why_fitness_1ii_1
string.font:
Why Physical Fitness?



1. It Can Make You Feel Happier

Exercising regularly can improve your mood and reduce feelings of anxiety and depression.


2. It Can Help With Weight Loss
 Exercise is crucial to supporting a fast metabolism and burning more Calories per day. It also helps you maintain your muscle mass and weight loss.


3. It Is Good for Your Muscles and Bones
 Physical activity helps you build muscles and strong bones. It may also help prevent osteoporosis.


4. It Can Increase Your Energy Levels
 Engaging in regular physical activity can increase your energy levels. This is true even in people with persistent fatigue and those suffering from serious illnesses.


5. It Can Reduce Your Risk of Chronic Disease
 Daily physical activity is essential to maintaining a healthy weight and reducing the risk of chronic disease.


6. It Can Help Skin Health
 Moderate exercise can provide antioxidant protection and promote blood flow, which can protect your skin and delay signs of aging.


7. It Can Help Your Brain Health and Memory
 Regular exercise improves blood flow to the brain and helps brain health and memory. Among older adults, it can help protect mental function.


8. It Can Help With Relaxation and Sleep Quality
 Regular physical activity, regardless of whether it is aerobic or a combination of aerobic and resistance training, can help you sleep better and feel more energized during the day.


9. It Can Reduce Pain
 Exercise has favourable effects on the pain that's associated with various conditions. It can also increase pain tolerance.


10. It Can Promote a Better Sex Life
 Exercise can help improve sexual desire, function and performance in men and women. It can also help decrease the risk of erectile dysfunction in men.


The Bottom Line

Exercise offers incredible benefits that can improve nearly every aspect of your health from the inside out. Regular physical activity can increase the production of hormones that make you feel happier and help you sleep better. It can also improve your skin's appearance, help you lose weight and keep it off, lessen the risk of chronic disease and improve your sex life. Whether you practice a specific sport or follow the guideline of 150 minutes of activity per week, you will inevitably improve your health in many ways.

Demerits of Physical Fitness



Following are the consequences of excessive exercising or obsession with fitness as it:-

 h) Hurts the heart.

 i) Is addictive.

 The simple solution to all the above problems is exercise in moderation.

'ABOUT US' section by clicking on the menu tab.


Once you are DONE with the above procedure, LET'S BEGIN :)


The first thing that comes in our mind when we hear the word fitness is:- a great aesthetic body having a low body fat percentage and good muscularity. Well, it’s not as simple as that. Fitness is not just about physical looks and stuff, it’s way beyond that.

 As success is the by-product of excellence, and money is the by-product of effort and skill, in the same way, a good physique is a by-product of many factors like strength, stamina, speed, endurance, mobility etc. And it’s not just physical fitness, but other types of fitness like mental, social, emotional and spiritual fitness are also equally important to stay strong, healthy and most importantly ‘happy’.

 Fitness is broadly classified into 5 categories:-

 a) Physical
 b) Mental
 c) Social

string.name: physical_fitness1ib
string.font:
Physical Fitness



Physical fitness is a state of health and well-being and, more specifically, the ability to perform aspects of sports, occupations and daily activities. Physical fitness is generally achieved through proper nutrition, moderate to vigorous physical exercise, and sufficient rest.


Components of Physical Fitness
 Depending on the source, the components of fitness vary considerably. Below are common components:


• Cardiorespiratory endurance - typically measured by how long or fast a person can perform an activity and how this impacts measurements such as heart rate and oxygen consumption.


• Muscular endurance - typically measured by how many repetitions of an exercise a person can perform. Common tests involve push-ups and sit ups.


• Muscular strength - typically measured by how much weight can be moved in relation to repetitions. Exercises involving multiple joints and muscle groups such as squats or bench press are often used.


• Muscular power - typically measured by how much force can be generated during a given activity. Advanced equipment used by bio-mechanists is often needed to measure muscular power.


• Flexibility - typically measured by how far a muscle group can be stretched or joint can be moved. The most common tests involve the hamstrings and shoulders.


• Balance - typically measured by how long a particular position can be held with or without some type of activity being performed. Simple tests such as standing on one leg can be used to assess balance. More advanced tests may involve standing on an unsteady object while trying to catch a ball.


• Speed - typically measured by how quickly an individual can move from one point to another. The 40-yard dash is often used to assess speed.


• Body composition - this is the amount of fat on the body versus other tissues such as muscle, bones and skin. Measured using a variety of tests and devices. Simple tests using mathematical equations or calipers are common and inexpensive. More advanced tests such as underwater weighing are far less common and much more expensive.


"For more info, click ""here."

font.div: Mental Fitness

What is it?
 Mental fitness refers to a state of psychosocial well-being, it means having a positive sense of how we feel, think, and act, which improves our ability to enjoy life. It contributes to our innate ability to be self-determined.

What does it look like?
 A person who demonstrates high levels of mental fitness often has the following characteristics:

 • Knowledge of their strengths, limitation and interests

 • Creativity

 • Problem solving and conflict resolution

 • Accountable for their actions and decisions

 • Seek help when needed

 • Follow their ideas and actions in spite of difficulty or opposition

Why does it matter?
 Mental fitness is fundamental to drive positive lifestyle changes and is also a strong predictor of physical health. Improved mental fitness motivates us for positive lifestyle changes around healthy eating, increased physical activity, and tobacco-free living.

 In contrast, when the three basic psychological needs (competence, autonomy, and relatedness) are not met, individuals are at higher risk for experiencing difficulties related to their emotional, social, and physical wellness.

 Research also tell us that people who experience higher levels of mental fitness live longer, are more successful in school and at work, are happier in their relationships, and are less prone to mental illnesses.

What can you do?
 The opportunities to improve our mental fitness begin in our homes, schools, communities and workplaces! There are various things we can do to encourage an environment that improve mental fitness.

 • Organize activities that are conducive to generating people’s interest and engagement

 • Promote success

 • Give constructive feedback

 • Provide active listening

 • Take into account suggestions from others

 • Make expectations clear and give the significance and usefulness of, and the reason for, the task assigned

 • Give choices

 • Suggest rather than dictate

 • Reduce all coercive approaches

 • Welcome and take into account others’ ideas

 • Show empathy for others

 • Respect, accept, and take an interest in others

 • Be present and attentive (mindful) to others’ need for competence, autonomy and relatedness

string.name: pillars_nutrition2i
string.font:
Nutrition (The First Pillar)



The food we eat plays a vital role in how we look and feel. Regular exercise is important but according to research, nutrition has the largest impact on our fitness. Using food as our medicine has become a popular theme for health improvement.

 The trend is now to focus on healthy food intake as a primary fitness goal. When healthy eating habits become a lifestyle, we get healthier and happier. Eating right allows us to reduce body fat, build muscle, feel more confident and reduce our risk of illness.

 Frequent studies are indicating healthy food intake as the most important part of our fitness programs. Some physicians are teaching healthy eating habits and lifestyle as a way to improve overall health by reducing obesity and related disease.


Food Is Our Medicine
 Nutrient-dense foods, or 'superfoods', that include lean proteins, healthy carbohydrates, and fats are essential for our health. Superfoods are rich sources of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants.


Antioxidants are known to reduce inflammation in our body helping us fight diseases and illnesses. Inflammation is said to be the leading cause of many diseases. Powerful antioxidants in leafy greens and vegetables, for example, help detoxify the body removing harmful chemicals.

 Some superfoods contain compounds that increase our metabolism for more efficient fat burning. Red peppers contain a molecule called ‘capsaicin’ known to enhance the rate at which we burn body fat.


How Do Quercetin Rich Foods Help?

Quercetin is a powerful antioxidant naturally occurring in a wide variety of plant foods. In fact, quercetin research indicates it to be one of the most potent antioxidants with numerous health benefits. Many athletes supplement with quercetin to reduce muscle inflammation caused by intense workouts. According to a study published in the
International Journal of Preventative Medicine, quercetin supplementation significantly improved athletic performance, increased metabolic rate and lean mass among athletes.

 The following foods are rich sources of quercetin:
 • APPLES
 • ONIONS
 • BROCCOLI
 • BERRIES


Increase Your Metabolism Naturally
 Your best fat burner is not going to come in a bottle but by eating foods containing certain compounds.

 Eating foods that stimulate and enhance the fat burning process will help us reduce fat more effectively. Adding metabolism boosting foods will be a great supplement to your existing workout and nutrition program.

 The following foods are known for increasing our metabolism:

 • HOT PEPPERS (active component:- capsaicin)

 • GREEN TEA (active component:- caffeine)

 • BLACK COFFEE (active component:- caffeine)

 • COLD WATER (500 ml of water daily increased metabolic rate by 30%)

 • WHOLE GRAINS (aiding components:- Fibre and iron)

 • YOGURT (aiding components:- calcium and probiotics)

 • APPLES (aiding component:- Fibre)

 • NUTS and SEEDS (aiding components:- essential fatty acids)

 • FATTY FISH (aiding components:- Omega-3 fatty acids)



Peanut Butter Is a Superfood
 Peanut butter just so happens to be the No.1 sports nutrition superfood. It contains healthy fat, is nutrient-dense and known to provide long-lasting energy for optimal athletic performance.

 Selecting natural or organic peanut butter is recommended to avoid added sugar and preservatives. Peanut butter contains quality nutrients and supplies lasting energy at 90 Calories per 2 tablespoon serving. It also contains 7 grams of protein per ounce compared to other nuts only supplying 4 grams. Adequate protein intake is essential for muscle growth.

 It is low in saturated fat and cholesterol making it a heart-healthy food. Research indicates consuming 1.5 ounces of peanut butter per day may reduce the risk of heart disease.

 Peanut butter is high in Fibre and an excellent source of plant protein. It also contains
niacin,
folate,
Vitamin E and other essential nutrients and minerals.


What Are Fitness Foods?
 The term fitness food is interchangeable with superfoods. Eating a diet rich in fitness foods is essential for our health. Incorporating healthy nutrition and knowing what that means is vital for achieving a lean and healthy body.

 The following is a list of foods favoured by fitness enthusiasts:

 • OATS (high in Fibre, improves digestion/increases metabolism)

 • EGGS (protein source, muscle building)

 • GREENS (antioxidants, reduces inflammation)

 • APPLES (antioxidants, reduces inflammation/increases metabolism)

 • LEAN MEAT/FISH (amino acids, protein source, muscle building)



Is Coffee Healthy or Not?
 Should we drink coffee? This is a popular question and although not the best drink for some, overall studies show coffee as beneficial to our health and fitness.

 Coffee contains antioxidants but also caffeine. Caffeine is a natural stimulant known to increase our metabolic rate. Many athletes are using coffee as a pre-workout drink to benefit from this effect. Low to moderate doses (1-2 cups) of coffee significantly improve athletic performance.

 Drinking black coffee 30 minutes prior to exercise is said to have the best ergogenic results. It improves our endurance and enables us to exercise longer.

 Coffee is also elevates mental focus and energy levels. Clearer thinking promotes a more productive and effective workout. Coffee also reduces exercise-induced muscle pain.

 Coffee also contains powerful antioxidants that reduce the risk of chronic diseases and illnesses. Studies have shown that it helps individuals suffering from Parkinson's disease recover faster and to reduce the incidence of gallstones.


As caffeine is a stimulant, make sure to consult your physician before consuming coffee if you are hypertensive, pregnant, breastfeeding or suffering from a heart disease.


Eat Superfoods Daily
 Superfoods play an important part in achieving and maintaining a healthy body. Eating a wide variety of superfoods daily will satisfy nutrient requirements for optimal body functioning.

 Start with the following top superfoods for improved health and fitness:

 • OATS (high in Fibre, improved digestion, heart health)

 • BLUEBERRIES (antioxidants, reduces inflammation, cancer-fighting)

 • APPLES (antioxidants, reduces inflammation, weight loss)

 • GREEN TEA (antioxidants, increases metabolism, weight loss)

 • FLAXSEEDS (essential fatty acids, increases metabolism, reduces inflammation)

 • BROCCOLI (antioxidants, cancer-fighting, detox)

 • YOGURT (calcium, probiotic, improved digestion, bone health)

 • OLIVE OIL (monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFAs)/heart health)

 • BEANS (high in Fibre, antioxidants, improved brain function)

 • CINNAMON (antioxidants, detox, healing spice)

string.name: pillars_phy_activity2ii_1
string.font:
Physical Activity (The Second Pillar)



Just following a proper nutrition plan is not enough to stay physically fit. Expecting to build stamina, speed, endurance, strength, flexibility, mobility etc. simply through nutrition and without physical activity, is like expecting to drive an automobile or an aircraft using the ‘best engine fuels’ but WITHOUT AN ‘ENGINE’!

 Physical activity simply means movement of the body that uses energy. For health benefits, physical activity should be moderate or vigorous intensity. Physical activity can take various forms which include sports (athletics, badminton, football, cricket, basketball, volleyball, lawn tennis, table tennis, hockey etc.), cardiovascular exercises (walking, jogging, sprinting etc.), resistance training (weight training, bodyweight training), skill training (calisthenics, gymnastics, plyometrics), flexibility and mobility training (yoga) etc.


Types of physical activity:-
 The four main types of physical activity are aerobic, muscle-strengthening, bone-strengthening, and stretching.

 Aerobic activity is the type that benefits your heart and lungs the most.


Aerobic Activity
 Aerobic activity moves your large muscles, such as those in your arms and legs. Running, swimming, walking, bicycling, dancing, and doing jumping jacks are examples of aerobic activity. Aerobic activity is also called endurance activity.

 Aerobic activity makes your heart beat faster than usual. You also breathe harder during this type of activity. Over time, regular aerobic activity makes your heart and lungs stronger and able to work better.


Other Types of Physical Activity
 The other types of physical activity are muscle-strengthening, bone strengthening, and stretching that benefit your body in other ways.

 Muscle-strengthening activities improve the strength, power, and endurance of your muscles. Practising calisthenics (bodyweight exercises), lifting weights, climbing stairs, and digging in the garden are examples of muscle-strengthening activities.

 With bone-strengthening activities, your feet, legs, or arms support your body's weight, and your muscles push against your bones. This helps make your bones strong. Running, walking, jumping rope, and lifting weights are examples of bone-strengthening activities.

 Muscle-strengthening and bone-strengthening activities also can be aerobic, depending on whether they make your heart and lungs work harder than usual. For example, running is both an aerobic activity and a bone-strengthening activity.

 Stretching helps improve your flexibility and your ability to fully move your joints. Touching your toes, doing side stretches, and performing yoga exercises are examples of stretching.


"For more info, click ""here."


Benefits of physical activity:-

string.name: pillarsrest2iii_1
string.font:
Rest and Recovery (The Third Pillar)



Rest is physically necessary so that the muscles can repair, rebuild, and strengthen. For recreational athletes, building in rest days can help maintain a better balance between home, work, and fitness goals.

 In the worst-case scenario, too few rest and recovery days can lead to 'overtraining syndrome', a difficult condition to recover from.


What Happens During Recovery?
 Building recovery time into any training program is important because this is the time that the body adapts to the stress of exercise and the real training effect takes place. Recovery also allows the body to replenish energy stores and repair damaged tissues. Exercise or any other physical work causes changes in the body such as muscle tissue breakdown and the depletion of energy stores (muscle glycogen) as well as fluid loss.

 Recovery time allows these stores to be replenished and allows tissue repair to occur. Without sufficient time to repair and replenish, the body will continue to breakdown from intensive exercise.

 Symptoms of overtraining often occur from a lack of recovery time. Signs of overtraining include a feeling of general malaise, staleness, depression, decreased sports performance, and increased risk of injury, among others.


Short and Long-Term Recovery
 Keep in mind that there are 2 categories of recovery. There is immediate (short-term) recovery from a particularly intense training session or event, and there is the long-term recovery that needs to be built into a year-round training schedule. Both are important for optimal sports performance.


'Short-term recovery', sometimes called active recovery occurs in the hours immediately after an intense exercise. Active recovery refers to engaging in low-intensity exercise after workouts during both the cool-down phase immediately after a hard effort or workout as well as during the days following the workout. Both types of active recovery are linked to performance benefits.

 Another major focus of recovery immediately following exercise has to do with replenishing energy stores and fluids lost during exercise and optimizing protein synthesis (the process of increasing the protein content of muscle cells, preventing muscle breakdown, and increasing muscle size) by eating the right foods in the post-exercise meal.

 This is also the time for soft tissue (muscles, tendons, ligaments) repair and the removal of chemicals that build up as a result of cell activity during exercise.

 Getting quality sleep is also an important part of short-term recovery. Make sure to get plenty of sleep, (at least 7-8 hours daily) especially if you are doing hard training.


'Long-term recovery' techniques refer to those that are built into a seasonal training program. Most well-designed training schedules will include recovery days or weeks that are built into an annual training schedule. This is also the reason why athletes and coaches change their training program throughout the year, add cross-training, modify workouts types, and make changes in intensity, time, distance, and all the other training variables.


Adaptation to Exercise
 The 'Principle of Adaptation' states that when we undergo the stress of physical exercise, our body adapts and becomes more efficient. It’s just like learning any new skill; at first, it’s difficult, but over time it becomes second-nature. Once you adapt to a given stress, you require additional stress to continue to make progress.

 There are limits to how much stress the body can tolerate before it breaks down and risks injury. Doing too much work too quickly will result in injury or muscle damage, but doing too little, too slowly will not result in any improvement. This is why personal trainers set up specific training programs that increase time and intensity at a planned rate and allow rest days throughout the program.


Sleep Deprivation Can Hinder Sports Performance
 In general, one or two nights of poor or little sleep won't have much impact on performance, but consistently getting inadequate sleep can result in subtle changes in hormone levels, particularly those related to stress, muscle recovery, and mood. While no one completely understands the complexities of sleep, research published in 2015 indicates that sleep deprivation can lead to increased levels of 'cortisol' (a stress hormone), decreased the activity of 'human growth hormone' (which is active during tissue repair), and decreased 'glycogen synthesis'.


Balance Exercise with Rest and Recovery
 It is this alternation of adaptation and recovery that takes the athlete to a higher level of fitness. High-level athletes need to realize that the greater the training intensity and effort, the greater the need for planned recovery. Monitoring your workouts with a training log, and paying attention to how your body feels and how motivated you are is extremely helpful in determining your recovery needs and modifying your training program accordingly.

string.name: nutridd_intro3i
string.font:
Introduction to Nutrition



Nutrition, nourishment, or aliment, is the supply of materials or food required by organisms and cells to stay alive. In science and human medicine, nutrition is the science or practice of consuming and utilizing foods.


The reason why I have kept the ‘nutrition’ section before the ‘exercise’ section is because no matter how intense your workout or training program is, you will NEVER be able to get any of its benefits, if your ‘NUTRITION’ and ‘RECOVERY’ is cr*p!! So, YOU MUST ALWAYS PRIORITISE ‘NUTRITION’ over any kind of PHYSICAL TRAINING!! So, let’s get started!


Types of nutrients:-
 A nutrient is a source of nourishment, a component of food, for instance, protein, carbohydrate, fat, vitamin, mineral, fibre, and water.


• Macronutrients are nutrients we need in relatively large quantities.


• Micronutrients are nutrients we need in relatively small quantities.

 Macronutrients can be further split into energy macronutrients (that provide energy), and macronutrients that do not provide energy.

string.name: nutriddproteins3iii_1
string.font:
Proteins



"Just click ""here"" to get a good overall understanding of PROTEINS.

"

font.div:
All foods contain differing combinations of amino acids. In general, animal proteins like meat, dairy, and eggs contain all the essential amino acids.

 Plant-based proteins from foods like beans, grains, nuts, and soy are rich in some amino acids but may lack others. A well-balanced diet with a variety of foods can provide sufficient protein for the body's needs.

Protein deficiency
 If a person does not consume enough protein, he/she may experience:

 • lack of growth

 • loss of muscle mass

 • reduced immunity

 • weakening of the heart

 • respiratory problems


 Protein deficiency can be fatal. Some people develop ‘kwashiorkor’ as a result of protein deficiency. It is a type of malnutrition, and it’s common during a famine.

 Early signs include swelling in the legs and possibly the face, due to ‘Edema’, or fluid collecting under the skin. Other symptoms are a pot belly, fatigue, dry brittle hair, and cracked nails. The person will be more prone to infections.

 In developed countries, those most at risk of a protein deficiency include people who do not eat properly, for example, due to a poorly managed weight loss diet, an eating disorder, or inability to cook their own food, for example, in older age.
Food sources\n The following images show the common protein rich sources:-\n

"NOTE:-" "The accurate macro and micro-nutrient composition of any food source per 100g is just a Google search away. This is a good way to get a better idea of protein, carbohydrate and fat content in a particular food source, which can help us to decide the quantity of that food source to be consumed in order to meet the necessary daily macro and micro-nutrient demands.

" Protein needs also increase for people who:

 • have injuries

 • have undergone surgery

 • consistently break down muscle during exercise



Anyone who is considering a high-protein diet should first speak to a doctor.

Demerits of excess protein intake
 Most studies support an intake of up to 2 g per kg of body weight without any negative or adverse effects.

 Consuming more than 2.5 g of protein per kg of body weight (for example, over 225g protein for a person weighing 200 pounds) can increase the risk of:
 • dehydration
 • fatigue
 • fat gain
 • constipation
 • passing out more calcium in the urine

 Eating more than 200 to 400 g of protein a day can make it hard for the liver to convert excess nitrogen to a waste product called urea. This can lead to nausea, diarrhoea, and other adverse side effects.

 Some experts have warned that with the current craze for high-protein diets, including protein shakes, people may be consuming more protein than is healthy.

 While protein supplements can assist those who have high protein needs reach their goals, it is usually best for most of the protein to come from a well-balanced diet of whole foods.

Fats are required in the diet for health as they serve many functions, including lubricating joints, helping organs produce hormones, assisting in absorption of certain vitamins, reducing inflammation, and preserving brain health.

 Following are the various healthy fat sources:-

font.div:
"NOTE:-" "Natural peanut butter is an excellent source of healthy fats and protein and is very popular in households. Majority of peanut butter jars, packets and bottles are bought from the shopping malls and grocery markets. The problem with this is that most of the peanut butter brands that are found in shopping malls and grocery stores are NOT natural peanut butter sources, but are rather processed.

" The only ingredient that is used to prepare natural peanut butter is roasted peanuts. That’s it! But almost all the peanut butter brands found in the markets usually contain many more ingredients like added salt, sweeteners, artificial preservatives, stabilisers, emulsifiers and most dangerous among them all being partially hydrogenated oils, which prevents the oil from the peanut butter to separate and rise to the top. Partially hydrogenated oils are VERY BAD FOR OUR HEART HEALTH as they increase our LDL (bad cholesterol) levels and reduce HDL (good cholesterol) levels, which can eventually lead to heart diseases.

 With that being said, the peanut butter (processed) that you consume on a daily basis in the name of ‘good health’, is actually ‘ruining’ yours! It’s best to THROW AWAY those peanut butter brands that contain ingredients other than ‘roasted peanuts’ and STOP BUYING THEM in the future.

 Instead, buy the brands that contain ‘natural’ peanut butter containing only ‘roasted peanuts’ in their ingredient list. An easy way to distinguish between ‘natural’ and ‘processed’ ones is simple. ‘Processed’ ones are usually ‘solid’ at room temperature, whereas ‘natural’ ones are ‘thick liquids’ at room temperature.
You would mostly likely find those brands only in online shopping websites like ‘Amazon’ and ‘Flipkart’.\n\n

"Click ""here" to know the BEST NATURAL PEANUT BUTTER BRANDS in INDIA.

 Just type ‘natural peanut butter’ in the search box of either ‘Amazon’ or ‘Flipkart’, and you will find the best brands available for home delivery.
Types of Fat\n

Unsaturated fats
 Unsaturated fats, which are liquid at room temperature, are considered beneficial fats because they can improve blood cholesterol levels, ease inflammation, stabilize heart rhythms, and play a number of other beneficial roles. Unsaturated fats are predominantly found in foods from plants, such as vegetable oils, nuts, and seeds.

 There are two types of ‘good’ unsaturated fats:

 1. 'MONOUNSATURATED FATS' are found in high concentrations in:

 o Olive, peanut, and canola oils

 o Avocados

 o Nuts such as almonds, hazelnuts, and pecans

 o Seeds such as pumpkin and sesame seeds


 2. 'POLYUNSATURATED FATS' are found in high concentrations in:

 o Sunflower, corn, soybean, and flaxseed oils

 o Walnuts

 o Flax seeds

 o Fish

 o Canola oil – though higher in monounsaturated fat, it’s also a good source of polyunsaturated fat.


 Omega-3 fats are an important type of polyunsaturated fat. The body can’t make these, so they must come from food.

 • An excellent way to get omega-3 fats is by eating fish 2-3 times a week.

 • Good plant sources of omega-3 fats include flax seeds, walnuts, and canola or soybean oil.

 • Higher blood omega-3 fats are associated with lower risk of premature death among older adults, according to a study by HSPH faculty.

Saturated Fats
 All foods containing fat have a mix of specific types of fats. Even healthy foods like chicken and nuts have small amounts of saturated fat, though much less than the amounts found in beef, cheese, and ice cream. Saturated fat is mainly found in animal foods, but a few plant foods are also high in saturated fats, such as coconut, coconut oil, palm oil, and palm kernel oil.

 The sources of saturated fat are:

 • Pizza and cheese

 • Whole and reduced fat milk, butter and dairy desserts

 • Meat products (sausage, bacon, beef, hamburgers)

 • Cookies and other grain-based desserts

 • A variety of mixed fast food dishes

 Though decades of dietary advice suggested saturated fat was harmful, in recent years that idea has begun to evolve. Several studies suggest that eating diets high in saturated fat do not raise the risk of heart disease, with one report analysing the findings of 21 studies that followed 350,000 people for up to 23 years.

 Investigators looked at the relationship between saturated fat intake and coronary heart disease (CHD), stroke, and cardiovascular disease (CVD). Their controversial conclusion: “There is INSUFFICIENT evidence from prospective epidemiologic studies to conclude that dietary saturated fat is associated with an increased risk of CHD, stroke, or CVD.”

 The overarching message is that cutting back on saturated fat can be good for health if people replace saturated fat with good fats, especially, polyunsaturated fats. Eating good fats in place of saturated fat lowers the “bad” LDL cholesterol, and it improves the ratio of total cholesterol to “good” HDL cholesterol, lowering the risk of heart disease.

 Eating good fats in place of saturated fat can also help prevent insulin resistance, a precursor to diabetes. So while saturated fat may not be as harmful as once thought, evidence clearly shows that unsaturated fat remains the healthiest type of fat.

Trans Fats
 Trans fatty acids, more commonly called trans fats, are made by heating liquid vegetable oils in the presence of hydrogen gas and a catalyst, a process called hydrogenation.

 • Partially hydrogenating vegetable oils makes them more stable and less likely to become rancid. This process also converts the oil into a solid, which makes them function as margarine or shortening.

 • Partially hydrogenated oils can withstand repeated heating without breaking down, making them ideal for frying fast foods.

 • For these reasons, partially hydrogenated oils became a mainstay in restaurants and the food industry – for frying, baked goods, and processed snack foods and margarine.


 Partially hydrogenated oil is not the only source of trans fats in our diets. Trans fats are also naturally found in beef fat and dairy fat in small amounts.

 Trans fats are the worst type of fat for the heart, blood vessels, and rest of the body because they:

 • Raise bad LDL and lower good HDL

 • Create inflammation – a reaction related to immunity – which has been implicated in heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and other chronic conditions

 • Contribute to insulin resistance

 • Can have harmful health effects even in small amounts – for each additional 2% of Calories from trans fat consumed daily, the risk of coronary heart disease increases by 23%.
"For more info, click ""here."

BOTTOM LINE:-
 So, this brings us to a conclusion that the majority of our fat intake must come from UNSATURATED FATS. But this doesn’t give us the license to include as much fat in our nutrition as possible. Remember fats are calorie dense (9 kcal/g). So overconsumption of fat will simply lead to an overall calorie surplus, which will eventually get stored as body fat, which we obviously don’t want.

 So always CONSUME FATS IN MODERATION.

string.name: nutriddfibre3va_1
string.font:
Fibre



Dietary Fibre, also known as roughage or bulk, includes the parts of plant foods your body can't digest or absorb. Unlike other food components, such as fats, proteins or carbohydrates, which your body breaks down and absorbs, fibre isn't digested by your body. Instead, it passes relatively intact through your stomach, small intestine and colon and out of your body.

 Fibre is commonly classified as soluble, which dissolves in water, or insoluble, which doesn't dissolve.

 • SOLUBLE FIBRE:- This type of fibre dissolves in water to form a gel-like material. It can help lower blood cholesterol and glucose levels. Soluble Fibre is found in oats, peas, beans, apples, citrus fruits, carrots, barley and psyllium.

 • INSOLUBLE FIBRE:- This type of fibre promotes the movement of material through your digestive system and increases stool bulk, so it can be of benefit to those who struggle with constipation or irregular stools. Whole-wheat flour, wheat bran, nuts, beans and vegetables, such as cauliflower, green beans and potatoes, are good sources of insoluble Fibre.


Benefits of fibre:-

 • Normalises bowel movement

 • Helps maintain bowel health

 • Lowers cholesterol levels

 • Helps control blood sugar levels

 • Aids in achieving healthy weight

 • Helps you live longer


 If you aren't getting enough fibre each day, you may need to boost your intake. Good choices include:

 • Whole-grain products

 • Fruits

 • Vegetables

 • Beans, peas and other legumes

 • Nuts and seeds


 Refined or processed foods such as canned fruits and vegetables, pulp-free juices, white breads and pastas, and non-whole-grain cereals are lower in fibre. The grain-refining process removes the outer coat (bran) from the grain, which lowers its fibre content. Enriched foods have some of the B vitamins and iron added back after processing, but not the fibre.

font.div:
Increase fibre in your nutrition plan gradually over a few weeks. This allows the natural bacteria in your digestive system to adjust to the change.

 Also, drink plenty of water. Fibre works best when it absorbs water, making your stool soft and bulky.
"For more info, click ""here."

Demerits of excess fibre consumption:-

 • Wind problem (flatulence)

 • Diarrhoea

 • Constipation

 • Reduced mineral absorption

 • Removal of good cholesterol
"For more info, click ""here."
So, as always the solution to prevent all the above problems is to CONSUME FIBRE IN MODERATION.\n

string.name: nutriddwater3vb
string.font:
Water



It’s common to hear that water is essential for your health. But why?

 This substance makes up a majority of your body weight and is involved in many important functions, including:

 • flushing out waste from your body

 • regulating body temperature

 • helping your brain function

 You get most of your water from drinking beverages, but food also contributes a small amount to your daily water intake.

 The 16 reasons why you need to consume water:-

 • It helps create saliva

 • It regulates your body temperature

 • It protects your tissues, spinal cord, and joints

 • It helps excrete waste through perspiration, urination, and defecation

 • It helps maximize physical performance

 • It helps prevent constipation

 • It aids in digestion

 • It helps with nutrient absorption

 • It helps you lose weight

 • It improves blood oxygen circulation

 • It helps fight off illness

 • It helps boost energy

 • It aids in cognitive function

 • It helps improve mood

 • It helps keep skin bright

 • It prevents overall dehydration



How much should you drink?
 Being attentive to the amount of water you drink each day is important for optimal health. Most people drink when they’re thirsty, which helps regulate daily water intake.

 According to the ‘National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine’, general water intake (from all beverages and foods) that meet most people’s needs are:

 • About 15.5 cups of water (125 ounces) each day for men

 • About 11.5 cups (91 ounces) daily for women

 People get about 20% of their daily water intake from food. The rest is dependent on drinking water and water-based beverages. So, ideally men would consume about 100 ounces (3.0 litres) of water from beverages, and women, about 73 ounces (2.12 litres) from beverages.

 You’ll have to increase your water intake if you’re exercising or living in a hotter region to avoid dehydration.

 Other ways to assess hydration include your thirst and the colour of your urine. Feeling thirsty indicates your body is not receiving adequate hydration. Urine that is dark or coloured indicates dehydration. Pale or non-coloured urine typically indicates proper hydration.


"For more info, click ""here."



Demerits of excessive water consumption:-

 1. Causes Hyponatremia

 2. Causes the Cells to Swell Up

 3. Causes Hypokalemia

 4. Affects the Brain

 5. Overburdens the Heart

 6. Overburdens the Kidneys

 7. Causes Liver Problems

 8. Frequent Urination

 9. Poses the Risk of Chlorine Overdose

 10. Coma in extreme cases


Ways to Prevent Over-hydration or Water Intoxication

Here are a few ways you can stop drinking too much water:

 • If you have medical conditions like diabetes or kidney problems, talk to your doctor to find out how much water you should consume.

 • If you exercise regularly, you may drink 2-4 cups of water per hour while exercising. If you need more water, drink sports drinks as they contain electrolytes that help balance the salts in your body.

 • Endurance athletes should measure their weight before and after a race to determine how much water they lost from the body. The lost water can be replenished without running the risk of over-hydration.


"For more info, click ""here."



To conclude, water is good for you, as long as you DON’T OVERDRINK IT. Take an informed decision on how much water you drank from foods and beverages to keep a track on your water intake. If you feel nauseous after drinking water, seek medical help immediately.

string.name: nutridd_minerals_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Minerals



Dietary minerals are the other chemical elements our bodies need, other than carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen.

 People with a well-balanced diet will, in most cases, obtain all the minerals they need from what they eat.


"For more info, click ""here."

string.name: nutridd_potassium3vib
string.font:
Potassium



• An important electrolyte, essential in co-regulating ATP (an important carrier of energy in cells in the body, also key in making RNA) with sodium.

 • Deficiency – ‘Hypokalemia’ - can profoundly affect the nervous system and heart.

 • Excess – ‘Hyperkalemia’ - can also profoundly affect the nervous system and heart.

string.name: nutridd_chloride3vic
string.font:
Chloride



• Key for producing stomach acid, important in the transport of molecules between cells, and vital for the proper functioning of nerves.

 • Deficiency – ‘Hypochloremia’ - low salt levels, which, if severe, can be very dangerous.

 • Excess – ‘Hyperchloremia’ - usually no symptoms, linked with excessive fluid loss.

 • The main source of chloride is SALT.

string.name: nutridd_sodium3vid
string.font:
Sodium



• An important electrolyte and essential in regulating ATP with potassium.

 • Important for nerve function and regulating body fluid levels.

 • Deficiency – ‘Hyponatremia’ - causes cells to malfunction; extremely low sodium can be fatal.

 • Excess – ‘Hypernatremia’ - can also cause cells to malfunction, extremely high levels can be fatal.

 • Here too, the main source is SALT.

string.name: nutridd_calcium3vie
string.font:
Calcium



• Important for muscle, heart, and digestive health.

 • Builds bone, assists in the synthesis and function of blood cells.

 • Deficiency – ‘Hypocalcaemia’ - muscle cramps, abdominal cramps, spasms, and hyperactive deep tendon reflexes.

 • Excess – ‘Hypercalcemia’ - muscle weakness, constipation, undermined conduction of electrical impulses in the heart, calcium stones in the urinary tract, impaired kidney function, and impaired absorption of iron, leading to iron deficiency.

string.name: nutridd_phosphorus3vif
string.font:
Phosphorus



• Important for the structure of DNA, transporter of energy (ATP), component of cellular membrane, helps strengthen bones.

 • Deficiency – ‘Hypophosphatemia’, an example is rickets.

 • Excess – ‘Hyperphosphatemia’, often a result of kidney failure.

string.name: nutridd_magnesium3vig
string.font:
Magnesium



• Processes ATP; required for good bones and management of proper muscle movement.

 • Hundreds of enzymes rely on magnesium to work properly.

 • Deficiency – ‘Hypomagnesemia’ - irritability of the nervous system with spasms of the hands and feet, muscular twitching and cramps, constipation, and larynx spasms.

 • Excess – ‘Hypermagnesemia’ - nausea, vomiting, impaired breathing, low blood pressure. Very rare, but may occur if patient has renal problems.

string.name: nutridd_zinc3vih
string.font:
Zinc



• Required by many enzymes.

 • Important for reproductive organ growth.

 • Also important in gene expression and regulating the nervous and immune systems.

 • Deficiency - short stature, ‘anaemia’, increased pigmentation of skin, enlarged liver and spleen, impaired reproductive function, impaired wound healing, and immune deficiency.

 • Excess - suppresses copper and iron absorption.

string.name: nutridd_iron3vi_i
string.font:
Iron



• Required for proteins and enzymes, especially ‘haemoglobin’, the oxygen-carrying compound in blood.

 • Deficiency – ‘Anaemia’.

 • Excess - iron overload disorder; iron deposits can form in organs, particularly the heart.

string.name: nutridd_manganese3vij
string.font:
Manganese



• A cofactor in enzyme functions.

 • Deficiency - wobbliness, fainting, hearing loss, weak tendons and ligaments. Less commonly, can be a cause of diabetes.

 • Excess - interferes with the absorption of dietary iron.

string.name: nutridd_copper3vik
string.font:
Copper



• Component of many enzymes.

 • Deficiency – ‘Anaemia’ or ‘Pancytopenia’ (reduction in the number of red and white blood cells, as well as platelets) and ‘neuro-degeneration’.

 • Excess - can interfere with body's formation of blood cellular components; in severe cases, convulsions, palsy, and eventually death (similar to arsenic poisoning).

string.name: nutridd_iodine3vil
string.font:
Iodine



• Required for the biosynthesis of thyroxine (one type of thyroid hormone).

 • Deficiency - developmental delays, enlarged thyroid gland (in the neck), and fatigue.

 • Excess - can affect the function of the thyroid gland.

string.name: nutridd_selenium3vim
string.font:
Selenium



• Essential cofactor for antioxidant enzymes.

 • Deficiency – ‘Keshan disease’ – ‘Myocardial Necrosis’ (tissue death in the heart) leading to weakening of the heart; ‘Kashin-Beck disease’ - break down of cartilage.

 • Excess - garlic-smelling breath, gastrointestinal disorders, hair loss, sloughing of nails, fatigue, irritability, and neurological damage.

string.name: nutridd_molybdenum3vin
string.font:
Molybdenum



• Vital part of three important enzyme systems, xanthine oxidase, aldehyde oxidase, and sulphite oxidase.

 • It has a vital role in uric acid formation, in carbohydrate metabolism, and sulphite detoxification.

 • Deficiency - may affect metabolism and blood counts, but as this deficiency often occurs at the same time as other mineral deficiencies, it is hard to say which deficiency caused which health problem.

 • Excess - there is very little data on toxicity.

 • Foods rich in molybdenum are:- beans and legumes, nuts, soy products, dairy products, leafy vegetables, eggs, whole grains, meat liver, tomatoes, peas etc.

string.name: nutridd_vitamin_intro3viia
string.font:
Introduction to Vitamins



• A vitamin is an organic compound and an essential nutrient that an organism requires in limited amounts. An organic compound is called a vitamin when the organism cannot make the compound in sufficient quantities, and it must be obtained through nutrition; thus, the term vitamin is conditional upon the circumstances and the particular organism. For example vitamin C is a vitamin for humans, but not for most other animals that make enough internally.


• Vitamins are nutrients that our body needs to function and fight off disease. Our body cannot produce vitamins itself. So we must get them through food that we eat or in some cases, supplements.


• There are 13 vitamins that are essential for the proper functioning of our body.

 • There are two types of vitamins:- 'fat-soluble' and 'water-soluble'. Fat-soluble vitamins are stored in your fat cells, consequently requiring fat in order to be absorbed. Water-soluble vitamins are not stored in your body; therefore, they need to be replenished daily. Your body takes what it needs from the food you eat and excretes what is not needed as waste.



Fat-Soluble Vitamins:-

 • VITAMIN A:- comes from orange coloured fruits and vegetables; dark leafy greens, like kale.

 • VITAMIN D:- can be found in fortified milk and dairy products; cereals; (and of course, sunshine!).

 • VITAMIN E:- is found in fortified cereals; leafy green vegetables; seeds; nuts.

 • VITAMIN K:- can be found in dark green leafy vegetables; turnip/beet greens.



Water-Soluble Vitamins:-

 • VITAMIN B1, or Thiamine:- comes from whole grains; enriched grains; liver; nuts; seeds

 • VITAMIN B2, or Riboflavin:- comes from whole grains; enriched grains; dairy products.

 • VITAMIN B3, or Niacin:- comes from meat; fish; poultry; whole grains.

 • VITAMIN B5, or Pantothenic Acid:- comes from meat; poultry; whole grains.

 • VITAMIN B6, or Pyridoxine:- comes from fortified cereals; soy products.

 • VITAMIN B7, or Biotin:- is found in fruits; meats.

 • VITAMIN B9, or Folic Acid (Folate):- comes from leafy vegetables.

 • VITAMIN B12:- comes from fish; poultry; meat; dairy products.

 • VITAMIN C, or Ascorbic Acid:- comes from citrus fruits and juices, such as oranges and grapefruits; red, yellow and green peppers.

string.name: nutridd_vitaminA3viib
string.font:
Vitamin A



One of vitamin A’s main roles is within the production of retinal. Your body uses retinal within the rods and cones of your eyes to sense light-weight and facilitate stop vision defect. Vitamin A is additionally necessary for your teeth, bones, skin, replica, and a healthy system.

string.name: nutridd_vitaminBcomplex3viic
string.font:
Vitamin B Complex



The various types of water-soluble vitamin B are thiamine (B1), riboflavin (B2), niacin (B3), pantothenic acid (B5), pyridoxine (B6), biotin (B7), folic acid (B9) and B12. They serve several functions in your body, as well as aiding in energy production, creating red blood cells, and creating new DNA, therefore, cells will multiply. They are additionally needed for healthy nerve and brain performance, internal organ health, and cardiovascular health.

string.name: nutridd_vitaminC3viid
string.font:
Vitamin C



Vitamin C, an inhibitor, might facilitate forestalling cell harm and scale back risk sure cancers, heart condition, and alternative diseases. Ascorbic acid is important for the formation of collagen that keeps your blood vessels sturdy and holds your teeth in their sockets. Additionally, ascorbic acid is very important to wound healing and serving your body to absorb iron.

string.name: nutridd_vitaminD3viie
string.font:
Vitamin D



Vitamin D aids our body in absorbing phosphorus and calcium from the food we eat. It deposits phosphorus and calcium in teeth and bones and makes them healthier and stronger. It also protects us from other infections by keeping our immune system healthy.

string.name: nutridd_vitaminE3viif
string.font:
Vitamin E



Vitamin E is an antioxidant which protects cells from damage and keeps the blood clean. It also aids our body in using vitamin K.

string.name: nutridd_vitaminK3viig
string.font:
Vitamin K



Vitamin K conjointly plays a job in alternative aspects of your health. ‘Osteoblasts’, the cells that deposit new bone tissue, think about fat-soluble vitamin K to operate properly, and this vitamin helps activate proteins that you simply have to be compelled to build healthy bones. This vitamin conjointly activates a macromolecule, referred to as ‘Ga6’, that is needed for brand new cell growth. Since ‘Ga6’ conjointly plays a job in system development, vitamin K may additionally contribute to healthy nerves.

string.name: nutridd_fatloss3viii_1
string.font:
Fat Loss (Cutting)



The exact biochemistry behind fat loss is a bit complicated and beyond the scope of this app. But I will try my best to explain the basic concept behind it.


According to the ‘First Law of Thermodynamics’ or the ‘Law of Conservation of Energy’, energy is neither created nor destroyed, rather it can only be transformed or transferred from one form to the other.

 This concept applies to both weight loss and weight gain in all organisms.

 Any organism requires a certain amount of energy depending on its size, to carry out various biochemical and physical processes occurring both inside and outside its body in order to survive and maintain its weight.

 This energy is obtained from the food that the organism consumes. If the amount of energy obtained from the food consumed by that organism is equal to the total energy required to survive and carry out physical activities, then the weight of the organism will remain unchanged and this quantity of energy is termed as Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) or maintenance Calories.


If the energy from the food consumed is higher than this ‘TDEE’, then the organism will gain weight as the excess energy or Calories from food will be transformed to mass in the form of new body cells (don’t confuse this with Einstein’s famous mass-energy equivalence relation or E = mc2,
this is just a rough explanation). These new cells contribute to 'weight gain' of the organism. This weight gain can either be in the form of fat cells, muscle cells, water retention, or in some cases an increase in BMD (Bone Mineral Density).
This process is known as anabolism or constructive metabolism.
This excess energy is termed as calorie surplus.


Conversely, the organism will lose weight due to the energy consumption being less than the TDEE. This process is known as catabolism or destructive metabolism.
This deficit in energy is termed as calorie deficit.


Now obviously this theory applies to human beings as well!


Before covering the of topic fat loss, let’s just clear the difference between 'fat loss' and 'weight loss'.



FAT LOSS = loss of body fat


WEIGHT LOSS = loss of body fat + muscle loss + water loss + loss of bone mass (in some cases)



Loss of bone mass due to reduction in BMD occurs only when exercising is completely ignored and proper nutrition (Calcium and Vitamin D intake) is also neglected. Loss of BMD usually occurs in extreme weight losses.


"For more info on loss of BMD, click ""here."



Muscle loss occurs as a result of inadequate protein intake and lack of resistance training. We will discuss about muscle loss and muscle gain in detail in the next section.


"For more info on water loss, click ""here."


 The following images will depict the differences between 'fat loss' and 'weight loss'.

font.div:
You definitely might have seen, read and heard tons of ways to lose fat on the internet and lifestyle magazines. For example:- “Lose 10 pounds in 1 week!”, “Lose 2 kg in 1 day!”, “1 trick to lose 2 pounds of belly fat overnight!”, “flat stomach hacks”, “magical detox diets”, “lemon juice diet”, “apple diet”, “burn fat with apple cider vinegar”, “egg diet”, “fat burners”, “body wraps!”, and the list is endless!

 If it was so easy to lose fat, then why is obesity a huge problem in the world?! Why don’t we see everyone in the streets with jacked physiques? Why does our “New Year’s resolution” always fail? The simple answer to this is that the above stated “shortcuts” are just 'marketing gimmicks' that are completely BULSH***ING YOU! There is unfortunately no secret or shortcut for achieving a good physique. Nothing in life worth having comes easy!

 It requires a BURNING DESIRE, dedication, determination, DISCIPLINE, hard work, PATIENCE, perseverance, and last but not the least, CONSISTENCY. CONSISTENCY is always the key!

 The only way to stay consistent is not through continuous motivation, but by ENJOYING the 'process' and not focussing on the 'results'. And the only way to enjoy the process is to stay in MODERATION. Going the 'extreme way' and aiming for 'perfection' is only going to waste your time, energy and money! (Like I did)

 Fitness is not a goal, it’s a lifestyle. It’s a marathon, not a 100 m race! How can you expect to reach the finishing line of a marathon in optimum time by 'sprinting' from the beginning? You have to take steady, moderate and consistent steps to reach the finishing line in the best time possible. The same applies here too.

 I sincerely apologise for my endless advices and detailed info, but my motive behind this is to change the ATTITUDE of the society towards fitness, as ATTITUDE CHANGES EVERYTHING. Based on my 3 years of experience (Starting from Dec 2016), I have learnt that fitness is an extremely complicated discipline and having a 'stereotypical mindset' and a 'dogmatic approach' towards it (the mindset I used to have) is only going to waste your time, energy and money (like I did).

 Given below are some images that depict the 'truth', and the 'correct' ways of losing fat:-

A \'moderate calorie deficit\' of \'300- 500 Calories per day\' is optimal for fat loss. A deficit of more than 500 Calories (extreme calorie deficit) can result in weight loss, and you know what weight loss is. In addition to that, extreme calorie deficit can cause various problems like:-\n\n

• Binge eating disorder

 Honestly, I did suffer with binge eating disorder during the 5th semester of my B.Tech due to severely dropping my daily caloric intake. I always had this mentality that the higher the calorie deficit, the faster I will reach my dream physique. When our body experiences extremely low caloric intake, it goes into the ‘survival mode’. In this mode, our body solely focuses on getting as many Calories as possible in order to survive, which eventually forces us to eat high Calorie fatty foods (the so called ‘forbidden’ foods) in UNBELIEVABLE quantities. This eventually made me end up in a ‘binge eating cycle’.


This was undoubtedly the WORST phase of my fitness journey as it literally stabbed me from the inside due to guilt and made me feel extremely lonely and isolated. And the problem with binge eating is that it’s a 'vicious cycle' that never stops. What I mean by that is when someone ends a binge, he/she starts feeling extremely guilty about it and ends up restricting his/her Calories drastically again the next day to ‘compensate’ for the binge. But after a day or so after restriction, his/her body again enters the ‘survival mode’ and forces him/her to somehow binge again. And the cycle goes on and on.

God forbid, if you are amongst those who are currently suffering from it, then based on my experience, the only way to come out of this cycle is to START EATING NORMALLY and STOP COUNTING YOUR CALORIES for about a week.
When your body gets back to the \'normal mode\' instead of the \'survival mode\', then start to track your Calories and NEVER maintain a deficit beyond 500 Calories!\n\n
"Click ""here"" for some more tips on how to stop binge eating or to stay away from it."\n\n
• Drastic reduction in BMR\n\n
• Weakening of immune system (Based on my experience, this can make you a lot more vulnerable to diseases like cold, flu, fever etc.)\n\n
• Fatigue and nutrient deficiencies\n\n
• Reduction of fertility in women due to reduction of estrogen\n\n
• The funniest and the scariest among these problems is:- ERECTILE DYSFUNCTION in men due to reduction in testosterone!!!\n\n

In order to attain a 'moderate deficit', we must know the approximate value of our TDEE. You can get access to many online maintenance calorie calculators through the internet. But these aren’t accurate as these calculators just utilise your age, gender, height and weight, and activity level to calculate your TDEE. But important factors like 'BODY FAT PERCENTAGE' and 'LEAN MUSCLE MASS' that have a huge influence on our BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate) aren’t included in these calculators.

 So some of the steps that I would recommend to find your TDEE are:-

 1. Wake up in the morning, do your bowel movements, and without eating anything, check your weight using a digital weighing machine.

 2. Consume the amount of Calories (TDEE) shown in the calculator for a day and don’t do any intense exercises on that day.

 3. Repeat STEP 1, the next day.

 4. If your weight remained the SAME, then the value in the calculator is almost accurate.

 5. If your weight DECREASED slightly, then your actual TDEE might be 100- 200 Calories ABOVE the calculator value.

 6. If your weight INCREASED slightly, then your actual TDEE might be 100- 200 Calories BELOW the calculator value.
"Click ""here"" for calculating your approximate TDEE."\n\n

I know that maintaining a track of Calories consumed can be annoying and tedious at the beginning, but eventually after 1 or 2 weeks, you will be able to count your Calories just by looking at the stuff you are eating.


Also make a habit of reading the nutrition labels of packed items to get a better idea of the pros and cons of that item.


The below image depicts why you still AREN'T losing fat:-
The below images depict the ways to stay CONSISTENT with the process of fat loss:-\n
Well, there are chances that HUNGER might \'consume you\' during the course of the day. The below image shows ways to tackle hunger during a fat loss program.\n\n
The most important way to stay consistent with your nutrition is to choose a style of eating that suits you.
The adoption of a style of eating and the foods needed to be incorporated in your nutrition plan is a HIGHLY PERSONAL CHOICE.

Nobody else can decide what’s good for you and what’s not. So, you need to experiment with different food choices and eating styles and pick the one with which 'YOU CAN STICK TO' for your LIFETIME. Please make sure that the foods are:-

 • TASTY

 • EASILY DIGESTIBLE by your body without any side effects like allergies or intolerances (like lactose intolerance or nut allergies)

 • NUTRIENT DENSE (to ensure adequate micronutrient intake)

 • HIGH IN FIBRE (to prevent overeating, to ensure adequate micronutrient intake and to improve your bowel movements)

 • HIGH IN PROTEIN (to prevent overeating, to maintain or even build muscle)

 • MODERATE in carbohydrates and fats.

string.name: nutridd_musclegain
string.font:
Muscle Gain (Muscle Hypertrophy aka Bulking)



Muscle hypertrophy too has an extremely complicated biochemistry behind it, which is way beyond the scope of this app. But I will try my best to explain it in the simplest way possible.


Muscles provide the driving force for all movements in our body like lifting, pulling, pushing, running, walking, pumping blood from heart, organ functions etc.

 There are 3 major types of muscles in the human muscular system:-

 • CARDIAC muscles, which are responsible for the function of our heart.

 • SMOOTH muscles, which are responsible for the function of our all other internal organs.

 • SKELETAL muscles, which are responsible for the movement of our bones.


 Cardiac and smooth muscles function involuntarily, i.e. they operate by themselves, unlike skeletal muscles, that function voluntarily (they are under our conscious control).

 Cardiac and smooth muscle growth is obviously not in our hands, so we are left with 'skeletal muscles', the muscles that are visible outside our body through our skin. So, fitness is concerned about skeletal muscle hypertrophy only.


Skeletal muscles contain approximately 75% water, 20% protein, 1–10% fat, and 1% glycogen.


The 4 MANDATORY and EQUALLY IMPORTANT conditions for muscle gain (muscle hypertrophy) are:-


• Intense resistance training


• Adequate protein intake (1.6 – 2.0 g / kg of body weight) to remain in a POSITIVE NITROGEN BALANCE.


• Staying close to TDEE by adequate intake of other macro and micro nutrients, in order to prevent the breakdown of protein for energy (a slight calorie deficit or a slight calorie surplus, usually 100-300 Calories).


• Adequate rest (7-9 hours daily)


 Failure to meet even one of the above conditions will NOT lead to muscle hypertrophy! PERIOD!

 So, why are the above stated conditions EQUALLY important? Let me explain.


When we carry out intense resistance training, many micro tears are formed in our muscle fibres. The repair of these micro tears is primarily carried out by protein and quality nutrition. New muscle fibres are produced to help replace and repair the damaged ones. This particular process is termed as Muscle Protein Synthesis or MPS
(as muscle fibres are made of protein). More fibres are produced to make up for the damaged ones, and this is where the actual muscle growth takes place. MPS occurs VERY SLOWLY when we are awake. However, the speed of this process is SIGNIFICANTLY ACCELERATED when we are ASLEEP. This is due to the fact that our body releases large amounts of 'anabolic muscle building hormones' like testosterone and
IGF-1 (Insulin-like Growth Factor-1) during our
REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep.

 So, the combination of all the above activities eventually leads to muscle hypertrophy. MPS lasts for about 24-48 hours after our resistance training session.

 As every repair process leads to the production of new muscle fibres and not muscle tissues, this muscle gain process is EXTREMELY SLOW. It takes months to see noticeable fat loss, but it takes YEARS to see noticeable muscle gains! So, PATIENCE is the key here.

 There is a difference between 'muscle gain' and 'weight gain'.



MUSCLE GAIN = increase in muscle mass (if the above conditions are met)


WEIGHT GAIN = increase in muscle mass (if the above conditions are met) + fat gain + water retention



Weight gain necessarily occurs due to a 'calorie surplus', but the same isn’t true for muscle gain. The fat gain and water retention occurs due to a 'high calorie surplus'.


Also weight gain doesn’t necessarily mean muscle gain. The entire calorie surplus can be stored in the form of fat or water retention if the above muscle building conditions are not met.


The storage of the excess Calories in our body in the form of fat, is our body’s way of storing energy for future use. This stored energy is utilised when our body doesn’t get the required energy to survive and carry our physical activities (TDEE). This occurs only when we are in a 'SLIGHT to MODERATE calorie deficit' (100-500 Calories). This process eventually leads to fat loss.


In the case of 'extreme calorie deficit' (greater than 500 Calories), our body starts tapping energy from both fats as well as muscles, which leads to muscle loss (muscle atrophy) as well, which is a part of weight loss.


The muscles in our body are METABOLICALLY ACTIVE tissues. This means that our body requires energy just to carry the muscle mass we have. Our body requires a decent amount of protein from nutrition for maintaining muscle mass. But this isn’t enough. The primary use of muscles in our body is to carry out physical activity of a particular intensity. If we just consume protein and don’t carry out intense physical activities like resistance training, there would probably be no reason for our body to maintain muscle mass. So our body chooses the path of losing the muscle mass. This process is termed as
muscle atrophy or muscle protein breakdown (MPD).


So, you ‘either use it, or lose it!’


Other important factors that lead to muscle atrophy are insufficient rest
(less than 7 hours per day) and overtraining. Insufficient rest at night and overtraining leads to elevated levels of 'CORTISOL', the 'stress hormone' responsible for MPD.


Some of the benefits of muscle gain are:-

 • Increase in BMD which leads to reduced risk of fractures

 • Increase in BMR which promotes fat loss

 • Increase in testosterone levels

 • Increased energy levels

 • Drastic improvements in confidence and self esteem

 • Improvement in body aesthetics



Resistance training to increase muscle mass can be done with free weights, gym machines, resistance bands or even bodyweight exercises. How much muscle mass you'll gain depends on a number of factors, including your genetics, training regimen, nutrition and hormone levels. Some people can gain muscle much faster than others because of their genes. Men typically have more mass than women due to 'higher' levels of 'testosterone'.


It's important to develop an exercise routine that 'challenges' your muscles. If you always do the same exercises with the same resistance, your body will adapt and you will stop seeing gains in muscle mass and strength.


Furthermore, your body needs to be properly nourished and hydrated to repair damaged muscle fibres after exercise and reap the benefits of weight training. You will see faster gains with a quality nutrition plan that provides plenty of protein and nutrients, and last but not the least, adequate rest of about 7-9 hours daily.
