string.name: nutridd_recdrugs
string.font:
Recreational Drugs



Recreational drugs affect your body's central nervous system. They affect how you think, feel and behave. The three main types are depressants, hallucinogens and stimulants:


• DEPRESSANTS slow or 'depress' the function of the central nervous system. They slow the messages going to and from your brain. In small quantities depressants can cause a person to feel relaxed and less inhibited. In large amounts they may cause vomiting, unconsciousness and death. Depressants affect your concentration and coordination, and slow your ability to respond to situations. It is important to not operate heavy machinery while taking depressants.
Alcohol, cannabis, GHB, opiates (heroin, morphine, codeine) and benzodiazepines (minor tranquillisers) are examples of depressants.


• HALLUCINOGENS distort your sense of reality. You may see or hear things that are not really there, or see things in a distorted way. Other effects can include emotional and psychological euphoria, jaw clenching, panic, paranoia, gastric upset and nausea.
Ketamine, LSD, PCP, 'magic mushrooms' and cannabis are examples of hallucinogens.


• STIMULANTS speed or 'stimulate' the central nervous system. They speed up messaging to and from the brain, making you feel more alert and confident. This can cause increased heart rate, blood pressure and body temperature, reduced appetite, agitation and sleeplessness. In large amounts stimulants may cause anxiety, panic, seizures, stomach cramps and paranoia.
Caffeine, nicotine, amphetamines (speed and Ice), cocaine and ecstasy (MDMA) are examples of stimulants.



Physical harms from drug use
 Drug use can affect short- and long-term health outcomes. Some of these health outcomes can be serious, and possibly irreversible.


Drug use can lead to risky or out of character behaviour. When affected by drugs:

 • You are more likely to have an accident (at home, in a car, or wherever you are).

 • You may be vulnerable to sexual assault or you may engage in unprotected sex. Either of these could lead to pregnancy and sexually transmitted infection.

 • You could commit a sexual assault or other violent act.

 • You may find it hard to sleep, think, reason, remember and solve problems.



Drug use can also result in long-term health outcomes that include:

 • harm to organs and systems in your body, such as your throat, stomach, lungs, liver, pancreas, heart, brain, nervous system.

 • cancer (such as lung cancer from inhaling drugs)

 • infectious disease, from shared injecting equipment and increased incidence of risk-taking behaviours

 • harm to your baby, if you are pregnant

 • acne, or skin lesions if the drug you are taking causes you to pick or scratch at your skin

 • needle marks and collapsed veins, if you inject regularly

 • baldness

 • male pattern hair growth in women, such as facial hair

 • jaw and teeth issues due to clenching and grinding your teeth; or bad breath, teeth cavities and gum disease

 • mood swings and erratic behaviour

 • addiction

 • psychosis (losing touch with reality)

 • accidental overdose

 • Higher risk of mental illness, depression, suicide and death.


"For more info, click ""here."



EFFECTS OF RECREATIONAL DRUGS ON FITNESS:-


BREATHING
 Depressant drugs such as cannabis, alcohol and opiates, slow down your breathing. Cannabis reduces your lung capacity, so it’s harder to get the oxygen your muscles need during sport. Opiates, such as heroin and codeine, slow down your breathing and narrow your airways. This makes it harder to breathe and reduces your breathing at a time when your body needs extra oxygen.


HEART RATE
 Stimulant drugs, such as cocaine, ecstasy and speed, increase your heart rate and put undue stress on your heart. Cocaine can cause heart attack and abnormal heart rhythm. When you use speed, the lack of blood to your heart can cause angina (severe chest pain). Depressants such as alcohol slow down your heart rate, meaning less oxygen-rich blood reaches your muscles.


MUSCLES
 The last thing you want during sport is to disrupt your coordination and relax your muscles. Depressants such as cannabis reduce your motor activity so it’s hard to coordinate your movements during sport. Alcohol is high in Calories so you may start piling on the weight. Stimulants increase your movements so you are more likely to injure yourself during sport. Cocaine at higher doses can act as an anaesthetic so you can’t feel pain and may play on after an injury, causing even more damage.


CONCENTRATION
 Depressants like cannabis, alcohol and opiates affect your alertness and concentration, so you are slower to react. Stimulants, such as cocaine, speed and ecstasy can make you irritable and restless – making you less focused on the game.


SENSES
 Hallucinogens like cannabis and magic mushrooms can play havoc with your senses. They affect your sights and sounds, which could disrupt your performance.


PAIN
 Some depressants, such as alcohol, cause mild anaesthesia or loss of feeling, so you may not notice when you’re injured. This can lead to delays in getting rapid treatment and in recovery.


BRAIN and BEHAVIOUR
 Stimulants, such as cocaine and speed, can keep you awake so you don’t get the rest you need and this can affect your performance. They also decrease your appetite when you should be replacing Calories after using so much energy. Side effects also include confusion, delirium and paranoia. At higher doses stimulants can cause you to become irritable and aggressive, they can also cause blood vessels in the brain to rupture leading to convulsions.


"For more info, click ""here."

string.name: nutridd_ped
string.font:
PEDs (Performance Enhancing Drugs)



Most serious athletes will tell you that the drive to win is fierce. Besides the satisfaction of personal accomplishment, athletes often pursue dreams of winning a medal for their country or securing a spot on a professional team. In such an environment, the use of performance-enhancing drugs has become increasingly common.

 But using performance-enhancing drugs (doping) has risks. Take the time to learn about the potential benefits, the health risks and the many unknowns regarding so-called performance-enhancing drugs such as anabolic steroids, androstenedione, human growth hormone, erythropoietin, diuretics, creatine and stimulants. You may decide that the benefits aren't worth the risks.


Anabolic steroids


What are they?
 Some athletes take a form of steroids known as anabolic-androgenic steroids or just anabolic steroids to increase their muscle mass and strength. The main anabolic steroid hormone produced by your body is testosterone.

 Testosterone has two main effects on your body:

 • Anabolic effects promote muscle building.

 • Androgenic effects are responsible for male traits, such as facial hair and a deeper voice.


 Some athletes take straight testosterone to boost their performance. The anabolic steroids used by athletes are often synthetic modifications of testosterone.

 These hormones have approved medical uses. But improving athletic performance isn't one of them.

 Why are these drugs so appealing to athletes? Besides making muscles bigger, anabolic steroids may reduce the muscle damage that occurs during a hard workout, helping athletes recover from the session more quickly and enabling them to work out harder and more frequently. Some athletes, as well as non-athletes, may like the muscular appearance they get when they take the drugs.


Designer steroids

 A particularly dangerous class of anabolic steroids are the so-called designer drugs — synthetic steroids that have been illicitly created to be undetectable by current drug tests. They are made specifically for athletes and have no approved medical use. Because of this, they haven't been tested or approved by the
Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and represent a particular health threat to athletes.


Risks
 Many athletes take anabolic steroids at doses that are much higher than those prescribed for medical reasons. Anabolic steroids have serious physical side effects.


Men may develop:

 • Prominent breasts

 • Shrunken testicles

 • Infertility

 • Prostate gland enlargement



Women may develop:

 • A deeper voice, which may be irreversible

 • An enlarged clitoris, which may be irreversible

 • Increased body hair

 • Baldness, which may be irreversible

 • Infrequent or absent periods



Both men and women might experience:

 • Severe acne

 • Increased risk of tendinitis and tendon rupture

 • Liver abnormalities and tumours

 • Increased low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol (the "bad" cholesterol)

 • Decreased high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol (the "good" cholesterol

 • High blood pressure (hypertension)

 • Heart and blood circulation problems

 • Aggressive behaviours, rage or violence

 • Psychiatric disorders, such as depression

 • Drug dependence

 • Infections or diseases such as HIV or hepatitis if you're injecting the drugs

 • Inhibited growth and development, and risk of future health problems in teenagers



Androstenedione


What is it?
 Androstenedione (andro) is a hormone produced by the adrenal glands, ovaries and testes. It's a hormone that's normally converted to testosterone and a form of estrogen (estradiol) in both men and women.

 Andro is available legally only by prescription and is a controlled substance. Its use as a performance-enhancing drug is illegal.

 Manufacturers and bodybuilding magazines tout andro's ability to allow athletes to train harder and recover more quickly. Scientific studies that refute these claims show that supplemental androstenedione doesn’t increase testosterone and that your muscles don't get stronger with andro use.


Risks
 Side effects of andro in men include:

 • Acne

 • Diminished sperm production

 • Shrinking of the testicles

 • Enlargement of the breasts


 In women, side effects include:

 • Acne

 • Masculinization, such as deepening of the voice and male-pattern

 • baldness


 In both men and women, andro can damage the heart and blood vessels, increasing the risk of heart attack and stroke.


Human growth hormone (HGH)


What is it?
 Human growth hormone (HGH) is a hormone that has an anabolic effect. Athletes take it to improve muscle mass and performance. However, it hasn't been shown conclusively to improve either strength or endurance.

 Human growth hormone is available only by prescription and is administered by injection.


Risks
 Adverse effects related to human growth hormone range in severity and may include:

 • Joint pain

 • Muscle weakness

 • Fluid retention

 • Diabetes

 • Vision problems

 • Carpal tunnel syndrome

 • Impaired glucose regulation

 • Enlarged heart (cardiomegaly)

 • High blood pressure (hypertension)



Erythropoietin


What is it?
 Erythropoietin is a type of hormone used to treat anaemia in people with severe kidney disease. It increases production of red blood cells and haemoglobin — the protein that carries oxygen to your body's organs.

 Taking erythropoietin improves the movement of oxygen to the muscles. 'Epoetin', a synthetic form of erythropoietin, is commonly used by endurance athletes.


Risks
 Erythropoietin use among competitive cyclists was common in the 1990s and allegedly contributed to at least 18 deaths. Inappropriate use of erythropoietin may increase the risk of stroke, heart attack and blockage in an artery in the lung (pulmonary embolism).



Diuretics


What are they?
 Diuretics are drugs that change your body's natural balance of fluids and salts (electrolytes), which can lead to dehydration. This loss of water can decrease an athlete's weight, which many athletes prefer. Diuretics may also help athletes pass drug tests by diluting their urine and are sometimes referred to as a "masking" agent.


Risks
 Diuretics taken at any dose, even medically recommended doses, predispose athletes to adverse effects such as:

 • Dehydration

 • Muscle cramps

 • Dizziness

 • Potassium deficiency

 • Drop in blood pressure

 • Loss of coordination and balance

 • Death



Creatine


What is it?
 Many athletes take nutritional supplements instead of or in addition to performance-enhancing drugs. Supplements are available over-the-counter as powders or pills. Creatine monohydrate is a supplement that's popular among athletes.

 Creatine is a naturally occurring compound produced by your body that helps your muscles release energy. Scientific research indicates that creatine may have some athletic benefit by producing small gains in short-term bursts of power.

 Creatine appears to help muscles make more Adenosine Triphosphate (ATP), which stores and transports energy in cells, and is used for quick bursts of activity, such as weightlifting or sprinting. But there's no evidence that creatine enhances performance in aerobic or endurance sports.


Risks
 Possible side effects of creatine that can decrease athletic performance include:

 • Stomach cramps

 • Muscle cramps

 • Weight gain


 Weight gain is sought by athletes who want to increase their size. But with prolonged creatine use, weight gain is more likely the result of water retention than an increase in muscle mass. Water is drawn into your muscle tissue, away from other parts of your body, putting you at risk of dehydration.

 It appears safe for adults to use creatine at the doses recommended by manufacturers. But there are no studies investigating the long-term benefits and risks of creatine supplementation.


Stimulants


What are they?
 Some athletes use stimulants to stimulate the central nervous system and increase heart rate and blood pressure.

 Stimulants can:

 • Improve endurance

 • Reduce fatigue

 • Suppress appetite

 • Increase alertness and aggressiveness


 Common stimulants include
caffeine and
amphetamines (Sounds familiar right?). Cold remedies often contain the stimulants 'ephedrine' or 'pseudoephedrine hydrochloride'.

 Energy drinks, which are popular among many athletes, often contain high doses of caffeine and other stimulants. The street drugs
cocaine and
methamphetamine (Jesse's favourite xD) also are stimulants.


Risks
 Although stimulants can boost physical performance and promote aggressiveness on the field, they have side effects that can impair athletic performance, including:

 • Nervousness and irritability, which make it hard to concentrate on the game

 • Insomnia, which can prevent an athlete from getting needed sleep

 • Dehydration

 • Heatstroke

 • Addiction or tolerance, meaning that athletes need greater amounts to achieve the desired effect, so they'll take doses that are much higher than the intended medical dose


 Other side effects include:

 • Heart palpitations

 • Heart rhythm abnormalities

 • Weight loss

 • Tremors

 • Mild high blood pressure (hypertension)

 • Hallucinations

 • Stroke

 • Heart attack and other circulatory problems



The bottom line

 Do performance-enhancing drugs boost performance? Some athletes may appear to achieve physical gains from such drugs, but at what cost?

 The long-term effects of performance-enhancing drugs haven't been rigorously studied. And short-term benefits are tempered by many risks. Not to mention that doping is prohibited by most sports organizations.

 No matter how you look at it,
using performance-enhancing drugs is a RISKY business.

string.name: nutridd_myth6
string.font:
High Glycemic Index (GI) foods are HARMFUL!!



We might have come across the term ‘high Glycemic Index’ and ‘low Glycemic Index’ foods and their association with 'type 2 diabetes'. The ‘high GI’ foods have got a bad reputation as they spike blood sugar levels and may lead to an increased risk of 'type 2 diabetes' and 'obesity', and so, they must be completely avoided.


Due to this, some of the foods that have got a bad reputation include white rice, white bread, watermelon, pumpkin, white potato, honey and other common starchy foods. Even I started to completely avoid these ‘forbidden’ foods. I seriously DID NOT enjoy avoiding these foods as I loved them a lot.


But then one day, I tried to find out what was actually inside these foods that made them so ‘bad’. To my surprise, there was NOTHING WRONG with the nutrient composition of these foods. In fact, their nutrient profile stated that they were ONE OF THE HEALTHIEST FOODS to be included in our nutrition plan.


After again including some of these 'forbidden foods' in MODERATION in my nutrition plan, I actually started to ENJOY my nutrition plan even more as it kept me more ENERGETIC and HAPPIER throughout the day.


"This article"" explains why ‘high GI’ foods are not necessarily harmful if consumed in moderation.

"
However, people already suffering from type 2 diabetes must limit the consumption of these foods and always eat them with foods rich in fibre, protein or fats.

string.name: nutridd_myth7
string.font:
There is a limit to the amount of protein (20-30g) to be consumed in one serving, to be utilised for Muscle Protein Synthesis!!



This is one of the TRICKIEST myths in the fitness industry and anyone who is new to fitness will definitely get consumed by this myth (this included me). You will always find this statement being reiterated by popular gym bros and even by some fitness experts in social networking websites to the newbies in fitness!


The above statement can prove a BIG HINDRANCE to the 'muscle hypertrophy' of those who incorporate ‘intermittent fasting’ ("For more info about intermittent fasting, click ""here"), who consume huge amounts of protein in one serving.


Well, the good news is that the above statement is NOT TRUE as there is no solid evidence to prove the above hypothesis.


The given videos will explain why this is the case.

"Video 1"


"Video 2"



"This article"" also proves the above theory to be FALSE.

" However, it can still be helpful for many people to reach their protein needs and improve their energy and blood sugar levels by 'spreading' protein intake throughout the day.

string.name: nutridd_myth8
string.font:
High intake of 'Dietary cholesterol' increases 'Serum cholesterol' levels, leading to increased risk of Heart diseases!!



We might have seen many people and the typical gym bros skipping egg yolks (including me xD) and emphasizing more on egg whites, just because they believe that egg yolks are high in cholesterol and so, their consumption can lead to increased risk of heart diseases.


Now according to Science and Nutrition research, this is just 'BS'. In fact, consumption of egg yolks can IMPROVE our 'heart health' and take us AWAY from 'heart diseases'. On top of that, egg yolks are one of the most 'NUTRIENT DENSE' foods on the planet. It’s the EGG YOLK that makes an egg a ‘SUPER-FOOD’, NOT the albumin (egg white).


"This video"" and "
"this article"" explain why 'dietary cholesterol' has NOTHING TO DO with 'serum (blood) cholesterol'.

"
However, people suffering from 'type 2 diabetes' must limit their egg yolk consumption as the above theory CAN PROVE TRUE for them.

string.name: nutridd_myth10
string.font:
You can’t build muscle and burn fat simultaneously!!



I have already covered the topic of fat loss and muscle gain. It is definitely true without a doubt that you need to be in a state of calorie deficit to lose fat, but you DON’T have to be in a state of calorie surplus to build muscle.


So, the above theory is completely FALSE. The process of building muscle and burning fat simultaneously is known as BODY RECOMPOSTION. This ‘recomposition’ process is slower than the traditional ‘bulking’ and ‘cutting’ cycles and requires a lot more planning and carefulness while executing it.

 This process gets SLOWER as the ‘overall body fat percentage’ DECREASES and ‘overall muscle mass’ INCREASES.


"For more info and better understanding of ‘body recomposition’, please click "
"here"" and "
"here."

string.name: nutridd_myth11
string.font:
You can burn 'stubborn belly fat' by doing 'ab exercises'!!



This is one of the most common myths concerning abs. You can still find tons of videos and images on almost all social networking sites giving a list of core exercises that focus on targeting belly fat loss. Now that is simply a bunch of freaking BS!!


There is NO such exercise to burn belly fat!! It’s not just belly fat, you can find videos on YouTube that promise the burning of arm fat, chest fat, shoulder fat etc. Exercises are meant to STRENGTHEN OUR JOINTS and MUSCLES, NOT for burning fat.


The most important and sufficient factor that decides fat loss is 'CALORIE DEFICIT'. No matter how high your sets, reps or intensity might be, if you do not maintain an overall calorie deficit throughout the day, you will NOT lose fat!!


The so-called 'belly fat targeting core exercises' are meant to 'strengthen our core and hip flexor muscles', not to burn belly fat. Even if we do manage to maintain an overall calorie deficit throughout the day, we will lose fat EVENLY throughout our body, i.e. from our face, neck, shoulders, chest, arms, back, glutes, legs, feet and finally from our core.


SPOT FAT REDUCTION IS A HUGE MYTH!!


The fat in our core (stubborn abdominal fat and love handles) are the FIRST ones to accumulate in a state of calorie surplus, and are simply the LAST ones to disappear in a state of calorie deficit. This means that you will experience fat loss from your core only after the occurrence of fat loss from all other areas of your body!


If you can’t buy this, then let’s for once believe the above hypothesis to be true. If that’s the case, then just imagine how WEIRD people might start to appear when they have some parts of their body completely free from fat and some parts completely surrounded by fat. Just the imagination of that situation makes me laugh!


Omar Isuf, a popular Canadian fitness YouTuber shares his experience about fat loss in
this video and explains why 'spot fat reduction' DOES NOT happen.


However according to recent research, 'spot fat reduction' has seemed to be POSSIBLE!! Shocked? No problem, I completely understand. Just watch
this video
TILL THE END to get a clearer picture about what I have just mentioned.

string.name: anatomy1
string.font:
Important Anatomy Fundamentals



Major Muscle Groups

 You might be wondering why the hell is this app turning out into a boring biology class xD!! I completely understand that. Even I used to hate biology in my schooling (no offence to those who love it, it’s just my personal opinion). But physical fitness is literally NOTHING without BIOCHEMISTRY and BIOMECHANICS. Having no idea about the muscles being worked whilst performing a particular exercise is like having no idea of the pros and cons of eating a particular food item.

 You need to have an answer to the questions like ‘why’, ‘what’, ‘how’ and ‘where’ regarding a particular exercise, in order to perform it CORRECTLY and SAFELY. The part of the answer to the ‘why’ question is:-
"Which muscle group does the exercise work?" Don’t worry; you don’t have to go too deep into 'muscle anatomy'. You just need to know the 'basics of the muscular system', 'types of muscle fibres' and the 'major muscle groups' in our body.

 Just watch the given videos to get an idea of the above quoted topics.


• The Muscular System


• Types of Muscle Fibres


• Major Muscle Groups


Those who are more interested in the details of each muscle group, can make use of the following two images.

font.div:
As far as the execution of an exercise is concerned, the only 3 components of our skeletal system that will frequently appear in tutorials are:-


• Spine (vertebral column)
• Scapula (shoulder blade in the upper back)\n\n
• Pelvic Tilt\n\n

Spine

 The below image depicts the basic anatomy of the spine.

It’s very important to keep your 'spine' (or back) COMPLETELY STRAIGHT while 'sitting' or 'standing' to IMPROVE POSTURE, and also while executing most of the exercises (deadlifts, squats, push ups, handstand, front lever, back lever, planche etc.) in order to prevent 'lower back (lumbar spine) injuries'.

Scapula

 The given image shows the 'location of the scapula' in our skeletal system.
The given image shows the various muscles attached to the scapula.
This video shows the 6 scapular movements and the muscles involved while performing them.

Pelvic Tilt

 

Another variable that decides our posture is the pelvic tilt. There are 2 types of pelvic tilts:-
• Anterior Pelvic Tilt (APT)\n\n

• Posterior Pelvic Tilt (PPT). 

 The following image depicts them.

As far as \'natural posture\' is concerned, both APT and PPT are termed as \'bad postures\' as they can lead to problems in the \'lumbar spine\' (lower back) in the longer run.\n\n But as far as exercise execution is concerned, PPT can be BENEFICIAL as it helps to \'activate the glutes and core muscles\'. PPT is always maintained while performing almost all core related exercises like planche, deadlift, front lever, back lever, handstand, L-sit etc.
APT is considered BAD in ALL aspects.\n\n
This video shares some of the exercises to be done to FIX YOUR \'APT\' (if you have it).\n

string.name: goalsetting
string.font:
Goal Setting



You might have heard this advice a million times from people and from the internet on how to set your goals to achieve something big in your life. And undoubtedly, this is the MOST IMPORTANT advice in fitness too. Without proper goal setting, you will only end up wasting your time, energy and money.

 The goals may differ from person to person. As far as fitness is concerned, some of the different types of goals are:-

 • Fat loss

 • Muscle gain

 • Both fat loss and muscle gain simultaneously

 • Strength gain

 • Speed improvement

 • Stamina improvement

 • Cardiovascular endurance improvement

 • Muscular endurance improvement

 • Mastering a sport

 • Powerlifting competition

 • Bodybuilding competition

 • Achieving gymnastics and calisthenics skills

 • Flexibility and mobility improvement

 And the list goes on and on…



You might have heard of the popular saying:-

 “A goal without a plan is just a wish!”

 The reason why you need to set or pick a particular goal is because
different goals have different action plans. You can’t follow the same training routine to achieve different goals simultaneously. Picking some random training plan is only going to give you random results.
The FASTEST way to achieve a specific goal is to have a SPECIFIC ACTION PLAN (training plan). Let me give you some examples to explain what exactly I mean by this.

 • Powerlifting training, strength training, hypertrophy (muscle gain) training and endurance training are different things. All of them have different training plans. So, choosing a specific training plan for achieving a specific goal from the above is the best way to go. Expecting optimum muscle hypertrophy by following the other training plans is a waste of time. We will discuss about these types of training in more detail later.

 • If you want to improve your CARDIOVASCULAR ENDURANCE for a marathon, then 'speed training' WON’T help you in any way.

 • If you want to improve your SMASHING POWER in badminton, then the best way to achieve it would be to actually 'practise your smash regularly'.

 • Instead of focusing on attaining various gymnastic or calisthenics skills simultaneously, it would be much better to shift your focus on attaining only 'ONE skill AT A TIME'. I know that sounds boring, and it actually is boring to train for only one skill at a time till you attain it, but unfortunately it’s this boring stuff that’s going to take you faster towards attaining that skill. That applies to other things in life as well.
Focusing and working towards ONE GOAL AT A TIME is the FASTEST way to achieve it.



Another important thing to remember is that as different individuals have different goals, COMPARING your progress with that of others is simply UNNECESSARY. Even if they have the same goal as that of yours, every individual has got a 'UNIQUE CAPACITY', 'SPEED OF LEARNING' and 'ADAPTING TO CHANGE', and so, comparing yourself with others even in this situation ISN’T a good idea.


So, JUST FOCUS ON YOUR OWN GOAL AND PROGRESS!!

string.name: cardio
string.font:
Cardiovascular or Aerobic exercises



Any physical activity that significantly increases your breathing rate and heart rate (cardiovascular activity) can be considered as a cardiovascular exercise or simply ‘cardio’. The reason why these exercises are termed as ‘cardiovascular’ is not simply because they increase your cardiovascular activity, but more importantly they IMPROVE YOUR CARDIOVASCULAR HEALTH. Depending on the intensity, cardio exercises can be classified as Low Intensity Steady State (LISS) cardio and
High Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) cardio.


There are hundreds of different types of cardio exercises. Some of the most common exercises among them are:-

 • Brisk walking

 • Slow to fast jogging

 • Sprinting

 • Swimming

 • Cycling

 • Sports (football, badminton, tennis, basketball, volleyball, cricket etc.)

 • Athletics

 • Dancing

 • Tabata

 • Zumba or dance workout

 • Skipping


 The problem with today’s society is that due to the 'high calorie burning rate' of cardio exercises, these exercises have been equated to 'fat loss'. Whenever anyone hears the term ‘fat loss’, the first thing that comes in his/her mind is ‘cardio’. Due to this mentality, most of the people today start doing endless cardio sessions from 'Jan 1 every year' (you know why) in order to lose body fat and get to their dream muscular physique, which is far from the best way of achieving it.

 Cardio exercises cannot lead to significant muscle gain as these exercises only activate your ‘Type I’ or 'slow twitch' muscle fibres. For muscle hypertrophy, your need to activate your ‘Type IIa’ and ‘Type IIx’ muscle fibres ('fast twitch' muscle fibres). And also, despite the high calorie burning rate of cardio exercises, you WON’T experience any fat loss if you AREN’T in a ‘net Calorie deficit’ or your daily net Calorie consumption (Calories through food – Calories burnt by any physical activity) is above your TDEE (Total Daily Energy Expenditure).

 So, looking at cardio exercises through a ‘fat loss’ perspective is simply a FOOLISH idea! These exercises can ‘AID’ you in attaining a 'Calorie deficit', but CANNOT certainly ‘GUARANTEE’ you one!

 Therefore, a better perspective to look at cardio exercises would be to simply consider their other important benefits like:-

 • Improved heart health

 • Improved lung capacity

 • Reduced risk of heart diseases, high serum cholesterol, hypertension, diabetes, cancer etc.

 • Improved stamina, speed and endurance

 • Improved confidence and energy levels

 • Improved mood due to release of endorphins

 • Temporary relief from depression, anxiety and stress

 • Improved sleep



Your next question might be:-


“Which is the best cardio exercise?”

 The simple answer to this is:-
"There is NO best cardio exercise!" Every cardio exercise has its own pros and cons.
Choose the type of cardio exercise THAT SUITS YOU. What I mean by that is, choose those cardio exercises that you
REALLY ENJOY and with which
YOU CAN STICK TO FOR YOUR LIFETIME. Doing an exercise that feels like a burden and makes you feel fatigued, should be simply AVOIDED.

string.name: intro_res_training1
string.font:
Introduction to Resistance Training



Resistance training is any form of physical activity that involves your skeletal muscles (Type I, Type IIa and Type IIx muscle fibres) to work against a 'RESISTIVE FORCE'. The 'resistive force' can be provided by literally any external weight like a
book, bag, bottle, suitcase, cricket bat, dumbbells, barbells, kettlebells, weight plates, resistance bands, your own bodyweight against gravity etc.


You might question:-


“What’s the difference between cardio and resistance training?”


The main difference between cardio and resistance training is that most of the cardio exercises train your cardiovascular endurance and activate mostly Type I muscle fibres. Some HIIT exercises do activate your Type IIa and Type IIx muscle fibres, but they don’t necessarily train your muscles to be stronger. On the other hand, all resistance training exercises activate all the 3 muscle fibre types, leading to an increase in 'muscular strength', 'endurance' and 'hypertrophy'.


Resistance training can be broadly categorised into the following types depending on individual goals:-


Powerlifting training

 This training involves performing the 3 major powerlifting moves namely DEADLIFTS, SQUATS and BENCHPRESS. All these moves will be performed using weight plates on both sides of a barbell. The specified amount of sets, reps, rest period between sets and the
training frequency (no. of training sessions per week) for this type of training are given below.
The weight chosen to lift depends on person to person and it’s usually the weight that can be heavy enough to manage the given number of reps per set. This is known as
RM or Rep Max. For example, 1RM means performing any exercise with a weight with which you can manage a maximum of 1 rep, 3 reps in case of 3RM, 5 reps in case of 5RM and so on. This weight selection concept applies for other training types as well.

font.div:
Strength training


This type of training is very common in calisthenics and gymnastics, where the KEY FOCUS is always on ‘GETTING STRONGER’.


This training involves performing any resistance training exercise (except mobility and flexibility exercises) using any kind of resistance (dumbbells, barbells, bodyweight, resistance bands etc.) for a specified amount of the above stated variables. They are:-

Hypertrophy training

 This training is SAME AS 'strength training' when it comes to 'exercise selection'. It only differs in the 'weight selection' and the other stated variables. They are:-

Endurance training (Muscular Endurance)


This training also differs in the 'weight selection' and other variables. They are:-

Flexibility and mobility training\n\n
The resistance can also be provided to your
Agonist muscles (that cause a particular movement) by your

Antagonist muscles (that inhibit a particular movement). This type of resistance is involved in flexibility ‘AND’ mobility training. The best example of this is 'YOGA'.

 There are hundreds of different flexibility exercises in yoga. Also, yoga is not just about performing exercises, it’s a much more complicated discipline. So, explaining yoga in detail is beyond the scope of this app.

 However, some of the common
yoga asanas are shown in

this video.\n\n
You might have noticed that I emphasised the word ‘AND’ between flexibility and mobility. That’s because unfortunately, \'flexibility\' and \'mobility\' are often used interchangeably (by using ‘OR’ between them) in today’s fitness community. But the truth is,
they are 2 different things.\n\n

This video explains the difference between them.


The dynamic and static stretching exercises can be good enough for improving your overall flexibility and mobility. Some additional exercises to further improve your overall flexibility and mobility are shown in the following videos:-
Video 1\n\n

Video 2



Now, before moving further with the exercises in resistance training, I would recommend you to first go through all the terms related to resistance training

here, so that you don’t get confused later on.


You can always come back and refer to the above link to review the meanings of the terms.


The main goal of any training program is simple:-
“Always strive to improve!” The process of training with a performance HIGHER than that of our previous training session is termed as
PROGRESSIVE OVERLOAD. This leads to improved \'strength\', \'endurance\' and \'muscle size\' (hypertrophy). The various ways to progressively overload are:-\n\n
Make sure to ALWAYS perform any exercise with STRICT FORM in order to reap the benefits of it and stay far away from injuries. With that being said,
CAREFULLY CHOOSE THE WEIGHTS according to the REP RANGES you want to perform. Lifting heavy weights at the expense of strict form is a HUGE MISTAKE.

The \'risk of injury\' is heavily dependent on IMPROPER FORM, NOT with heavy weights. Performing an exercise with improper form even with light weights will definitely lead to injuries in the longer run. Performing an exercise with \'strict form\' is also the KEY to the FASTEST PROGRESSION with it.\n\n

string.name: gym_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Basic Resistance Training exercises in Gym



There are tons and tons of different exercises that can be performed in a gym.

 But fortunately, you don’t have to do a hell lot of different exercises over there in order to build strength, muscle and endurance. Just performing the exercises mentioned in this section would be MORE THAN SUFFICIENT for building your 'DREAM PHYSIQUE'.

 There are 2 broad categories of exercises that can be performed in a gym. They are:-

 • Compound exercises

 • Isolation exercises

string.name: comp_exer_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Compound exercises



Compound exercises are the exercises that activate MULTIPLE MUSCLE GROUPS simultaneously. Below mentioned are some of the merits and demerits of compound exercises.

 Merits:-

 • Help to quickly build overall body strength

 • Help in saving time as multiple muscles are trained simultaneously

 • Burn more calories due to multiple muscle activation

 • Improve intra-muscular coordination

 • Elevate heart rate

 • Improve overall joint flexibility and mobility

 • Help to gain muscle mass evenly throughout the body

 • Helps improve posture

 • They simulate real-world movements, eventually helping in building strength for everyday living (lifting a heavy suitcase, lowering a heavy suitcase from the top shelf slowly and safely to the ground, washing clothes etc.)



Demerits:-

 • Performing these exercises with IMPROPER FORM can lead to SERIOUS INJURIES in the short as well as long term. Due to this 'PROPER WEIGHT SELECTION' is absolutely CRUCIAL to perform the movement correctly in order to stay injury free.

 • The benefits of compound exercises may differ from person to person depending on his/her height, limb length, anatomical limits for range of motion etc. Due to this, the extent of activation of specific muscle groups might be different for everyone. For example, a squat can lead to better activation of the quadriceps of a shorter individual, as compared to a taller one. Advanced exercises like
front lever, back lever and planche require balancing of the upper body and lower body using our 'ARMS' as the 'FULCRUM'. These exercises get significantly TOUGHER with INCREASE in the 'length of the arms and legs'. Due to this, these exercises tend to become MORE challenging for TALLER individuals.

 • It would be impossible for you to perform compound exercises if you are recovering from an injury. In such situations, isolation exercises come in handy. For example, if you are recovering from a shoulder injury, then you literally won’t be able to do any pushing and pulling compound exercise that requires even a slight manipulation of that particular shoulder joint. You would however be able to do isolation exercises like the cable tricep extension or a bicep curl with lighter weights. (This is based on my experience with ‘shoulder impingement’).



Now let’s move on to the basic and the most important compound exercises that need to be incorporated in your training regime in the gym.


NOTE:- Throughout this app, I will be making use of VIDEOS in order to demonstrate 'what the exercise is', 'what muscles does it activate', 'how to perform it with proper form' and 'what mistakes should be avoided' to stay INJURY FREE. Based on my experience, VIDEOS can help you quickly and efficiently learn the correct form of execution of any exercise.


So, PLEASE watch all the videos COMPLETELY with FULL ATTENTION.

string.name: deadlifts1
string.font:
Deadlifts



The Deadlift is a weight training exercise in which a loaded barbell or bar is lifted off the ground to the level of the hips, torso perpendicular to the floor, before being placed back on the ground. It is one of the three 'POWERLIFTING' exercises, along with the 'SQUAT' and 'BENCH PRESS'.

 Deadlift is also termed as the
‘King of all compound exercises’. It’s termed so as it works almost your entire body. This is definitely one of my favourite exercises in the gym. If I was asked to pick only one exercise to be done in the gym for my lifetime, then it would definitely be deadlifts.



Muscles worked:-

 • Quadriceps
 • Glutes
 • Adductor Magnus (Inner Thigh)
 • Hamstrings
 • Erectors
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Trapezius
 • Rhomboids
 • Brachioradialis (forearm)
 • Biceps
 • Rectus abdominis
 • External obliques
 • Serratus anterior


 The BENEFITS of 'Deadlifts' are given
here.


There are 3 main types of deadlifts. They are:-



Conventional Deadlift

this tutorial for 'Conventional Deadlift'.

string.name: barbell_squats0
string.font: Barbell Squats\n

font.div: A Barbell Squat is one of the 3 POWERLIFTING exercises in which the individual lowers their hips from a standing position and then stands back up.\n\n During the descent of a squat, the hip and knee joints flex while the ankle joint undergoes
dorsiflexion; conversely the hip and knee joints extend and the ankle joint undergoes

plantar flexion when standing up.


You might be wondering:-

“What the hell is 'dorsiflexion' and 'plantar flexion'?”


Well, the following image answers your question.

Muscles worked:-

 • Gluteus maximus, minimus and medius (butts)
 • Quadriceps (front of the thigh)
 • Hamstrings (back of the thigh)
 • Adductor (groin)
 • Hip flexors
 • Rectus abdominis (abs)
 • Obliques
 • Transverse abdominis
 • Erector spinae
Click here to know the BENEFITS of \'Barbell Squats\'.\n\n
Click here for the TUTORIAL.\n\n

Click here for the MISTAKES to be avoided.



Now, it’s very important for you to improve your HIP MOBILITY in order to squat deep. If you are an 'Asian' or an 'Indian' like me, who uses ‘Asian’ or ‘Indian style’ toilets (squat toilets), then squatting deep would be a ‘cakewalk’ for you.


This is because we 'Asians' are used to squatting deep since our birth as we need to be in a ‘deep squatting position’ while pooping in ‘squat toilets’, instead of being in a ‘seated position’ while using ‘western style’ toilets. The ‘deep squatting position’ can turn into a ‘resting position’ for those who are used to ‘squat toilets’.


So, a good way to improve your hip mobility for achieving the deep squat would be to either use ‘squat toilets’ or to simply practice pooping on western style toilets by keeping both feet on the sides of the toilet seat instead of sitting on it.

string.font:

 A
lunge can refer to any position of the human body where one leg is positioned forward with knee bent and foot flat on the ground while the other leg is positioned behind.

string.name: benchpress1
string.font:
Bench Press



The Bench Press is an upper-body weight training exercise in which the trainee presses a weight upwards while lying on a weight training bench. This exercise is one among the 3 POWERLIFTING exercises. This exercise is mainly performed for building our
chest muscles (Pectoralis major).



Muscles worked:-

 • Pectoralis major (chest)
 • Serratus anterior
 • Latissimus dorsi (lats)
 • Triceps brachii
 • Biceps
 • Anterior deltoids (front shoulders)
 • Forearms



There are 3 main variations of a 'bench press'. They are:-



Flat Bench Press (for targeting our 'overall chest')

font.div: Click here for the 'Flat Bench Bress' TUTORIAL.
Incline Bench Press (for targeting \'upper chest\')\n
Click here for 'Incline Bench Press' TUTORIAL.
Decline Bench Press (for targeting \'lower chest\')\n
Click here for \'Decline Bench Press\' TUTORIAL.\n\n
This video clearly explains the DIFFERENCES between them.\n\n
Click here to know the BENEFITS of \'Bench Press\'.\n\n

Click here for 'Bench Press' MISTAKES to be avoided.



Choose any of the above stated Bench Press variations depending on your goal and interest. You can perform all of them if you want. It’s completely up to you :)

string.name: ohp1
string.font:
Overhead Press (OHP)\n\n\n
The Overhead Press or
\'Shoulder Press\' or
\'Military Press\' is a weight training exercise with many variations, typically performed while standing, in which a weight is pressed straight upwards from racking position until the arms are locked out overhead, while the legs, lower back and abs maintain balance. This exercise is my second most favourite after \'Deadlifts\'. This is a great exercise for improving \'VERTICAL PUSHING STRENGTH\' and building
\'3-D shoulders\'.\n

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Anterior deltoids (front shoulders)
 • Lateral deltoids (middle shoulders)
 • Posterior deltoids (rear shoulders)
 • Trapezius (upper back)
 • Pectoralis major (chest)
 • Triceps brachii
 • Serratus anterior
 • Forearms
Click here to know the BENEFITS of \'Overhead Press\'.\n\n
Click here to view the TUTORIAL for \'Overhead Press\'.\n\n
Click here to view some of the \'Overhead Press\' MISTAKES to be avoided.\n\n

string.name: barbellrows1
string.font:
Rows



Rowing exercises are HORIZONTAL PULLING exercises that involve pulling a weight or resistance acting perpendicular to our torso and away from it, towards our torso using our hands. Simply put, they are OPPOSITE to HORIZONTAL PUSHING exercises like the 'Bench Press'. These exercises mainly emphasize our
'back muscles' and 'lats'.

 There are 5 common types of rowing exercises in the gym. They are:-



Single arm Dumbbell Rows

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Rhomboids
 • Trapezius
 • Teres major and minor
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Posterior deltoids
 • Brachialis
 • Brachioradialis
 • Infraspinatus
 • Pectoralis major (chest)


 Please click on the following 'blue' links.
BENEFITS (in the ‘benefits’ section).\n\n

BENEFITS:- Same as that of 'Barbell Rows'.

 Please click on the following 'blue' links.

This row type is similar to the 'Barbell Row'. The only difference is that in this row, your back remains parallel to the ground and you lift the barbell from the ground (dead position) instead of lifting it from mid-air as in the case of barbell rows.

 Muscles worked:- Same as that of the above rows.

BENEFITS:- Same as that of the above rows.

‘RISK to REWARD ratio’ for majority of individuals.
Again, as I said, you don’t necessarily have to perform all the above mentioned row variations. Choose the variation that you personally enjoy the most and at the same time feel most comfortable, strong and safe with.\n\n

string.name: latpulldown1
string.font:
Lat Pulldown



The Lat Pulldown exercise is a strength training exercise designed to develop the
'latissimus dorsi' muscle. It performs the functions of 'downward rotation' and 'depression' of the 'scapulae' combined with 'adduction' and 'extension' of the 'shoulder joint'. This is basically a VERTICAL PULLING exercise.

 This exercise is a 'prerequisite' for performing BODYWEIGHT PULL UPS. If you CAN’T perform a pull up yet, then lat pulldown is going to be the best exercise to strengthen your lats and basically your overall vertical pulling strength in order to get strong enough to perform pull ups.

font.div:
Muscles worked:- Similar to that of rowing exercises. The main DIFFERENCE is in the 'rhomboid and lat activation'. HORIZONTAL pulling exercises activate MORE of your RHOMBOIDS and less of your lats. VERTICAL pulling exercises activate MORE of your LATS and less of your rhomboids.


Please click on the following 'blue' links.
BENEFITS.\n\n
TUTORIAL.\n\n
Five \'Lat Pulldown\' VARIATIONS.\n\n

string.name: isolation_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Isolation exercises



Isolation exercises in weight training are exercises that involve only
ONE joint and a LIMITED number of muscle groups. This is in contrast with 'Compound exercises' that work TWO OR MORE joints and MANY MORE muscles.


Click here to know the MERITS and DEMERITS of 'isolation exercises'.


I usually DON’T RECOMMEND performing isolation exercises unless you really want to
STRENGTHEN your WEAK POINTS or you want to
MAINTAIN THE STRENGTH of SPECIFIC muscles while RECOVERING from an INJURY.

 If you don’t have any of the above mentioned issues, then performing isolation exercises would be a 'WASTE of TIME'.
You can gain MORE THAN SUFFICIENT 'muscle' and 'strength' from 'Compound exercises'.

 Isolation exercises for some muscle groups are COMPLETELY UNNECESSARY and will only 'WASTE YOUR TIME' in the gym. Those muscle groups are your
'back', 'core muscles' or 'abs', and 'forearms'.

 I don’t think there are any isolation exercises for the back, as your back is connected to so many different muscle groups, and so, just isolating a large muscle group like your back is PRACTICALLY IMPOSSIBLE.


The same applies to your 'core muscles'. Almost 'all compound exercises' activate your core to some extent for
'overall body stabilisation' while performing the exercise.


Your 'forearms' are HEAVILY ACTIVATED in all upper body compound exercises. So, spending extra time for isolating them is COMPLETELY UNNECESSARY.
Training SMARTLY is equally important.


There are tons and tons of different isolation exercises for the other smaller muscle groups. The isolation exercises for various other muscle groups, 'recommended in the upcoming sections' would be MORE THAN SUFFICIENT for their complete isolation.

string.name: biceps1
string.font:

Barbell Curls

font.div: Click here for the TUTORIAL.

KEEP YOUR TRAINING AS SIMPLE AS YOU CAN!! SIMPLICITY TRUMPS VARIETY!!\n\n

string.name: plateau
string.font:
Overcoming Strength Plateaus (Only for Intermediates and Advanced)



This section is only for INTERMEDIATE or ADVANCED lifters who have been lifting for 'AT LEAST 2 YEARS'. If you HAVEN’T, then it would be better to just SKIP THIS SECTION because as a beginner, no matter what exercise program you follow, you will definitely progress quickly in strength training.


But when time passes by and when you slowly get into intermediate levels of strength and fitness, you will start to experience a drastic reduction in your PROGRESSION SPEED in STRENGTH GAINS. You will start to realise that you have been stuck at a PARTICULAR WEIGHT or REPS for one or more exercises.


This is the time when you kind of get a ‘reality check’. Despite keeping everything in check and busting your a** in the gym every single time, you just CAN’T seem to get past the number which you are stuck at. Don’t worry. This happens to all of us at some point of time in fitness. Instead of getting demotivated and giving up, you need to incorporate some changes in your fitness routine in order to get past your PESKY STRENGTH PLATEAUS.



There are 2 types of strengths:- ABSOLUTE strength and RELATIVE strength.


• Absolute strength:-

 Absolute strength is the maximum amount of force exerted, regardless of muscle or body size. Greater amounts of absolute strength favour those with higher body weight and in general, larger individuals. Greater absolute strength will improve relative strength capabilities. For example, the maximum load that you can lift in all barbell and dumbbell based exercises is a measure of absolute strength.



• Relative strength:-

 Relative strength is the amount of strength to body size, or how strong you are for your size. This reflects a person's ability to control or move their body through space, a vital trait in athletics. All else being equal, smaller individuals have higher relative strength.



Relative Strength = 
(Absolute Strength) / (Bodyweight)



This is a term used to define the maximum capacity for you to lift your own bodyweight. In other words, it is completely relative to you. Relative strength is usually related to calisthenic/body weight based movements. For example, your performance in any bodyweight movement is a measure of your relative strength.


This means that an individual who has high absolute strength MAY or MAY NOT have high relative strength due to his heavy bodyweight (absolute strength to bodyweight ratio). And conversely, an individual who has low absolute strength MAY or MAY NOT have low relative strength.



This video explains why you might need to RECHECK what you are doing OUTSIDE the gym.

NOTE:- He is talking about 'ABSOLUTE strength plateau'. So, his advice MAY NOT WORK for breaking 'RELATIVE strength plateaus'.



NOTE:- When it comes to improving your 'ABSOLUTE strength', you MUST BE in a 'calorie SURPLUS' (200-300 Calories above TDEE). But you DON’T necessarily have to be in a calorie surplus to build 'RELATIVE strength'. Obviously you MUST be a POSITIVE NITROGEN BALANCE in both cases.


Instead, you need to be in a 'slight calorie DEFICIT' (200-300 Calories below TDEE) in order to build RELATIVE strength, because as your bodyweight drops, your absolute strength will definitely drop, but due to your lower bodyweight, any bodyweight exercise may get easier, thereby improving your relative strength. In both cases, staying too above or too below your TDEE won’t help you progress. So, make sure you stay close to your TDEE in both cases.



This video explains a quick programming tip on how to avoid plateaus (absolute strength plateau) in the future.


This video gives some tips on how to break through absolute strength plateaus.


Another important way of breaking through 'rep based plateaus' (both absolute and relative strength plateaus) is to actually focus specifically on that exercise for 2 to 3 months religiously.
This video gives some explanation to that.


‘GREASING THE GROOVE’ (GtG) is another popular way of overcoming rep based plateaus. Watch
this video to learn more about GtG.


The main problem with GtG is that it’s definitely NOT PRACTICAL to APPLY IT in our busy day to day life. As I have tried it myself for about a week, it does work in breaking the rep based plateau, but it’s extremely monotonous, boring and impractical.


You can SUCCESSFULLY APPLY this training routine if you have CONSTANT ACCESS to a 'pull up bar' or a 'gym' THROUGHOUT the day for about 4 weeks. Clearly, this ISN’T PRACTICAL at all.


A BETTER training routine that can help in increasing reps as well as be PRACTICALLY APPLICABLE is shown in
this video.



Another important way of increasing the reps of a particular exercise (above 10 reps) would be to
SIMPLY INCREASE THE INTENSITY (weight or resistance) of every rep in order to manage a
MAXIMUM OF 5 REPS PER SET. This is basically the adoption of the ‘basic principle’ of STRENGTH TRAINING (increased intensity and lower reps) for breaking through rep based plateaus. This applies to almost any exercise.


For example, if you can’t get past 10 reps in pull ups (relative strength), then simply increase the intensity by performing WEIGHTED PULL UPS (bodyweight + extra weight) for
2-5 RM for about
5-8 sets per training session. Make sure you take rest for at least
5 minutes between each set.


This training style can definitely make the normal bodyweight pull ups a lot easier after 2-3 months of consistent training and you’ll surely end up doing a lot more reps of bodyweight pull ups, provided you are EATING CLOSE TO YOUR TDEE and SLEEPING ENOUGH.



Sometimes, it can become increasingly difficult to keep increasing the volume and intensity by performing strict sets. In such situations, if you want to keep increasing the amount of volume using the same or even higher intensity,
CLUSTER SETS can come in handy. Watch
this video to understand what cluster training is.



Given below are some articles containing some more ways of breaking a strength plateau.


Article 1


Article 2


Article 3


Article 4

string.name: etiquettes_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Gym Etiquette



A gym is a PUBLIC place. So, practicing proper gym etiquette is CRUCIAL to maintain a healthy atmosphere in the gym and get your workouts done in the most efficient and safe manner.


Please go through
this article THOROUGHLY to get an overall idea of the DO’s and DON’Ts in the gym.


This video discusses the various steps to be taken by beginners in order to overcome gym fear and to be more confident in the gym.

string.name: common_mistakes
string.font:
Common Gym Mistakes to be avoided



DROPPING THE WEIGHTS

 This is very prevalent in almost all gyms and I just don’t understand what exactly do the gym ‘bros’ want to express through this act. I have literally seen advanced lifters do this mistake every now and then. This seriously pisses me off every time I step into the gym. This is one of the reasons why I love to train calisthenics (bodyweight training) outside the gym in order to avoid such stuff.

 Dropping weights especially dumbbells and barbell plates on the floor not only damages it, but also creates a lot of unnecessary noise. This can also lead to serious injuries if someone accidentally comes near these ‘bros’. This definitely distracts others in the gym too.


SOLUTION:- ALWAYS LOWER THE WEIGHTS SLOWLY TO THE GROUND WITHOUT MAKING ANY SOUND. YOU MUST ‘RESPECT’ THE WEIGHTS AND EQUIPMENTS THAT HELP YOU BUILD MUSCLE AND STRENGTH!


By doing so, you will not only prevent the problems associated with it, but you will also unintentionally perform ‘Deadlift eccentrics’ which can help in improving your ‘grip strength’ as well as ‘pulling strength’, which is why you are in the gym in the first place!


Also, as mentioned earlier, lowering the weights slowly to the ground is also a gesture of ‘respect’ towards them. I know that sounds funny, but you ‘MUST RESPECT and VALUE’ almost anything or anybody that help you get better and stronger!


Now I’m not saying to make absolutely ZERO SOUND while lowering the barbell during a Deadlift, as some ‘thudding’ sound is inevitable while performing them. In this case, just make sure you try your best to LIMIT THE SPEED of the Deadlift ‘descent’.


But as mentioned earlier, NEVER DROP the barbells during the descent. That can cause more problems than dropping a dumbbell would.



GIVING UNSOLICITED ADVICE TO STRANGERS

 Now, this act won’t be performed by beginners as you (if you are a beginner) yourself aren’t having a very good idea about fitness. But when you slowly reach to an intermediate level of fitness where you have experienced some good results in the past, you are bound to commit such actions as you might start thinking that you have a good grasp of what’s going on. But in reality, you are in the VERY EARLY STAGES of making developments.

 There are many chances that you may not know all the details and nuances about a certain topic. You also may not know the current situation or condition of the other person. So, advising some random strangers regarding a certain topic (form of exercise or anything related to fitness) can end up misleading them with incomplete information. This can lead to serious problems for them in the longer run.

 Even if your input is completely correct, this act is simply NOT welcomed by anyone. Anyone who is given unsolicited advice feels as if he/she has been verbally attacked.

 Sadly, even I have given unsolicited advices to some guys regarding proper form of execution. But when I started to visualise myself in their places, I realised how it actually feels when someone else does the same to you. You will literally feel like you have been attacked. From that moment onwards, I realised my mistake and completely stopped doing that and I just focused on my own business.

 And I SINCERELY APOLOGISE to those whom I have given such advices.

 You may think that this will HELP the other person, but in reality, it just makes you look like an ‘arrogant do****bag’! So, please DON’T commit the same mistake that I did!


SOLUTION:- The most important exercise to be performed in the gym is KEEPING YOUR F***ING MOUTH SHUT AND FOCUSING ON YOUR OWN GODDAMN BUSINESS! ADVICE SOMEBODY ONLY IF THEY SEEK YOURS! PERIOD! If you really feel like someone may get hurt by what they are doing (improper gym etiquette), then just inform this to the gym staff. They will take care of the rest.



LIFTING WITH EGO

 This is very common in the gym especially with beginners and intermediates. Even I used to do this earlier in the sense of pushing harder. As a beginner or an intermediate, when you watch a strong individual lifting heavier weights, your ‘ego’ gets fired up and you start questioning yourself:-


“Why the hell can’t I lift like him/her? Why the hell can’t I show off by lifting heavy?”


In reality, the simple logical answer to that is:-


“I am not strong enough to handle that weight. I am not strong enough at this point of time to perform 'Quality Reps' with 'Good Form' and 'Full Range of Motion' using those heavy weights. Lifting those heavy weights will only make me end up ‘screwing’ my form, thereby 'increasing' my chances of getting 'injured'. This will simply make me look like an ‘idiot’ in front of the entire gym, which is the last thing I want. Injuries will also become a big setback in my strength gains. Period!”


Now, the problem with your ego is that it does not think the logical way. You will NEVER come up with the above answer if you let your ego come in your way.


SOLUTION:- LEAVE YOUR F***ING ‘EGO’ OUTSIDE THE GYM AND FOCUS ONLY ON ‘YOUR’ WORKOUT! THINK ‘REALISTICALLY’ DURING WEIGHT SELECTION! PERIOD!



BLOCKING SOMEONE’S VIEW OF THE MIRROR

 The mirrors provided in the gym are NOT for checking our physique or showing off. They are provided to make sure anyone exercising in front of it performs the exercise with proper form and full range of motion (especially compound exercises like deadlifts, overhead press, barbell rows etc.). They are also provided to be able to look at your working muscles while performing the exercise (especially isolation exercises) in order to maintain good ‘MIND MUSCLE CONNECTION’
(Check this for more info on ‘mind muscle connection’).

 So, by standing in front of ‘anyone serious about lifting’ and blocking their view of the mirror will undoubtedly PISS THEM OFF!


SOLUTION:- JUST MAKE SURE NOBODY IS USING THE MIRROR BEFORE STANDING IN FRONT OF IT. IF SOMEBODY IS USING IT, KINDLY DON’T INTERFERE AND LOOK FOR SOME OTHER SPOT. PERIOD!



SHOWING OFF

 As I mentioned earlier, the mirrors are not provided for checking your toned abs and showing it off. I have seen many intermediate and advanced lifters moving and working out in the gym shirtless just to SHOW OFF THEIR F***ING ABS!

 They might be doing this with the intention of sending a message to others around that hard-work brings results. Now, that’s not a wrong message. But based on my experience, the TRUTH is that NOBODY GIVES A SH*T ABOUT YOUR ABS AND YOUR HARD-WORK!

 Showing off your abs to anyone only makes them ‘ENVIOUS’ (usually beginners and intermediates) or ‘JEALOUS’ (usually advanced) and eventually ending up PISSING THEM OFF!

 Gym is a VERY WRONG place to show off your physique. It’s a place to get your training done in order to meet your specific goals. It’s also a great way of distracting others in the gym. This is not only limited to the gym, but literally any public place where being shirtless and showing off only makes you look like a ‘NARCISSIST’!


SOLUTION:- DO TAKE PRIDE in your physique but DON’T SHOW OFF at the WRONG places. Choose the RIGHT PLACES to show off, the best example being the ‘beach’, where almost everyone is shirtless, or at ‘your home’ or some ‘bodybuilding competition’ or a ‘fashion show’ or a ‘photo-shoot’ or basically any place where you don’t find many people around. BUT WHEN IT COMES TO THE GYM, JUST GET YOUR GODDAMN TRAINING DONE AND LEAVE!! PERIOD!



USING MOBILE FOR THE UNNECESSARY STUFF


I have rarely noticed people in the gym using their mobiles to 'note down some important points as notes', to 'refer video tutorials for some exercises', to 'use stopwatches to measure their rest time period', 'time taken to complete a set' or 'recording their maximum hold time' for isometric exercises.


What I’ve often noticed in the gym is the use of mobiles for 'online chatting', 'surfing through Facebook and Instagram', 'taking selfies while flexing' and 'posting stories' in whatsapp, FB and IG using captions such as ‘#hard_work’ , ‘#gym_time’, ‘#never_give_up’, ‘#never_skip_leg_day’, ‘#consistency’, ‘#busting_my_a**_in_the_gym’ and so on.


My question to these people is:-


“Are you REALLY busting your a** in the gym??”


Now, this again is a sign of unnecessary show off. This not only wastes your time in the gym, but it also distracts others over there. You can surely 'take videos' by 'demonstrating the execution of a particular exercise', provided there are very few people around, or you can also 'surf through your favourite songs playlists' for short time periods. But using your mobiles for doing unnecessary stuff in the gym is only going to WASTE YOUR TIME.


SOLUTION:- USE YOUR MOBILES ONLY FOR CONSTRUCTIVE OR USEFUL PURPOSES, ESPECIALLY IN THE GYM! PERIOD!

string.name: less_common_mistakes1
string.font:
Less Common Gym Mistakes to be avoided



USING GYM GLOVES

 Gym gloves are popular among beginners as they consider it to be an 'essential gym gear'. And it’s not their fault. Any beginner will definitely fall into this TRAP due to 'extensive advertisement' of gym gloves in 'online shopping websites' and also by seeing some 'professionals wearing it' in some 'online articles and magazines'.

 Even I was tempted into buying them in my initial workout days. Just like most beginners, even I used to think that these gloves help in improving our grip strength. After using them for almost a year and a half, I started realising that these gloves actually do the 'OPPOSITE' of that. Yes, you read it right! These fancy looking gloves actually worsen your grip strength due to the smooth leather and fibre layers in it. These smooth layers make it very easy for the bars, barbells and dumbbells to SLIP from your hands, leading to 'poor performance' in an exercise.

 'GRIP STRENGTH' is NOT so important when it comes to PUSHING exercises. But your performance in PULLING exercises like 'Deadlifts', 'pull ups', 'hanging exercises', 'rows' etc. is HEAVILY DEPENDENT on your 'grip strength'.

 When I started using my
'BABY SOFT' bare hands for performing the pulling exercises, I initially struggled with 'BURNING SENSATION' all over my palm and fingers. They used to turn RED every time in the beginning. Just holding the bar for a few seconds turned into a challenge at first. During this process, I developed 'CALLUSES' in my palms and fingers. They look exactly like this:-

font.div: This might look a little nasty, but it’s actually NOT AT ALL PAINFUL when you GET USED TO IT. Calluses are \'hardened skin layers\' on your \'baby soft skin\' and their sole purpose is to PROTECT your soft skin from the \'HARSH FRICTIONAL STIMULUS\' experienced while \'pulling heavy stuff\'. This is a way of our body to ADAPT to the \'rough stimulus\' to our hands by building calluses, SIMILAR to the way our body builds muscle and strengthens our joints, tendons and ligaments to adapt to the heavy loads we lift.\n\n Honestly, once you get used to it, your \'grip strength\' will significantly IMPROVE, eventually leading to \'IMPROVED PULLING PERFORMANCE\'. The best way to improve grip strength would be to perform

hanging exercises from the pull up bar or simply \'hanging from the bar\'. It will be very UNCOMFORTABLE in the beginning and hanging even for a few seconds would be challenging, but after one or two weeks of practice, it will definitely turn into a ‘cakewalk’. As of now, I can easily perform a
two-arm hang from the bar for 120+ seconds and a

one-arm hang for about 30-45 seconds.\n\n But when it comes to exercises that involve lifting loads much heavier than your bodyweight, like Deadlifts, your toughened palms still won’t be enough to prevent the \'slipping\' of the barbell from your hands. In such cases I would definitely RECOMMEND using

‘chalk’ or ‘weightlifting straps’ to further improve your grip on the barbell. Just remember, unlike gym gloves, weightlifting straps or chalk won’t protect your skin against calluses, they will simply BOOST your grip.\n\n

As I was using gym gloves in the past, I did recommend some of my friends who were new to resistance training, to use them too. That was a MISLEADING ACT. So, I SINCERELY APOLOGISE to them for this.


SOLUTION:- JUST THROW AWAY YOUR FANCY GYM GLOVES AND TOUGHEN UP! USE CHALK OR WEIGHTLIFTING STRAPS INSTEAD! THE ONLY WAY TO SOLVE PROBLEMS IS TO ‘FACE’ THEM, INSTEAD OF ‘AVOIDING’ THEM. PERIOD!



WEARING SHORTS IN THE GYM

 Wearing shorts in the gym both by men and women can be distracting for the opposite sex especially while performing exercises involving INVERSION OF YOUR BODY UPSIDE DOWN. For example, while performing 'handstands' or 'hanging exercises' like ‘toes to the bar’, ‘inverted hang’, ‘inverted deadlifts’, ‘windshield wipers’, ‘front and back lever eccentrics’, ‘skin the cat’ etc.

 While performing such exercises, there are chances of 'unintentional exposure' of your 'undergarments' due to the slipping of your shorts towards your waist due to gravity. This can be embarrassing and distracting especially for the opposite sex.


SOLUTION:- SIMPLY WEAR FULL LENGTH SPORTS PANTS (MEN AND WOMEN) OR FULL LENGTH LEGGINGS (WOMEN) IN ORDER TO PREVENT SUCH EMBARASSING SCENARIOS.



BARBELL ETIQUETTES


Just refer the following image to get an idea of proper barbell etiquettes to be followed in the gym.
