string.name: cali_beg_intro1
string.font:
Introduction to Calisthenics



Calisthenics aka
bodyweight training is a style of resistance training that involves moving your body in space against gravity. Performing bodyweight exercises requires
significant strength, mobility, skill, balance and coordination.


Click on the following 'blue links'.

 Calisthenics explained.


Why you SHOULD CONSIDER Calisthenics! (especially BEGINNERS)

font.div: Gymnastics is actually a sport which involves performing 'INSANE bodyweight movements and skills' at the 'Olympic level' that require a lot more of the above stated qualities. Almost all exercises and movements in calisthenics and gymnastics are COMPOUND movements.

Click here to know the 'PROS' and 'CONS' of Calisthenics.


Gymnastics is a hell lot more complicated than Calisthenics. There are literally hundreds of exercises in both Gymnastics and Calisthenics. So, covering all of them is beyond the scope of this app. But we will surely be covering some of the most common moves in both Calisthenics and Gymnastics.


Before trying to attempt any advanced skill in either calisthenics or gymnastics, you need to have a
VERY STRONG FOUNDATIONAL STRENGTH, i.e. you need to

MASTER THE BASICS FIRST AT ANY COST before even thinking of attempting the advanced moves.


I completely understand how attractive the advanced moves look, which eventually make you end up craving to achieve them. Don’t just jump into performing the progressions of the advanced moves because no matter how long you practice the progressions, you will only end up GETTING STUCK IN A PLATEAU and GETTING AVOIDABLE INJURIES, IF YOU SKIP THE BASICS. I have done this mistake. So, PLEASE DON’T be a ‘JERK’ LIKE ME!

This video describes how to start Calisthenics if you are a \'COMPLETE BEGINNER\'. (Watch it in private with headphones on!)\n\n
If you can’t even perform a standard

push up, a dip, a pull up or any of the basic exercises mentioned in the above video, then it would be better to KEEP PRACTISING THE EASIER PROGRESSIONS of the above mentioned basic exercises. Once you are able to perform the basic exercises (push up, dip, pull up), then you can start practising them consistently to eventually master them.\n\n

string.name: pushup1
string.font:
Push Up (Horizontal Push)



A Push Up or
Press Up is a common Calisthenics conditioning exercise performed in a
prone position by raising and lowering the body with the straightening and bending of the arms while keeping the back straight and supporting the body on the hands and toes.

 Push Up is actually the bodyweight equivalent of a 'Flat Bench Press'. So, if you can’t get access to a gym, and you really want to get a 'bigger chest', then 'Push Ups' can be the best way to get the job done. The best part of Push Ups is that it can be LITERALLY DONE ANYWHERE!! All you need is a flat surface, that’s it!

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Pectoralis major and minor (chest)
 • Triceps brachii
 • Anterior deltoids (front shoulders)
 • Serratus anterior
 • Coracobrachialis
 • Abdominal muscles (core)
 • Glutes
 • Quadriceps
Click here for the BENEFITS of \'Push Ups\'.\n\n
IMPORTANT NOTE:- Almost

90% of all individuals who are into fitness perform the \'Push Up\' INCORRECTLY. The MOST COMMON mistake being \'lack of Full Range of Motion\' (half reps), i.e. not going completely down and not coming completely back up.\n\n The main reason for this is, as you might have guessed it:-

EGO! The same problem is carried over to other basic exercises like ‘dips’ and ‘Pull Ups’.

 I have literally seen ‘jacked gym bros’ performing 'half reps' for Push Ups, dips and Pull Ups with the pursuit of doing as many reps as they can to IMPRESS others or completing the ‘100 Push Ups in a row’ challenge. The same goes for dips and Pull Ups.

 STOP CHEATING YOURSELF! You MUST RESPECT the exercise in order to REALLY REAP IT’S BENEFITS! STOP COUNTING YOUR REPS and instead MAKE YOUR REPS COUNT! PERIOD! Please carefully watch the following tutorial.

Click here for the TUTORIAL.
 (Notice the 'PPT' or 'Posterior Pelvic Tilt' that needs to be incorporated when performing a Push Up).

NOTE:- You need to have a \'LOW body fat percentage\' to get good at Push Ups. As it’s a bodyweight exercise, the lighter you are, the easier it will get. So, make sure you stay in a ‘slight calorie DEFICIT’ while working your way to a push up, and also to get better at it. The same applies for dips, Pull Ups, or literally any bodyweight exercise, as ‘relative strength’ comes into action while performing them.\n\n
\'Knee Push Up\' is an easier progression of a standard Push Up. The only difference is that your lower body is supported on your \'knees\', instead of \'toes\'. \'Knee Push Ups\' involve
41% of your bodyweight, as compared to \'Standard Push Ups\' that involve
64% of your bodyweight.

Click on the following 'blue links'.

 Serious Push Up Mistake (NEVER do it, if you DON’T want SHOULDER IMPINGEMENT)
Harder Push Up Variations\n\n
NOTE:- Make sure you practice Push Ups in order to get strong enough to be able to do
ATLEAST 50 PUSH UPS (standard push ups) IN A ROW, in order to progress to the \'Advanced Calisthenics Pushing skills\' like

Handstand Push Ups, Impossible Dip, Elbow Lever, 90° Handstand Push Up, Human Flag, Planche, Maltese etc. 

I know that’s being ‘RUDE’. Even I can perform only a maximum of 30 push ups (clean push ups, not cr*ppy ones) in a row. But trust me; based on my experience of directly jumping to the advanced moves, I only ended up plateauing with the progressions. Having a strong foundation will surely benefit us in the longer run and keep us away from injuries. 

We just need to accept the HARSH REALITY and just focus on CONSTANT IMPROVEMENT. Eventually after consistent hard-work, we will definitely be able to hit that mark.

 A good way to get stronger at Push Ups (apart from doing Push Up variations) would be to simply practice
WEIGHTED PUSH UPS. Choose a weight that is heavy enough to manage only
3-5 reps (ideal rep range for strength training). Keep practicing it and keep increasing the weight GRADUALLY to work your way up to 50 bodyweight push ups in row.\n\n

string.name: dips1
string.font:
Dips (Vertical Push - Extension)



The Standard 'Dip' is an upper body VERTICAL PUSHING exercise where your elbows move behind our body while performing it.


The 'dip' is performed by using your hands to support your FULL body weight, lowering yourself in a controlled motion, and returning to the starting position to complete one repetition. Dips can be performed on parallel bars, straight bars, pull up bars (if you can do a muscle up) and on gymnastics rings.


Dips are tougher compared to 'push ups' as 'dips' involve lifting your
Entire bodyweight (100%), as compared to push ups that only involve around
64% of your bodyweight.

font.div: • If you are a \'COMPLETE BEGINNER\', then you need to work your way up to a \'bodyweight dip\' by focusing on getting stronger at \'push ups\' first.
10 push ups in a row would be enough to be able to do a dip.\n\n • You can also practise \'Bench Dips\' (feet assisted). Similarly,

10 Bench Dips in a row would be enough to be able to do a dip.

 • You can practise
‘Band Assisted Dips’ using ‘thicker bands’ initially, and then slowly progressing towards ‘thinner’ ones and then finally, the 'Unassisted'.

• Practising 'Dip Eccentrics' (or 'negatives') can also help in increasing 'time under tension' for getter 'better strength adaptations'. With this, you will definitely be able to perform 3-5 dips in a row.

Muscles worked:-

 • Pectoralis major and minor
 • Triceps brachii (lateral, medial and long head)
 • Deltoids (anterior, lateral and posterior)
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Forearm muscles
 • Trapezius
 • Serratus anterior


 Click on the following 'blue links'.
BENEFITS\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n
MISTAKES\n\n
20 Dip Variations (\'Beginner\' to \'Advanced\')\n\n The \'toughest\' Dip Variation in the above tutorial is the

‘Impossible Dip’. It’s definitely an ‘Advanced Strength skill’ and so, we will be covering that later in this app. Also, PLEASE DON’T TRY the \'RING dip exercises\' as mentioned in the above video straight away!! We will discuss in a bit more detail about \'Ring exercises\' later in this app.\n\n
NOTE:- You need to be able to perform

ATLEAST 30 DIPS (Standard or Normal Dips) IN A ROW in order to progress to the 'Advanced Pushing skills'.


 • Just keep practising the various other Dip Variations to work your way to 10-15 dips in a row.

 • Once you achieve that, you can start practising
‘WEIGHTED DIPS’ by choosing a weight heavy enough to manage
3-5 reps. Keep increasing the weight GRADUALLY to work your way up to 30 dips in a row.\n

string.name: pullups1
string.font:
Pull Ups (Vertical Pull)



A Pull Up is an upper-body VERTICAL PULLING exercise. The 'pull up' is a closed-chain movement where the body is suspended by the hands and is pulled up. As this happens, the elbows undergo 'FLEXION' and the shoulders 'ADDUCT' and extend to bring the elbows to the torso. Pull ups can be performed using a PRONATED grip, NEUTRAL grip and a SUPINATED grip.

font.div: \nGenerally, a \'Pull Up\' is considered to be performed using a ‘PRONATED grip’.\n

The pull up performed using a 'SUPINATED grip' is also termed as a ‘Chin Up’.

 The 'Pull up' is one of the 'toughest basic exercises' that needs to be 'mastered' in order to progress to the 'Advanced Pulling skills' like the

\'Muscle Up\', \'Back Lever\', \'Front Lever\', \'Human Flag\', \'OAC\' (One Arm Chin up) and \'OAP\' (One Arm Pull up).\n\n
If you are a \'COMPLETE BEGINNER\' and you can’t perform a pull up yet, then the best exercise to build your way up to a pull up would be

‘Lat Pulldowns’. 'Lat pulldowns' are actually 'pull ups' performed with a 'weight' LOWER than your 'bodyweight'.


 • So, in order to get stronger, choose a weight with which you can manage up to only 3-5 reps. Keep practising and making improvements in the weight consistently, and by doing so, you will surely be able to perform a
‘Band Assisted bodyweight pull up’ using ‘resistance bands’ in some months. Click on the following \'blue link\' to learn how to perform one.\n
Band Assisted pull ups\n\n • Use a \'thick band\' in the \'beginning\' for more assistance. Keep practising
‘Pull Up Eccentrics’ with a \'thick band\' (3-5 reps) and work your way up to ‘thinner bands’. Click on the following \'blue\' link to learn how to perform one.\n

Pull Up Eccentrics


• Keep practising the 'eccentrics' with the 'thinner' bands using the 'same rep range' (3-5 reps) and slowly, you will definitely get strong enough to perform your first ‘bodyweight pull up’.

 • Once you achieve that, practise the 'eccentrics WITHOUT bands' for the same rep range. In this way you will get strong enough to perform 2-3 pull ups.



If you don’t have access to a 'Lat Pulldown Machine' or a 'pull up bar', then you can practise

‘Australian pull ups’ or ‘bodyweight rows’ or ‘inverted rows’ (feet assisted) on 'dip bars' or a 'barbell supported on a rack'. Keep increasing the difficulty of the rows by keeping your body 'more parallel' to the horizontal (or ground).


 Please keep in mind that 'Rows' are ‘HORIZONTAL pulling’ movements, but 'Pull Ups' are ‘VERTICAL pulling’ in nature. So, practising 'horizontal pulling movements' won’t directly translate into improved 'vertical pulling strength'. So, my recommendation would be to stick to the ‘easier VERTICAL pulling’ exercises as mentioned above to work your way to a 'bodyweight pull up'.

Muscles worked:-

 • Latissimus dorsi (lats)
 • Biceps brachii
 • Brachioradialis
 • Brachialis
 • Posterior deltoid (rear shoulders)
 • Trapezius (middle and lower)
 • Infraspinatus
 • Teres major and minor
 • Rectus abdominis or core (stabilisation)


 Click on the following 'blue links'.
BENEFITS\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n
MISTAKES\n\n
Pull Up Variations (Beginner to Advanced)\n\n
NOTE:- You need to be able to perform

ATLEAST 20 PULL UPS IN A ROW in order to progress to the 'Advanced Pulling skills'.


 • Just keep practising 'bodyweight pull ups' of 'different variations' till you make your way to '10 pull ups in a row'.

 • Once you achieve this, you can start doing
‘WEIGHTED PULL UPS’ to increase your way to \'20 reps in a row\'.\n

string.name: lyingcore1
string.font:
Lying Core exercises



Core exercises include movements that activate a 'group of muscles' called the 'core'. These muscles work as a group to help 'stabilize and control' the spine. These muscles are located on the midsection of the trunk and are mostly deep muscles. Activation of these muscles is possible by recruiting the right fibres in the movement.


The main core muscles include the
transverse abdominis, obliques and erector spinae, but there are many other muscles that can be considered as core.


'Core exercises' train these muscles to work together properly to maintain proper balance, agility, posture and movement to help the body move efficiently as well as preventing injury.


As you might have learnt by now, almost 'ALL COMPOUND EXERCISES activate your CORE muscles' for 'overall STABILIZATION' while performing them. All exercises and skills in Calisthenics and Gymnastics HEAVILY activate your core and hip flexors. Having a weak core and weak hip flexors can lead to 'POOR performance' in 'Intermediate' and 'Advanced bodyweight exercises'. Therefore, strengthening of these muscles need to be your PRIORITY if you want to PROGRESS in Calisthenics.


A good starting point to strengthen them would be to incorporate
‘lying core exercises’ in your training routine. These exercises are similar to
‘pilates exercises’. You would require a ‘YOGA MAT’ for performing these exercises, as performing them on a 'hard flat surface' can put a lot of stress on your ‘posterior pelvic bones’, leading to prolonged pain for a couple of days. So, PLEASE BUY A YOGA MAT for practising these exercises.


This video gives a list 10 basic, effective and sufficient ‘lying core exercises’ for developing decent core, hip flexor strength and increased endurance.



NOTE:- The TITLE of the above video and the MOTIVE for doing these exercises AS PREACHED by the 'exercise demonstrator' in the video is
COMPLETELY MISLEADING! You CAN’T burn 'stubborn belly fat' by doing tons and tons of HIIT or cardio or any amount of reps, sets or intensity of ab exercises, if you DON’T maintain a ‘DAILY NET CALORIE DEFICIT’! These exercises are only meant to STRENGTHEN your 'CORE muscles', 'hip flexors' and also to IMPROVE your 'muscular endurance'. PERIOD!

 Also these are ‘LYING’ core exercises, NOT ‘LAYING’ core exercises. You are performing these core exercises by ‘lying’ on a flat surface; you aren’t ‘laying’ anything on the flat surface while doing them xD.

 Also, ALWAYS remember to keep your
‘LEGS COMPLETELY LOCKED AND STRAIGHT’ while performing any ab exercise, to maintain OPTIMUM TENSION in your 'core and hip flexors'. 'POINT YOUR TOES COMPLETELY' to maintain the tension 'throughout your legs'. PLEASE KEEP THIS IN MIND as this is a very common cue everyone neglects while performing them.

font.div:
I know it’s very difficult and it ‘SUCKS’, but how the hell can you expect to get stronger if you can’t push yourself beyond your comfort zone?!!\n\n
Another great ‘lying’ exercise to significantly strengthen your ‘obliques’ is the
‘Lying Windshield Wipers’. Watch the following tutorial.\n\n

‘Lying’ (not ‘Laying’) Windshield Wipers


Now, these exercises might look simple, but they are INTENSE! You will definitely feel a 'strong burning sensation' in your 'core and hip flexors' while doing them and it’s COMPLETELY NORMAL. These exercises will 'REALLY SUCK' at first. But as you keep practising them consistently for some months, they will eventually get easier and you will be able to build a really strong foundational core and hip flexor strength to advance to the harder core exercises in calisthenics.

string.name: air_squats1
string.font:
Air Squats (Bodyweight Squats)



Air Squat is actually a 'barbell squat' where the weight of the barbell is equal to that of AIR AROUND YOU xD. In other words it’s just a normal bodyweight squat done without external weights.

font.div:
Muscles worked:- Same as that of barbell squats.

 Click on the following 'blue links'.
BENEFITS\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

NOTE:- Honestly, there aren’t too many intense leg exercises in bodyweight training. That is one 'downside' of Calisthenics. I would recommend you to practice bodyweight leg exercises only if you DON’T have access to a gym. But if you do, then it would be better to prioritise the basic weighted leg exercises performed in the gym (as discussed earlier), in order to make the exercises intense enough for better strength and muscle gains.


You can practise bodyweight leg exercises in order to build muscular endurance, but not significant amount of strength or muscle.

string.name: walking_lunges1
string.font:
Walking Lunges



Walking Lunges are 'bodyweight lunges' performed without any external weights, as simple as that.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of dumbbell or barbell lunges.
BENEFITS:- Same as that of weighted lunges.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: archer_squats1
string.font:
Archer Squats (Cossack Squats)



This is also called as a
‘side-to-side squat’ or ‘Cossack squat’. This is an 'asymmetrical squat' that involves squatting on one leg while keeping the other leg straight. This squat is an easier variation of the
‘pistol squat’ or ‘single legged squat’. So, this exercise can be a great way to work your way up to a 'pistol squat'.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of normal squats.
BENEFITS:- Being asymmetrical in nature, this exercise improves your balance, flexibility, strength and control. Practising this can help you work your way up to a \'pistol squat\'.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: single_leg_box_squats1
string.font:
Single Leg Box Squat



This is nothing but a box or a chair or a bench assisted ‘single leg squat’ or pistol squat which involves going down on one leg until you reach a point from where you can’t get back up.

 At the lowest point, you sit on a horizontal surface like a box, chair, bench etc. and then use some upward reaction force from the horizontal surface to get back up. This is one of the best conditioning exercises to work your way up to a 'pistol squat'.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of normal squats or Archer squats.
BENEFITS:- This exercise is an excellent way to condition yourself for achieving a \'pistol squat\' (unassisted single leg squat).\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: single_leg_calf_raise1
string.font:
Single Leg Bodyweight Calf Raises



This exercise is similar to 'barbell calf raises' on both legs; the only difference is that only one leg is used in this exercise to increase the intensity on the calf muscles on the leg being raised.

 This exercise can be made more difficult by avoiding any kind of assistance with our hands (by holding it to something) to activate more stabilising muscles to balance our body while performing this.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Calves and some more stabilising muscles in the legs to maintain balance while performing the unassisted version.
BENEFITS:- You can work your calves literally anywhere with this exercise.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: drinking_bird1
string.font:
Drinking Bird



This exercise as its name suggests, involves bending our neck forward and simultaneously extending our one leg backwards while standing on the other leg. We need to maintain a straight back and keep our core engaged while performing this. Also, the leg being extended backwards should also remain straight.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Hamstrings
 • Glutes
 • Abs
 • Lower back
BENEFITS:- This exercise helps in strengthening our glutes and hamstrings and also improves our balance by activating the stabiliser muscles.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: single_leg_glute_bridge1
string.font:
Single Leg Glute Bridge



This exercise is similar to a Barbell Glute Bridge. The only difference is that you perform this on a single leg using only your bodyweight.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Similar to that of Barbell Glute Bridge.

BENEFITS:- Similar to barbell glute bridge. This exercise being a unilateral one, also involves stabiliser muscles to aid in maintaining balance. Also, this exercise can be literally done anywhere, even on our bed!\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.font:

string.name: cali_inter_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Intermediate Calisthenics



Once you have mastered all the beginner level Calisthenics exercises, it’s time to move on to some HARDER exercises that will help you to 'CONDITION' yourself in a much better way to get strong enough to start training the 'progressions' of the 'Advanced skills'. You definitely need to master these 'intermediate level exercises' in order to COMFORTABLY and SAFELY train for the 'Advanced skills'.

string.name: hanging_core1
string.font:
Hanging Core Exercises



Once you have mastered the ‘Lying Core exercises’, it’s time for you to move on to the ‘HARDER’ and ‘MORE ENJOYABLE’ version of Core exercises, which are none other than the ‘Hanging Core exercises’.


As the name suggests, these exercises are performed while ‘Hanging’ from a ‘Pull Up bar’ or from ‘Gymnastic Rings’, which HEAVILY activate our forearms, biceps and lats (latissimus dorsi), eventually making them HARDER. ‘GRIP STRENGTH’ also plays a VITAL role in performing these exercises.


The ‘PREREQUISITE’ for being able to perform these exercises would be to perform a
‘two-arm hang’ for at least 60 Seconds. If you can’t do that, then I’m sorry, you really won’t be able to effectively perform these exercises. So, PLEASE DON’T JUMP to these, GET YOUR BASICS RIGHT FIRST!

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Rectus abdominis
 • Transverse abdominis
 • Obliques
 • Hip Flexors
 • Brachioradialis
 • Biceps brachii
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Quadriceps
 • Calves (If toes are pointed)
 • Glutes (in some cases)
 • Lower back (in some cases)

This link explains the BENEFITS of the most basic Hanging Core exercise, ‘Hanging knee raises’. If a basic Hanging Core exercise can be so beneficial, then just think about the BENEFITS of the HARDER versions of these exercises.\n\n
25 Best Hanging Core Exercises\n\n
Worst ab training Mistakes to Avoid\n\n

NOTE:- Please make sure to keep your legs TIGHTLY LOCKED and COMPLETELY STRAIGHT for ‘optimal activation’ of your ‘Core’ and ‘Hip Flexors’.



Now, the Exercise Demonstrator in the above videos

(DANIEL VADNAL, Director of FitnessFAQs) makes these exercises look very SIMPLE as he is already at an ‘Advanced level’ in ‘Calisthenics’. He can perform most of the ‘Advanced skills’ like the ‘Back Lever’, ‘Front Lever’, ‘Human Flag’, ‘Handstand Push Ups’, ‘90° Push Ups’, ‘OAP’, ‘OAC’, ‘Straddle Planche’ etc.


So, performing the above exercises is just ‘a walk in the park’ for him. But, when you actually start practising these exercises, you will instantly realise how F***ING WEAK you really are!! You will feel a ‘STRONG BURNING sensation’ in your ‘Hip Flexors’, ‘Core’ and your Palms’ while performing even the ‘simplest’ ones among them.


You will only be able to perform around 5 of them initially. But don’t worry. When you keep practising them consistently for about 6 months, you will definitely be able to perform all of them. During this process, you will experience a ‘huge BOOST’ in your ‘overall body strength’ and ‘self-esteem’ as well.

 • Once you achieve this, you will be strong enough to perform a

‘10 Second L-sit’, ‘5 Second One-Arm L-sit hang’, ‘5 Second Advanced Tuck Back Lever’, ‘5 Second Advanced Tuck Front Lever’, ‘10 Second Tuck Planche’, ‘skin the cat’, ‘Front Lever and Back Lever negatives or Eccentrics’, ‘Dragon Flag Isometrics and Eccentrics’ etc.\n\n • The
‘L-lever to Inverted Hang’ is also termed as the

‘Inverted Deadlift’ as it is similar to a \'Barbell Deadlift\' performed with the weight being lifted equal to our ‘bodyweight’ and performed on a ‘Pull Up bar’ in an ‘Inverted position’. This exercise has a good ‘carryover’ to the ‘Dragon Flag’ as it helps to strengthen your ‘Core’ and ‘lower back’, which is necessary to perform it (Dragon Flag).\n\n • The
‘Full Hanging leg raise’ or ‘Toes to the bar’ is great exercise to train for the
‘V-sit’.\n\n • The ‘toughest’ among them in my opinion is the
‘Full Windshield Wiper’ which works your ‘obliques’ like no other exercise. Mastering this exercise will ‘CONDITION’ your ‘obliques’ for the

‘Human Flag’, which is an impressive Advanced skill.


 So, undoubtedly, these exercises have a GREAT CARRYOVER to most of the 'Advanced Pulling skills' that are ‘Core dominant’.

string.name: lsit1
string.font:
L-sit



The L-sit is an acrobatic body position and an Isometric exercise in which the entire body weight rests on the hands, with the torso held in a slightly forward-leaning orientation, with legs held horizontally so that each leg forms a nominal ‘right-angle’ with the torso.


You obviously would require some decent ‘Hip Flexor’ and ‘Core’ strength in order to achieve this, which can be acquired through 'Hanging Core exercises'. You also need to have some 'basic Pushing strength' to hold your entire bodyweight on two palms.


So, PLEASE make sure you are able to perform
AT LEAST 10 ‘Hanging leg raises’ and 5 ‘Standard Dips’ to start training for the L-sit. This move can be performed on almost any flat surface (even on your ‘BED’!), on ‘Parallettes’, on Dip bars, Pull Up bars (if you can perform a ‘Muscle Up’) and on ‘Gymnastic Rings’. Performing an L-sit on the ‘Rings’ is a hell lot more difficult due to the ‘INSANE INSTABILITY’ of the ‘Rings’, which requires an additional PREREQUISITE of mastering the L-sit (on anything else) and also mastering the ‘Ring Support Hold’.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Pectoralis major and minor
 • Triceps (all heads)
 • Posterior deltoids
 • Rectus abdominis
 • Obliques
 • Serratus anterior
 • Hip Flexors
 • Quadriceps
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Trapezius
 • Forearm muscles
 • Calves (if toes are pointed)


 Now, that is a hell lot of muscles worked ‘in tandem’. This is the reason why I love this exercise. You can work all the above muscles ‘SIMULTANEOUSLY’ by performing this exercise on literally 'any flat surface'

(table, chair, bench, floor, seat, box, even on your ‘BED’!). So, if you are travelling or can’t get access to a Gym, then simply pick a flat surface and perform an L-sit on it!! Heck, even if you are too lazy to get off from your bed and still want a great body, perform an L-sit on it xD!! (Provided you have mastered the ‘floor L-sit’ as it’s more difficult on the ‘soft bed’ due to the ‘reduced distance’ between your ‘legs and the bed’ as your arms ‘depress into it’.)

 This exercise is also a very important PREREQUISITE that needs to be mastered to start training for the ‘V-sit’ and the ‘Manna’.
BENEFITS\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n
NOTE:- You need to master the \'floor L-sit\' by being able to hold it for
AT LEAST 30 Seconds to start training for the V-sit.\n\n

string.name: dragon_flag1
string.font:
Dragon Flag (Body Lever)



The Dragon Flag or
Body Lever is an Advanced Core exercise that can help build 'excellent overall Core strength'. It is credited to ‘martial arts master’ BRUCE LEE and is among the most advanced ones he used in his physical training.


This exercise is an ‘advanced version’ of the ‘Lying Leg Raises’. The only difference is that you need to grab your hands ‘FIRMLY’ to a ‘STURDY’ object just ‘behind your head’ for support (a bench or a vertical pole or a lower horizontal bar), and raise your ‘entire body from mid back to the toes’, keeping only your upper back grounded.


Your entire body from ‘mid back to your toes’ must be STRAIGHT and in COMPLETE TENSION while performing this move. So, you obviously need to master the ‘Lying Leg Raises’ in order to perform this. Barbell Deadlifts as well as ‘Inverted Deadlifts’ can also greatly help in strengthening your ‘lower back’ and ‘lats’ in order to perform this move.


This is because ‘strong lower back’ and ‘lats’ can help lift your ‘entire torso’ above the ground (instead of just your legs in leg raises) to turn the ‘lying leg raise’ into a Dragon Flag.


Another great exercise to strengthen your lats is obviously, ’Pull Ups’. Pull Ups not only strengthen your lats, but they also help in strengthening your biceps, forearms and shoulders for holding firmly to a support.


The closer your ‘legs’ are to the ‘ground’, the ‘harder’ this move becomes. When your body is almost ‘horizontal’ to the ‘ground’ and in the air, it almost turns into a ‘Shoulder Flag’, which is a completely horizontal’ Dragon Flag performed on a ‘vertical bar’. We will talk more about it later.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Rectus abdominis
 • External obliques
 • Serratus anterior
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Lower back muscles
 • Hip Flexors
 • Quadriceps
 • Glutes
 • Calves
 • Deltoids
 • Forearms muscles
 • Biceps
 • Pectorals (to some extent)


 Clearly, Dragon Flag is almost an ‘entire body exercise’ and you definitely need ‘overall body strength’ in order to perform this. This is another reason why ‘Barbell Deadlifts’ and ‘Inverted Deadlifts’ help in preparing you for the ‘Dragon Flag’ (as they are ‘Full body exercises’ too).

BENEFITS:-

 Dragon Flags help you build a very strong anterior as well as posterior chain which is essential for being able to perform Advanced Core dominant skills like the ‘Shoulder Flag’, ‘Human Flag’, ‘Back Lever’ and the ‘Front Lever’. Being able to perform this exercise definitely BOOSTS your ‘confidence’ for trying HARDER Core exercises in the future. This exercise can also help you get a ‘BULLET-PROOF’ Core :)

TUTORIAL

 The ‘hollow body position’ is achieved my maintaining a PPT (Posterior Pelvic Tilt) to prevent ‘arching of the lower back’ (Anterior Pelvic Tilt) and also to optimally activate your Core muscles to perform this exercise.

string.name: muscle_up1
string.font:
Muscle Up



The Muscle Up is an intermediate level strength skill, within the domain of Calisthenics. It is a combination of a radial Pull Up, followed by a Dip. This exercise consists of 3 phases:-
the 'Pull Up' phase, the 'Transition' phase and the 'Dip' phase.


So, the PREREQUISITES to start training for the Muscle Up are
AT LEAST 12 Pull Ups in a row, and AT LEAST 5 straight Bar Dips in a row.


Muscle Up is a great exercise to improve our 'explosive Pulling power', which in turn helps improve our lat strength for successfully holding the ‘Front Lever’ and ‘Back Lever’.


Muscle Ups can be performed on Pull Up Bars and on Gymnastic Rings. The toughest phase of a Muscle Up is the ‘transition phase’. Clearing the transition phase and getting our chest over the Bar is almost considered as a successful Muscle Up as the ‘Dip phase’ is a lot easier.


While performing a Bar Muscle Up, we need to bring our chest towards the Bar during the transition phase, as the Bar is rigid. But in the case of ring Muscle Ups, we can bring the Rings (that are not fixed in space) towards our chest during the transition phase. Due to this, ‘Ring Muscle Ups’ are generally considered easier than ‘Bar Muscle Ups’.

font.div: Also, Ring Muscle Ups are performed using a ‘False grip’ as it’s very difficult to perform them using a ‘Neutral grip’ as the rings aren’t fixed like the Bars. But you can use a ‘False grip’ while performing a Bar Muscle Up.

Muscle Ups can also be performed using some momentum by ‘kipping’. The Muscle Up performed WITHOUT any 'kipping' is termed as a ‘Strict Muscle Up’. 'Kipping Muscle Ups' can be used an easier progression of the 'strict one' in the initial stages. But after consistent practise, you will get strong enough to perform the ‘strict version’ as it’s the one that’s generally considered as a ‘Perfect Muscle Up’.


Once you master the Strict Muscle Up, you can start practising the ‘Slow Muscle Up’, (the usual ‘strict ones’ being quick and ‘explosive’ in nature), which is even tougher as it’s a 'PURELY STRENGTH-BASED' move. You don’t have to master the slow version though, as the usual ‘explosive’ one is considered as the 'Standard version' of a Muscle Up.
Muscles worked:- Same as that of Pull Ups and straight Bar Dips.\n\n
BENEFITS\n\n
Bar Muscle Up TUTORIAL\n\n

Bar Muscle Up TIPS


We will discuss about the ‘Ring Muscle Ups’ in the next section because you need to master some basic exercises on ‘rings’ in order to perform ‘Ring Muscle Ups’. You just CAN’T directly perform a ‘Ring Muscle Up’ despite having decent Pulling and Pushing strength, without mastering the 'basic exercises' on rings, as rings are GODDAMN UNSTABLE!!

string.name: injuries_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Injury Management



We all go through some sort of injury at some point in our lives. Injuries are very common among people who are into fitness like sports, athletics, resistance training (especially powerlifting and strength training) etc. If you are someone who doesn’t perform any kind of physical activity, then you most probably won’t experience injuries in the short term, but in the long term, you will. So, this section will deal with the various techniques and rehab exercises that can help you prevent or recover from an injury, because guess what, INJURIES SUCK!!


This link gives the list of common injuries in fitness that can be encountered by anyone.



NOTE:- YOU MUST ALWAYS MAINTAIN HIGH QUALITY NUTRITION WHILE RECOVERING FROM ANY INJURY TO ENSURE OPTIMAL AND FAST RECOVERY!! Eating ‘cr*p’ will not help you recover optimally despite performing the correct rehab exercises! Also, NEVER WORKOUT DURING RECOVERY, if you DON’T want to turn your TEMPORARY INJURY into a PERMANENT ONE!!

string.name: muscle_strain1
string.font:
Muscle Pull or Strain



A muscle strain, or
pulled muscle, occurs when your muscle is overstretched or torn. This usually occurs as a result of fatigue, overuse, or improper use of a muscle. Strains can happen in any muscle, but they're most common in your lower back, neck, shoulder, calves, and hamstrings, which is the muscle behind your thigh.

font.div:
This kind of injury is generally experienced in ‘hamstrings’ and ‘calves’ by athletes being involved in intense physical activities like ‘sprinting’, ‘jumping’, ‘powerlifting’ etc.


The following links provide the best information regarding the types of muscle strains, their overview, causes, symptoms and treatments.
Link 1\n\n

Link 2



Click on the following 'blue links' for the Rehab exercises for various muscle strain types.
Hip Flexor strain Rehab exercises\n\n
Lower back pain Rehab exercises\n\n
Hamstring strain Rehab exercises\n\n
Neck pain Rehab exercises\n\n
Groin strain (Adductor strain) Rehab exercises\n\n
Calf strain Rehab exercises\n\n
Chest pain Rehab exercises\n\n

string.name: ankle_sprain1
string.font:
Ankle Sprain



An ankle sprain or
‘lateral ankle sprain’ is an injury that occurs when the ankle rolls, twists or turns in an awkward way. This can stretch or tear the tough bands of tissue (ligaments) that help hold the ankle bones together.

 A sprained ankle causes swelling, pain and limited range of motion. Many people simply treat a sprained ankle at home with rest, ice and pain relievers. Severe sprains may need medical evaluation.

font.div: This condition is common among athletes that have sprinting or jumping as an important part of their sport. It’s also common among those wearing ‘high heels’ xD. PLEASE AVOID HIGH HEELS IF YOU CAN’T USE THEM!!
The following links provide the best information regarding the overview, causes, symptoms and treatments of ankle sprain.
Link 1\n\n
Link 2\n\n
Link 3\n\n
Ankle sprain Rehab exercises\n\n

string.name: shoulder_injuries_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Shoulder Injuries



This is the most common and PAINFUL type of injury not only in fitness (especially Calisthenics), but even among the general population who have consistently been sitting or standing in a bad posture for years.


It’s also the most challenging to recover from a shoulder injury as you literally won’t be able to move the arm of the affected shoulder. The simplest and the most ‘trivial’ daily activities using our arms like
‘wearing clothes’, ‘washing hands’, ‘brushing our teeth’, ‘bathing’, ‘sleeping’, ‘eating’ etc. turn into a goddamn challenge!! Life literally turns into a living hell!


I have myself experienced ‘Shoulder Impingement’ or ‘Rotator Cuff Tendinitis’ and it TRULY SUCKS!! So, I completely understand the pain and the situation of anyone out there who is experiencing any sort of shoulder injury. This was the main reason why I decided to add the ‘injury management’ section in this app, as SH*T HAPPENS!



There are actually many different types of Shoulder Injuries. The most common types are:-

 • Rotator Cuff Tear

 • Shoulder Impingement (Rotator Cuff Tendinitis)

 • Dislocated shoulder

 • SLAP Tear

 • Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)

 • Shoulder Arthritis (Shoulder Osteoarthritis)



NOTE:- The Rehab exercises for all the above shoulder injury types are essentially the SAME. All the rehab exercises for different shoulder injury types mainly focus on ‘strengthening’ the 4 major ‘Rotator Cuff Muscles’ namely:-

 • Infraspinatus
 • Supraspinatus
 • Teres minor
 • Subscapularis

 Strengthening the above muscles will be more than sufficient to heal or recover safely, optimally and quickly from almost any kind of shoulder injury.



GURU MANN, is an
Indian Fitness YouTuber, who is a 'Certified Nutritionist', 'Fitness trainer', 'Kinesiologist', 'Exercise and Sports Scientist', and also has certifications in:-

 • ISSA (International Sports Sciences Association)

 • NASM (National Academy of Sports Medicine)

 • ACE (American Council on Exercise)

 • ASFA (American Sports and Fitness Association)


 He has recommended the most beneficial shoulder injury rehab exercises in
this video that work like ‘magic’ and can seriously BOOST your ‘recovery’ in just a few weeks. These exercises have not only helped me recover quickly, but also thousands of other viewers of his channel.


Now, he has briefly explained the basics of shoulder injury and its treatment in the above video in ‘Hindi’. So, if you don’t understand Hindi, then simply skip to
‘7:22’ of the video for the
‘Best Rehab and Strengthening exercises for the Rotator Cuff Muscles’ to recover and also to stay away from any further shoulder injuries.

string.name: rotator_cuff_tear1
string.font:
Rotator Cuff Tear



A Rotator Cuff Tear is a tear in the tissues connecting muscle to bone (tendons) around the shoulder joint.


This often occurs in people who repeatedly perform the same incorrect shoulder motions.


Symptoms include shoulder pain and weakness.


Treatment includes
rest, medication, physiotherapy, corticosteroid injections and possibly surgery (in worst cases).

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment

string.name: shoulder_impingement1
string.font:
Shoulder Impingement (Rotator Cuff Tendinitis)



Shoulder Impingement or
‘Rotator Cuff Tendinitis’ is the shoulder pain caused by connective tissue (a tendon) rubbing on a shoulder blade.

 Impingement syndrome is caused by inflammation from repetitive shoulder activities. Injury and ageing are other causes.

 Pain may be consistent and increase with lifting or reaching movements.

 Rest, medication and physiotherapy can help.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment

string.name: dislocated_shoulder1
string.font:
Dislocated Shoulder



Dislocated Shoulder is an injury in which the upper arm bone comes out of the shoulder blade socket.

 A dislocated shoulder requires prompt medical care.

 Symptoms include an out-of-place shoulder, swelling, pain and inability to move the joint.

 Treatments include moving the bone in place, splinting, medication and rehabilitation. Surgery is required only in rare cases.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment

string.name: slap_tear1
string.font:
SLAP Tear



The term SLAP stands for
Superior Labrum Anterior and Posterior. In a SLAP injury, the top (superior) part of the labrum is injured. This top area is also where the biceps tendon attaches to the labrum.


A SLAP tear occurs both in front (anterior) and back (posterior) of this attachment point. The biceps tendon can be involved in the injury, as well.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment

string.name: frozen_shoulder1
string.font:
Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)



Frozen Shoulder or
‘Adhesive Capsulitis’ is a condition characterised by stiffness and pain in the shoulder joint.

 The condition occurs more commonly in people with diabetes and in people who've kept their arm immobilised for a long period of time.

 Symptoms may start gradually and resolve within one or two years.

 Treatment involves stretching and sometimes injecting corticosteroids and numbing medication into the joint capsule. In some cases, surgery is used to loosen the joint capsule.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment

string.name: shoulder_osteoarthritis1
string.font:
Shoulder Osteoarthritis



Shoulder Osteoarthritis is a gradual wearing of the articular cartilage that leads to pain and stiffness. As the joint surface degenerates, the subchondral bone remodels, losing its sphericity and congruity. The joint capsule also becomes thickened, leading to further loss of shoulder rotation.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment

string.name: knee_injury1
string.font:
Knee Injury



Your knee is a complex joint with many components, making it vulnerable to a variety of injuries. Some of the most common knee injuries include fractures, dislocations, sprains, and ligament tears.

 Many knee injuries can be successfully treated with simple measures, such as bracing and rehabilitation exercises. Other injuries may require surgery to correct.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment:-
Link 1\n\n
Link 2\n\n
Rehab Exercises\n\n

string.name: shin_splints1
string.font:
Shin Splints



Shin Splints aka
‘Medial Tibial Stress Syndrome’ (MTSS) is the pain caused by overuse along the shinbone, the large front bone in the lower leg.

 Shin splints result when muscles, tendons and bone tissue become overworked. Shin splints often occur in athletes who've recently intensified or changed their training routines.

 The main symptom is pain in the leg.

 Treatment includes rest, ice and pain relievers.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment:-
Link 1\n\n
Link 2\n\n
Anterior Shin Splints Rehab exercises\n\n
Posterior Shin Splints Rehab exercises\n\n

string.name: elbow_tendinitis_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Elbow Tendinitis



Two forms of tendinitis commonly involve the elbow:
Lateral Epicondylitis and
Medial Epicondylitis. Both are very common overuse injuries among athletes involved in throwing, racquet sports and Calisthenics.

string.name: tennis_elbow1
string.font:
Lateral Epicondylitis (Tennis Elbow)



It’s an irritation of the tissue connecting the forearm muscle to the elbow.

 Tennis elbow can be caused by repetitive wrist and arm motions.

 Pain is the primary symptom. It usually occurs on the outside of the elbow and sometimes in the forearm and wrist.


Treatment includes rest, pain relievers and physiotherapy.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment:-
Link 1\n\n
Link 2\n\n
Rehab exercises\n\n

string.name: golfers_elbow1
string.font:
Medial Epicondylitis (Golfer's Elbow)



It’s a condition that causes pain on the inner side of the elbow.

 The cause is excess or repetitive stress, often by forceful wrist and finger motions.

 The elbow may feel stiff. Hands and wrists may feel weak.

 Treatments include rest, ice, pain relievers, stretching, physiotherapy and elbow bandaging.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment:-
Link 1\n\n
Link 2\n\n
Rehab exercises\n\n

string.name: wrist_injuries_intro1
string.font:
Introduction to Wrist Injuries



This is another very common and painful type of injury experienced by almost anyone performing any upper body exercise or any sport where wrist power plays a crucial role.

font.div:
There are 9 major types of wrist injuries that most people experience:-

 • Distal Radius Fracture (Wrist Fracture)

 • Wrist Tendinitis

 • Wrist Sprain

 • Dislocated Wrist

 • Wrist Arthritis

 • Ganglion Cyst

 • Carpal (Carpometacarpal) Boss

 • Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

 • Cubital Tunnel Syndrome

string.name: lower_back_injury1
string.font:
Lower Back Injury



It’s a physical discomfort occurring anywhere on the spine or back, ranging from mild to disabling.


Back pain can have causes that aren't due to underlying disease. Examples include overuse such as working out or lifting (Deadlifting) too much, prolonged sitting and lying down, sleeping in an uncomfortable position or wearing a poorly fitting backpack.

font.div: Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment
Rehab exercises\n\n

string.name: distal_radius_fracture
string.font:
Distal Radius Fracture (Wrist Fracture)



The radius is the larger of the two bones of the forearm. The end toward the wrist is called the distal end. A fracture of the distal radius occurs when the area of the radius near the wrist breaks.

 Distal radius fractures are very common. In fact, the radius is the most commonly broken bone in the arm.



Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment


Rehab exercises

string.name: wrist_tendinitis
string.font:
Wrist Tendinitis



This is the swelling of the tissues (tendons) connecting muscle to bone in the wrist.

 This occurs due to repetitive stress (overuse) of the tendons, such as from hand-intensive activities, is the usual cause.

 Stiffness and pain are symptoms.

 Treatments include rest, ice, pain relievers, physiotherapy and sometimes steroid injections.



Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment


Rehab exercises

string.name: wrist_sprain
string.font:
Wrist Sprain



A Wrist Sprain occurs when the strong ligaments that support the wrist stretch beyond their limits or tear. This occurs when the wrist is bent or twisted forcefully, such as caused by a fall onto an outstretched hand.


Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment


Rehab exercises

string.name: dislocated_wrist
string.font:
Dislocated Wrist



Dislocated Wrist is an injury caused by falling on an outstretched hand. Most wrist dislocations involve the lunate bone of the proximal row of carpal bones and other bones. When the dislocation occurs, the affected bone is no longer properly articulating with adjoining bones.


Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment


Wrist dislocation is similar to a 'wrist sprain', but usually more serious. SURGERY would most probably be required for treating 'wrist DISLOCATION'.

 The rehab exercises post-surgery are the SAME as that of wrist sprain. So, make sure to check the rehab exercises of the ‘wrist sprain’ section and apply them for recovering from this too.

string.name: wrist_arthritis
string.font:
Wrist Arthritis



Wrist Arthritis occurs when the normally smooth cartilage surfaces of the wrist joints are worn away and uneven bony surfaces are exposed. The wrist joint can become stiff, swollen, and painful.

 Wrist arthritis is most common in elderly people, but can sometimes be found in younger people too.


 Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment:-


Link 1


Link 2


Rehab exercises

string.name: ganglion_cyst
string.font:
Ganglion Cyst



Ganglion Cyst is a non-cancerous lump, often on the tendons or joints of wrists and hands.

 Ganglion cysts are more likely to develop in women and people who repeatedly stress their wrists, such as Gymnasts.

 A ganglion cyst is round, small and usually painless. Although rare, it can be painful if it presses a nerve. In a few cases, the cyst can interfere with joint movement.

 A ganglion cyst often clears on its own. If troublesome, it can be drained or removed.


 Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment:-


Link 1


Link 2


Treatment

string.name: carpal_boss
string.font:
Carpal (Carpometacarpal) Boss



The Carpal Boss or
Carpometacarpal Boss is a bump occurring at the junction of the long hand bones and the small wrist bones.


This is most commonly seen as a bump on the back of the hand at the middle or index carpometacarpal joint - where the hand bones meet up with the wrist bones. Carpal boss usually causes occasional pain in the wrists and some reduction in wrist mobility.



‘Carpal boss’ vs ‘Ganglion Cyst’


Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment


Exercises to improve wrist mobility (while having a ‘Carpal Boss’)

string.name: carpal_tunnel
string.font:
Carpal Tunnel Syndrome



It’s a numbness and tingling in the hand and arm caused by a pinched nerve in the wrist.

 Wrist anatomy, underlying health conditions and patterns of hand use can contribute to carpal tunnel syndrome.

 Key symptoms are pain in the hand and arm with numbness or tingling.

 Treatment may include rest, ice, wrist splints, cortisone injections and surgery.


 Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment:-


Link 1


Link 2


Rehab exercises

string.name: cubital_tunnel
string.font:
Cubital Tunnel Syndrome



Cubital Tunnel Syndrome aka
‘Ulnar Nerve Entrapment’ occurs when the ulnar nerve or funny bone nerve is stretched, compressed, or irritated where it crosses the elbow.

 Symptoms of cubital tunnel syndrome include: numbness or tingling in the fingers, especially the ring and pinky fingers, pain or soreness along the forearm.



Overview, causes, symptoms and treatment


Rehab exercises

string.name: freestyle_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Freestyle Calisthenics



This is a sub-branch of Calisthenics which mostly consists of ‘dynamic’ movements and skills that are mostly performed on Pull Up bars, parallel bars, straight bars and the ground with momentum playing an important role in addition to pure strength while executing them. These skills are also popularly known as ‘street workout battles’ or simply ‘Calisthenics battles’.


This article gives a complete overall picture of what Freestyle Calisthenics is all about.


How to start Freestyle Calisthenics

string.name: pullover1
string.font:
Pullover



A Pullover is an 'ascension' performed on the Pull Up bars and the Rings. It is an easier way of getting over the Pull Up bar or the Rings if you can’t do a Muscle Up on them.

 This is among the easiest skills in ‘freestyle Calisthenics’. The ‘bar pullover’ is easier than the ‘ring pullover’ as the bars slightly assist us towards our hips while performing it, but the Rings don’t as there’s air between them.

 The following image depicts the movement.

font.div: You need to be able to perform AT LEAST 8 Pull Ups in a row, AT LEAST 5 ‘Toes to the bar’ (Full leg raises) in a row and AT LEAST 3 ‘Inverted Deadlifts’ in a row to be able to perform this skill.
Muscles worked:- Same as that of the ‘Pull Ups’, ‘Toes to the bar’ and the ‘straight bar Dip’.\n\n
BENEFITS:- This skill helps improve our Pulling strength, Core strength and Hip Flexor strength to better prepare for the HARDER freestyle skills.\n\n
Bar Pullover TUTORIAL\n\n

Ring Pullover TUTORIAL

 The resistance bands used while performing ring pullovers can help prevent your hips from dropping down into a ‘German Hang’. Once you get comfortable with the resistance bands and eventually end up not touching them while performing this move on the Rings, you can finally end up achieving the ‘unassisted’ or ‘perfect’ ring pullover.

string.name: bar_kip_up1
string.font:
Bar Kip Up



The Bar Kip Up is similar to the 'Bar Muscle Up' performed using a big kip from our straight legs. This skill utilises more momentum than strength, so it’s naturally easier than the strict bar Muscle Up.

 This is a popular skill not only in Freestyle Calisthenics, but also in Gymnastics.

font.div: PREREQUISITES:- Similar to that of the bar pullover.
Muscles worked:- Similar to that of the kipping Muscle Up and bar pullover.\n\n
BENEFITS:- This skill helps in preparing yourself for the strict Muscle Up and also for the other HARDER freestyle skills like the ‘bar jump’, ‘shrimp flip’ etc.\n\n
TUTORIAL and MISTAKES\n\n

string.name: bar_jump1
string.font:
Bar Jump



The Bar Jump or
‘jump on the bar’ is a cool dynamic skill where we actually end up bringing our ‘feet on top of the bar’ while performing an explosive Muscle Up. This skill just requires explosive Pushing strength while performing it on the straight Dip bars, but it requires both explosive Pulling and Pushing strength in order to do it on the Pull Up bar.

 This skill obviously requires significant explosive Pulling strength to be able to pull high enough so that our feet get over the bar.

font.div:
PREREQUISITES:-

 • AT LEAST 10 explosive bar Muscle Ups in a row

 • AT LEAST 20 straight bar Dips in a row

 • AT LEAST 20 burpees in a row
Muscles worked:- Same as that of explosive bar Muscle Ups, straight bar Dips and explosive burpees.\n\n

BENEFITS:- This skill is one of the toughest ascension skills in freestyle Calisthenics and so mastering this move will certainly boost your overall body explosive Pulling and Pushing strength. This will also make you look like a ‘beast’ on the bars, which obviously boosts your confidence and self-esteem.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: bar_spin1
string.font:
Bar Spin



The Bar Spin is a freestyle skill that involves spinning on the Pull Up bar with the bar as the ‘axis of spin’. This skill can be considered as the ‘non-stopping pullover’. This move obviously requires you to master the pullover to properly perform it. This skill also puts some more stress on the elbows and forearms while performing it, so please make sure to stretch and warm up properly before practising it.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of the pullover.

BENEFITS:- This skill is slightly tougher than the pullover as it requires little more concentration, timing and strength while performing it. So, this skill does help to improve some concentration which can be a good carryover to the tougher freestyle skills like the ‘swings’.\n\n

TUTORIAL

 Make sure to use captions (subtitles) while watching it.

string.name: shrimp_flip1
string.font:
Shrimp Flip



The Shrimp Flip or
‘skin the catch’ is a popular street workout skill that involves performing a flip on the Pull Up bar after performing a ‘half skin the cat’ and then again catching the bar after performing the flip in the air.

 This move is a little complicated and risky as improper execution can easily lead to injuries. This move requires a lot of focus and timing to perform it properly and safely. It also requires some mobility in the shoulders and lower back while doing it. So, please make sure to practise it slowly by mastering each easier progression first, before moving on to the next.

 You obviously need to master the ‘skin the cat’ and Pull Ups as you do need explosive Pulling strength and grip strength to again grab the bar safely while performing it.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of explosive Pull Ups and skin the cat.

BENEFITS:- This skill does help improve your explosive Pulling strength, focus, grip strength, coordination, shoulder mobility, lower back mobility, and most importantly ‘confidence’ as this is a risky skill to master.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: swing360_1
string.font:
Swing 360°



Swings are the most popular street workout skills out there just because of their difficulty and ‘attractive’ nature.
A Swing 360° is a swing performed by making an angle of 360° in the air between 'letting go' of the bar and again grabbing it. This skill obviously requires good explosive Pulling and Pushing strength and also a good grip strength in order to grab the bar again from the air safely. This skill needs you to master the explosive Pull Ups, the normal swing and the ‘swing 180°’.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of the explosive Pull Up and Muscle Up.

BENEFITS:- This skill is great for improving our focus, explosive Pulling and Pushing strength as well as grip strength. This skill is also very attractive if performed correctly, which definitely boosts our confidence when it comes to train for the HARDER swings like the 540°, 720° and the giant swing.\n\n
Swing TUTORIAL\n\n
Swing 180° TUTORIAL\n\n
Swing 360° TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: swing540_1
string.font:
Swing 540°



The Swing 540° is similar to the ‘swing 360°’, the only difference being that a 180° is performed before the 360° to make it a 540°. This skill is slightly more challenging than the swing 360°, so make sure you master the latter skill and ‘swing 180°’ first.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of ‘swing 180°’ and ‘swing 360°’.
BENEFITS:- The BENEFITS of ‘swing 180°’ and ‘swing 540°’ are amplified through this skill. This skill is another great way to prepare for the mighty ‘swing 720°’.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: swing720
string.font:
Swing 720°



The Swing 720° is nothing but a ‘double swing 360°’ in air. This is probably the toughest swings in street workout or freestyle Calisthenics. You obviously need to master all the previous types of swings before starting to train for this one.


You always need to PRIORITISE YOUR SAFETY FIRST while learning freestyle Calisthenics, as they are GODDAMN RISKY if performed incorrectly!!


Muscles worked:- Same as that of the ‘swing 360°’ but more intensely.


BENEFITS:- The BENEFITS of the previous swing types are amplified by this swing type.


TUTORIAL

 The progressions for this skill are almost the same as the previous swings. The key is to practise and practise till you finally achieve it.

string.name: giant_swing1
string.font:
Giant Swing



The Giant Swing is an Advanced freestyle Calisthenics as well as Gymnastics skill that involves keeping our entire body straight and swinging for a complete giant circle (where our palms are at its ‘centre’, our entire body length is its ‘radius’ and our toes are at its ‘circumference’). This skill requires significant grip strength, body tension, momentum and practise to perform it successfully.


You obviously need to master your grip strength as well as your normal swings in order to start training for this Advanced skill. This skill is also very risky if you don’t master the prerequisites and the easier progressions first!! So, PLEASE PRIORITSE YOUR SAFETY FIRST!!

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of the normal swing.

BENEFITS:- This is an challenging Gymnastic as well as street workout skill. So, achieving it will definitely boost our grip strength, our capability to maintain overall body tension and also our momentum generating capacity. This move will also boost our confidence and self-esteem.
TUTORIAL

string.name: rings1
string.font:
Ring Exercises



Calisthenic exercises performed on ‘Gymnastic Rings’ or simply ‘Rings’, are termed as ‘ring exercises’. Almost any upper body exercise (Pushing and Pulling) can be performed on Rings, by simply ‘adjusting the height’ of the Rings from any tall horizontal support (Pull Up bar, a tall horizontal pole, a tree branch etc.)

 Unfortunately, there ISN’T any exercise for the lower body on the Rings that can have a significant improvement in their strength as well as hypertrophy (muscle gain). So, we will only stick to upper body exercises on Rings.

font.div:
The speciality about 'rings' is that they AREN’T FIXED like the Pull Up bars, Dip bars, ground or any other flat surface that is fixed in space. The Rings are free to move in space and so an ‘EXTRA EFFORT’ needs to be put in, to ‘STABILISE’ the Rings while performing ‘Pushing’ exercises on them. As you have noticed, Rings need to be ‘stabilised’ only for ‘PUSHING’ exercises, NOT ‘PULLING’ exercises. Pulling exercises performed on the Rings is the same as performing them on rigid or fixed bars like Pull Up or Dip bars.

 You might be wondering why? Well, let’s understand the basic ‘Physics’ behind it. You WON’T find anyone else on the internet explaining this. This explanation is purely based on my close observation on why this actually happens.

 CAUTION:- BORING Physics AHEAD xD!!! READ ONLY IF YOU ARE ‘INTERESTED’!!

You may have read about the terms ‘stable equilibrium’ and ‘unstable equilibrium’ in your 11th Grade Physics. The given image can clearly explain the types of equilibrium of a spherical ball on different surfaces.

As you can observe, in the case of a CONCAVE surface, if a ball is displaced from its equilibrium position, which is the bottom most position of the surface (potential energy is minimum at this point), its potential energy increases and due to this it tends to return to its initial equilibrium position. This is because every object tends to be in its ‘minimum potential energy state’. This situation is considered as ‘stable equilibrium’. No external force is required to keep the ball at its initial stable position.

In the case of a CONVEX surface, the ball initially at the top most point has ‘maximum potential energy’, which is the most ‘unstable’ position. As any other point on this surface will lead to a reduction of the ball’s potential energy, a slight displacement of the ball will lead to more and more displacement of the ball until it reaches its ‘minimum potential energy’ state. In this case, the ball never returns to its initial position. This situation is considered as ‘unstable equilibrium’. Here, some external force must be constantly provided to keep the ball at its initial unstable position.\n\n

In the case of a FLAT surface, the ball once displaced, does not return to its initial position as every point on the flat surface has the ‘same potential energy’. This situation is considered as ‘neutral equilibrium’.


Now, there aren’t any cases of ‘neutral equilibrium’ in physical fitness. Our body can be in a state of ‘neutral equilibrium’ only when we are completely lying down horizontal on a flat surface.


Another example of the equilibrium types which can be easily correlated with our Pulling and Pushing exercises on Rings is that of a ‘PENDULUM’.

I have labelled the above images as Pulling and Pushing exercises because our body is in ‘stable equilibrium’ while performing ‘Pulling’ exercises and in an ‘unstable equilibrium’ while performing Pushing exercises. This applies to both Rings as well as anything fixed like a Pull Up bar, Dip bars, floor etc. I’ll explain why.

 Consider our ‘body’ as the ‘bob of the pendulum’, our ‘arms’ as the ‘string or wire of the pendulum’ and our ‘palms’ as the ‘pivot point of the pendulum’.

 When we start swinging slightly while hanging from anything (fixed or unfixed support), our body automatically comes back to rest vertically below the support after some time. No matter how many times we swing, we will come back to our initial position after some time. This is clearly a condition of ‘stable equilibrium’. This applies to both fixed bars as well as Rings. This is the reason why any ‘hanging’ or ‘pulling’ exercise performed on rings is same as performing them on fixed bars.

On the other hand, when we try to perform a ‘support hold’ on the fixed parallel bars, straight bars or Pull Up bar (during a Muscle Up), our muscles are constantly engaged throughout the support hold. We don’t have to engage any of our muscles while hanging though. This is because hanging is already a ‘stable’ position where our potential energy is ‘minimum’. But our potential energy is ‘maximum’ during a ‘support hold’, which makes it an ‘unstable’ position. This is clearly a case of ‘unstable equilibrium’. This condition becomes even more unstable when we perform advanced exercises like ‘Handstands’ on the bars.

The ‘instability’ further ‘increases’ with ‘reduction in friction’ between your palms and the bars (when there’s water or sweat or oil or any other lubricant between your palms and the bar). Conversely, the instability can be ‘reduced’ by having a ‘better grip’ (high friction between your palms and the bars) and performing pushing exercises on something rigid like Pull Up bars, parallel bars, straight bars, parallettes, the ground etc.

 These unstable positions ‘force’ our body to unintentionally either lean forward or backward. In order to stay at the top position, we need to constantly provide ‘opposite reaction forces’ using our palms to the ‘random’ forward and backward leans of our body. This constant process of providing reaction forces in short time intervals leads to the generation of ‘vibrations’ in our body, our hands and ultimately our palms.

 These vibrations are ‘dampened’ or ‘absorbed’ by rigid supports, which is exactly what makes pushing exercises on them easier than on the ‘FREE’ rings. As rings AREN’T rigid, they are ‘free to move’ in space, and so they DON’T ‘absorb’ or ‘dampen’ the vibration of our palms while being in an unstable position, resulting in the ‘vibration of the rings along with our body’. So, the vibration or ‘instability’ of the rings is simply the representation of the vibration or ‘instability’ of our body. In simpler words, it’s OUR BODY that’s unstable, NOT the Rings!!

In order to limit the vibration of our ‘palms’ and ultimately the ‘rings’, we need to activate more ‘stabiliser muscles’ in our body to generate a higher vertical force to maintain our body in an ‘unstable equilibrium’. This is the reason why even the simplest pushing exercises on Rings turn into a challenge. For example, anyone who can perform around 15 parallel bar Dips in a row, will be able to manage only 5 Ring Dips in a row!

 That’s why anyone in an 'intermediate strength level' can replace ‘weighted parallel bar Dips’ with ‘Ring Dips’ to get stronger. The same applies for any other pushing exercise on rings like ‘Pelican Push Ups’, ‘L-sit’, ‘Handstand’, ‘Elbow Lever’, ‘Handstand Push Up’, ‘Planche’,’ Maltese’ etc.

Another point to note is that the ‘vibration of the rings’ depends on the ‘length of the individual’s arms or overall height’, and the ‘distance of the rings from the pivot point’ (horizontal support). Let’s understand why.
\n\nConsider the ‘bob of the above pendulum’ as the ‘combined system of rings and your arms’. So, as you might have already assumed, ‘L’ is distance of the combined system from the pivot point,
‘θ’ is the ‘angular displacement of the combined system’, and
‘s’ is the ‘arc length or linear displacement of the combined system’.\n\n
Here, ‘s’ is a measure of the ‘amplitude of vibration’ of the combined system, i.e. ‘instability’ of the system.\n\n
The angular displacement ‘θ’, is a ‘constant’, which depends on the ‘length of the individual’s arms’. So, from the above image, it’s clear that:-\n
Due to this reason, the ‘FARTHER’ the rings are from the pivot point or horizontal support, the ‘TOUGHER’ the pushing exercises will get and vice-versa.
THAT’S ENOUGH PHYSICS xD!! Now, let’s have a look at how to ‘set up’ or ‘hang’ the rings from a horizontal support by clicking
here.\n\n

NOTE:- Please make sure that the ‘horizontal support’ from where you hang the rings, is STURDY ENOUGH to handle your weight while performing exercises WITHOUT SHAKING AT ALL!! For example, if you hang your rings on a branch that can handle your weight but still shakes while performing exercises, then please find another branch that’s STURDY ENOUGH TO NOT SHAKE AT ALL!! SAFETY ALWAYS COMES FIRST!!!

 You might have observed one common thing from the images related to Gymnastics. And that is:-

 “The Gymnasts are Jacked and Muscular as hell!!”

 In order to find out why that’s the case, just watch

this video.
 (Please watch it in private with headphones on!)
Some Basic exercises on Rings for Complete Beginners.\n\n
‘Skin the cat’ is a great exercise for improving our shoulder mobility. The hang at the end of ‘skin the cat’ is termed as the

‘German Hang’. ‘German Hang’ can be performed on rings as well as on Pull Up bars using a ‘Pronated’ and ‘Supinated’ grip. The ‘Supinated German Hang’ is one of the PREREQUISITES of the ‘German Hang Muscle Up’ aka
‘Hefesto’. It’s an Advanced Skill. So, we will be discussing more about it later.\n
Ring Muscle Up TUTORIAL
Ultimate upper body Ring workout for Aesthetics\n\n

Best ring exercise for Biceps :- ‘Pelican Push Ups’


The ‘Pelican Push Up’ is another great exercise to condition your shoulders and biceps for the ‘German Hang Muscle Up’ aka ‘Hefesto’.

string.name: elbow_lever1
string.font:
Elbow Lever



As the name implies, an Elbow Lever or
Elbow Planche is performed by leveraging your bodyweight against one or both elbows while balancing on your hand(s) with your body outstretched, typically in a horizontal position. As you can see, our ‘entire body’ acts as ‘lever’ where our ‘elbows supported on our forearms’ act as the ‘fulcrum’.

font.div:
In all levers in Calisthenics, our ‘arms’ act as the ‘fulcrum’, our ‘lower body’ acts as the ‘load’ and our ‘upper body’ generates the ‘effort’ to balance the ‘load’ (lower body), to keep the entire ‘lever’ horizontal to the ground.


The ‘One Arm Elbow Lever’ is an advanced move, so we will only focus on Elbow Lever on ‘both arms’. The arms are usually placed near our ‘waistline’, which is the location of our body’s ‘centre of gravity’. Elbow Lever can be performed on literally any flat surface.


Elbow Lever is similar to a ‘Bent Arm Planche’. The only difference is that our elbows are ‘in contact’ with our Core in an Elbow Lever, as compared to the elbows being ‘beside’ our Core in the ‘Bent Arm Planche’. As we are stronger in any bent arm position, this move is obviously a prerequisite to master, before even thinking of training for the
Planche (straight arms) and for one of the Hardest Push Ups in existence:- the
‘90° Handstand Push Up’. The prerequisite basic Pushing strength to start training for the Elbow Lever is
AT LEAST 30 Push Ups in a row.\n

Muscles worked:-

 • Deltoids
 • Pectoralis major
 • Biceps
 • Triceps
 • Forearms
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Rectus abdominis
 • Serratus anterior
 • Glutes
 • Lower back muscles
 • Quadriceps
 • Calves (when toes are pointed)

BENEFITS:- Performing an Elbow Lever requires grace, flexibility, and major mental focus. It\'s one of the rare exercises that helps develop strength and balance throughout your whole body. Practicing this move will also help teach you how to create total body tension and build serious Core strength to boot. Mastering the Elbow Lever has a good carryover to the ‘Bent Arm Planche’, which in-turn is a prerequisite for training the ‘90° Push Up’.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n
NOTE:- You should be able to hold the
Full Elbow Lever (both arms) for AT LEAST 15 Seconds, in order to condition yourself to start your \'Planche\' and \'90° Handstand Push Up\' training.\n\n

string.name: handstand1
string.font:
Handstand (Two Arm)



A Handstand is the act of supporting the body in a stable, inverted vertical position by balancing on the hands. In a basic handstand, the body is held straight with arms and legs fully extended, with hands spaced approximately shoulder-width apart and the legs together.


Handstand is very important prerequisite for many Advanced Pushing Skills like
‘Handstand Push Ups’, ‘90° Push Up’, ‘One Arm Handstand’, ‘Planche’, ‘Maltese’, ‘Inverted Cross’ etc. Handstand is mostly a balance-based Skill and it does not require significant strength to perform. A prerequisite pushing strength of
‘20 Push Ups in a row’ would suffice.

 Handstand requires significant balance, coordination and focus while performing it, which obviously recruits a lot of stabiliser muscles throughout our body. This is because as discussed earlier, there CANNOT be any body position except the ‘One Arm Handstand’ that can be more unstable than the ‘Two Arm Handstand’. It usually takes ‘AT LEAST 1-2 months of consistent practise’ to successfully achieve a proper handstand. Handstand can be performed on any flat surface, parallettes, parallel bars, straight bars and rings.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Deltoids
 • Triceps
 • Pectoralis major and minor
 • Trapezius
 • Forearms
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Serratus anterior
 • Rectus abdominis
 • Glutes
 • Quadriceps
 • Calves (if toes are pointed)
BENEFITS\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n As you might have noticed, he mentioned to maintain a ‘slight bend in our hips’ while performing a proper handstand. Now that’s nothing but

PPT (Posterior Pelvic Tilt) as we have discussed earlier. Maintaining a PPT in most of the exercises helps to optimally activate the Core and glutes. Also, as any handstand exercise puts a lot of stress on your wrists, PLEASE MAKE SURE TO WARM YOUR WRISTS UP BY STRETCHING THEM!!

Wrist Stretching and Mobility Guide


He mentioned to push through our ‘finger tips’ when our legs start moving ‘forward’. Conversely, we need to ‘push’ through the ‘base of our palms’ when our ‘legs’ start moving ‘backward’. In this way, we need to keep our legs vertically over our palms by constantly alternating between Pushing through our finger tips and our palms.

NOTE:- PLEASE PRIORITISE YOUR SAFETY FIRST while learning this skill. Our body gets into a VERY RISKY position when our legs start coming IN FRONT of our hands. So, to make sure you don’t fall off, PLEASE MASTER THE DISMOUNT FIRST!!
Handstand DO’s and DON’Ts\n\n

NOTE:- You need to really master the handstand in order to progress to the Advanced exercises like \'Planche\', \'Handstand Push Up\', \'90° Handstand Push Up\', \'One Arm Handstand\' , \'Inverted Cross\', \'Maltese\' etc. You must be able to hold a
‘free’ or ‘unassisted’ straight handstand for AT LEAST 30 Seconds, in order to progress to the Advanced Skills.\n\n

string.name: pistolsquats1
string.font:
Pistol Squats



A Pistol Squat, also known as a ‘One-legged’ or ‘Single Leg Squat’, is an advanced 'unilateral' bodyweight exercise where you squat using only one leg.
This is the 2nd hardest variation of the bodyweight squats after the ‘Shrimp Squat’.


This exercise not only requires significant lower body strength, but as it’s a 'unilateral' move, it also involves the activation of stabiliser muscles to help us maintain balance.
The ‘Archer Squat’, ‘Single Leg Box Squat’ and ‘Assisted Pistol Squats’ are sufficient prerequisite exercises to achieve the pistol squat. You can perform ‘Assisted Pistol Squats’ using either Rings or some vertical support.


Now, this is not a very difficult move if you have already developed decent lower body strength through ‘Barbell Squats’. So, achieving this move is not very difficult. This move also gets easier when you have a low body fat percentage. It WON’T take more than 2 months to achieve this move.


You will definitely reach a point when you will start to find this move easy. So, if you are not very serious about training your legs then you can get away by just performing this exercise. But if you really want strong and muscular legs, then I would definitely recommend you to keep practising Barbell squats or ‘Weighted Pistol Squats’ in order to continue getting stronger.

font.div: The above image might have made it clear ‘why’ this move is termed as a ‘pistol’ squat.
Muscles worked:- Same as that of Barbell squats plus extra stabiliser muscles.\n\n
BENEFITS\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n
MISTAKES\n\n

string.name: shrimpsquats1
string.font:
Shrimp Squats



The Shrimp Squat is a challenging single-leg unilateral bodyweight squat where instead of being positioned in front of the body as it is with the pistol, when you perform a shrimp squat, your ‘non-squatting leg’ is held ‘behind’ the body.


This move is very similar to the ‘Bulgarian split squat’. The only difference is that the leg at the behind is not resting on a support, but you are rather using your antagonist muscles in your Hamstrings to keep them folded in the initial progression. So, this exercise does work your hamstrings to some extent.


The toughest progression of this squat would be to ‘completely fold’ our ‘back leg’ using our ‘one hand’ and using the other hand to balance while performing this move. This move also requires some extra ‘hip and ankle mobility’ as compared to ‘Pistol Squats’. This is the reason why this move is slightly TOUGHER than the pistol squat.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of Pistol Squats plus some extra activation of your hamstrings.
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: nordic_curl1
string.font:
Nordic Hamstring Curl



The Nordic Hamstring Curl, also called the ‘Leg Curl’ or ‘Russian Hamstring Curl’ is an advanced strength exercise that primarily works the hamstring muscles. This is undoubtedly the ‘Toughest Bodyweight Hamstring exercise’ in existence. In most cases, this exercise can be MORE INTENSE than the other machine and Barbell Hamstring exercises.

 This exercise involves kneeling on a pad (for knee comfort) and lowering under control while the ankles are held in place by a partner, a loaded Barbell, or any other immovable object.

 Then extend the hamstring muscles to lean forward from the knee, not from the hip.

 The movement should be slow and controlled.

 You should come as forward or low to the floor as you can without using your hands. Only put your hands out in front of you on the floor when you can no longer rely on your legs. Then push yourself back up to the starting position and repeat.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Hamstrings
 • Glutes
 • Calves
 • External obliques
 • Erector spinae
 • Pectoralis major (to some extent)
BENEFITS\n\n

TUTORIAL

 This exercise can also be done by keeping the feet under a loaded Barbell, using our partner to hold our feet or any other sturdy horizontal support that is low enough to tightly support our knees.

NOTE:- PLEASE make sure to use EASIER progressions FIRST like incorporating a slight forward bend in the hips or using resistance bands. DON’T DIRECTLY JUMP into the standard way of performing this as this can lead to an INJURY due to its HIGH INTENSITY!!\n\n

string.name: cali_adv_intro
string.font:
Introduction to Advanced Calisthenics



This is the sub-discipline of Calisthenics which includes all impressive skills defying gravity and human limitations that are extremely rare and require extreme levels of overall body strength, mobility, skill, balance and coordination.


You definitely need to be at an 'Expert level' in fitness already in order to even start training for these crazy skills. So, without a doubt, YOU MUST MASTER ALL THE BASIC and INTERMEDIATE LEVEL EXERCISES before even thinking of attempting them. If you don’t, then you will only end up INJURING YOURSELF. PERIOD!!

string.name: oah1
string.font:
One Arm Handstand



Performing a ‘handstand’ on one arm is termed as a ‘One Arm Handstand’. It’s that simple. Well, it may sound simple, but this is probably one of the most challenging Advanced Skills to master. Even the most Advanced Calisthenic and Gymnastic athletes ‘struggle’ to achieve this skill! This skill requires ‘extreme levels’ of balance, coordination and focus.


This skill can be performed in the ‘Straddle position’ (legs straight and wide apart), and in the ‘Full position’ (legs straight and together). The latter version is undoubtedly tougher than the former version and it’s extremely rare to find anyone performing the ‘Full’ version. So, even a ‘Straddle One Arm Handstand’ is considered as a good ‘One Arm Handstand’.


Undoubtedly, you need to FIRST master the ‘Two Arm Handstand’ before even thinking of attempting this move.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of the ‘Two Arm Handstand’. However, it requires a hell lot more strength, balance, coordination and focus.

BENEFITS:- The BENEFITS of the ‘Two Arm Handstand’ are ‘amplified’ through this version. As the ‘Two Arm Handstand’ has a great carryover to the ‘Two Arm Planche’, in the same way, the ‘One Arm Handstand’ too has a great carryover to the ‘One Arm Planche’.
