Now, the ‘One Arm Planche’ is an EXTREMELY Advanced Skill and is also the RAREST among the RAREST Skills in Calisthenics. So, explaining the ‘One Arm Planche’ is beyond the scope of this app.\n\n
TUTORIAL:-
Part 1\n\n
Part 2\n\n
MISTAKES\n\n

string.name: vsit1
string.font:
V-sit



The V-sit is an ‘Advanced L-sit’ where our legs are ‘perpendicular’ to the ground. In other words, an ‘L-sit’ is Skill where our legs make an angle between
‘0° and 90°’ (0° included and 90° excluded) with the horizontal, whereas a ‘V-sit’ is a skill where our legs make an angle between
‘90° and 180°’ (90° included and 180° excluded).

 Now, unfortunately, if you ‘google’ V-sit, then you will come up with almost all images similar to the following image. A ‘V-sit’ is NOT performed by sitting on your butts by keeping your body in a V-shape!! This is Absolute BS!! You just CAN’T assume the literal meaning of each and every word to be ‘true’.

font.div:
This is a big reason why I’ve made this app. As far as fitness is concerned, ‘the internet’ is unfortunately filled with loads and loads of ‘cr*p’!! It’s extremely easy for beginners (including me in the past) to get MISLED in fitness through ‘the internet’. The move depicted in the above pic is a ‘V-S**T’!! I’m REALLY SORRY about my language but this seriously PISSES ME OFF!! You just CAN’T COMPARE the above move to an ‘actual V-sit’, which is a hell lot more challenging and complex.


The following pic depicts how exactly a ‘proper V-sit’ must look like.
\n\nThis Skill definitely needs mastery in the L-sit. If you can perform a clean

L-sit on the floor for ‘AT LEAST 30 Seconds’, then you can start training for this Skill. This skill requires tremendous amount of ‘Hamstring mobility’ to be able to get your legs completely vertical, significant ‘Hip Flexor and Core strength’ to hold your legs in this crazy position, and significant ‘shoulder mobility’ (shoulder extension) to support your body in that position.\n\n
Muscles worked:- Higher activation of the muscles as that of an L-sit.\n\n
BENEFITS:- The benefits of an L-sit are ‘amplified’ through this Advanced Skill. This Skill is a great PREREQUISITE to work towards the ‘MANNA’, which is an ‘Advanced V-sit’.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: hspu1
string.font:
Handstand Push Up (Vertical Push - Flexion)



The Handstand Push Up also called the ‘HSPU’ or the ‘Inverted Push Up’ is a type of Push Up exercise where the body is positioned in a handstand. This is essentially a ‘vertical push’ involving ‘flexion’ of our elbows.


For a true handstand, the exercise is performed free-standing, held in the air, instead of doing it on a vertical support like a wall. This move can be performed on any flat surface, Parallettes, parallel bars, straight bars and Rings.


This skill is the bodyweight equivalent of the ‘Overhead Press’. So, the muscles worked while performing this skill is the same as that of Overhead Press. However, it activates a lot more stabiliser muscles in our body to maintain balance while being in an ‘extremely UNSTABLE position’. This skill requires you to master the ‘handstand’, which is what makes it RARE and ADVANCED.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Deltoids
 • Forearms
 • Triceps
 • Pectoralis major and minor
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Trapezius
 • Rectus abdominis
 • Serratus anterior
 • External obliques
 • Glutes
 • Quadriceps
 • Calves (if toes are pointed)

BENEFITS

 HSPUs also have a great carryover to more Advanced Pushing exercises like the '90° Handstand Push Ups', 'Planche', 'Human Flag', 'Maltese' etc.
TUTORIAL and Common MISTAKES to Avoid\n\n

string.name: hspu90_1
string.font:
90° Handstand Push Up



90° Handstand Push Up or simply '90° Push Up', is an advanced version of the Standard HSPU where our body needs to be ‘completely HORIZONTAL’ in the ‘lowest part’ of the ‘eccentric phase’. This horizontal position is known as the ‘Bent Arm Planche’. From this horizontal position, we need to push back up to the ‘VERTICAL’ Handstand position which constitutes the ‘concentric phase’ of this movement.


This move is termed as ‘90°’ as our body makes a complete ‘right angle’ while going from a completely horizontal position at the bottom to a completely vertical position at the top. The ‘Standard HSPU’ can be considered as an approximately ‘30-40° HSPU’.


This movement requires a lot more strength and wrist mobility as compared to the Standard HSPU, making it a lot HARDER than the Standard version. Obviously, this skill does require mastery in ‘Handstand’, ‘Standard HSPU’ and ‘Bent Arm Planche’. So, make sure you have mastered them first.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of Standard HSPU. The only difference is that all the muscles especially in the Core and the upper body are more heavily engaged as compared to the Standard version. Wrists are also stressed a lot more in this version, making ‘wrist mobility’ an important prerequisite for this move.

BENEFITS:- The benefits of Standard HSPU are ‘amplified’ by this version. The eccentric as well as concentric phases of this move greatly improve our upper body strength and power, which can be a great carry over to ‘Advanced Static Skills’ like the ‘Planche’ and ‘Maltese’.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: imp_dip1
string.font:
Impossible Dip



The Impossible Dip (it’s actually possible) also known as ‘Triceps Extension Dip’ is similar to a ‘Russian Dip’ with no momentum from the legs, and trying to keep your ‘shoulder back so it doesn’t pass your elbow’. The mechanics of your arm while performing this Skill is exactly like the ‘Tricep Extension Push Up’. The only difference is that this Skill is generally performed on Parallel Dip bars by executing the Tricep extension by lifting your ‘entire body’.


This Advanced Dip variation is one of the ‘Toughest Dip variations’ in existence as it requires significant ‘strength in triceps’ as well as the ‘elbow joints’, ‘tendons’ and ‘ligaments’. So, please make sure you master the ‘Tricep Extension Push Ups’, ‘Russian Dips’ and also ‘Bar Muscle Ups’ as the Bar Muscle Ups HEAVILY recruit your ‘triceps’ during its ‘transition phase’.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • TRICEPS (all heads are HEAVILY ACTIVATED)
 • Posterior deltoids
 • Forearms
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Pectoralis major
 • Rectus abdominis

BENEFITS:- This skill strengthens your forearms, posterior deltoids, triceps, elbow joint, tendons and ligaments like no other movement. You will be almost ‘vaccinated’ from any kinds of elbow injuries in the long run if you safely master this strength Skill. This Skill also has a good carryover to Advanced Pushing Skills like the Planche, Maltese, V-sit and the mighty ‘Victorian Cross’.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

NOTE:- This Dip variation puts immense stress on your elbow joints, tendons and ligaments. So, if you want to PREVENT ELBOW INJURIES, then:-

 • PLEASE WARM UP PROPERLY

 • MASTER THE PREREQUISITES and EASIER PROGRESSIONS FIRST BEFORE MOVING ON TO THE HARDER ONES

 • DON’T OVERTRAIN THIS SKILL

string.name: shoulder_flag1
string.font:
Shoulder Flag



The Shoulder Flag is a STEP UP from the ‘Dragon Flag’ and a STEP DOWN from the ‘Human Flag’, in which you suspend yourself sideways between two outstretched arms. The best way to describe a Shoulder Flag is that you start by creating a vice grip between your hands, a vertical pole, and the upper traps. You are basically trying to make a pole sandwich between your upper trap and both hands.


Once the pole is positioned correctly between your neck and your shoulder, you hop your lower body above the ground, while pulling through your arms as strong as you can. From there, you extend your entire body from shoulders to the toes until they are horizontal to the ground.


This Skill requires significant strength in your shoulders, lats, arms and your Core. You also definitely need ‘significant grip strength’ to perform this, as the only part of your body in contact with the pole would be your ‘palms’ and your ‘upper traps’.


You obviously need to master the ‘Dragon Flag’ as this is the ‘completely horizontal’ version of it. The main difference between the ‘Dragon Flag’ and the ‘Shoulder Flag’ is that the former move can be performed involving ‘concentric’, ‘eccentric’ and ‘Isometric’ phases, whereas the latter move is a purely ‘Isometric’ Skill.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of the ‘almost horizontal Dragon Flag’.

BENEFITS:- The benefits of the ‘Dragon Flag’ are ‘amplified’ through this Advanced Skill. This Skill significantly strengthens your grip, shoulders, arms, lats and your Core, which can definitely turn as a great carryover to more difficult levers like the ‘Back Lever’, ‘Front Lever’ and the ‘Human Flag’.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: human_flag1
string.font:
Human Flag (Side Lever)



The Human Flag aka ‘Side Lever’ is an Advanced Isometric Skill where the body is parallel to the ground supported by a vertical bar. A straight line is formed using the arms and body. The move requires the performer to have significant upper body Pushing, Pulling and Core strength.


This Skill is tougher than the ‘Shoulder Flag’ as the Shoulder Flag activates more of our ‘rectus abdominis’ muscles and it’s also performed using bent arms. On the other hand, the Human Flag activates more of our ‘external obliques’ (which are relatively weaker than ‘rectus abdominis’) and is also performed using ‘straight arms’, which undoubtedly makes this Skill tougher than the ‘Shoulder Flag’. So, PLEASE MASTER THE SHOULDER FLAG FIRST!!


This skill primarily involves keeping our ‘entire body horizontal’ to the ground by ‘pushing through the lower arm’ and ‘pulling through the upper arm’. So, you need to have a decent amount of ‘pushing’ and ‘pulling’ strength in order to start training this skill. You should be able to perform
‘AT LEAST 15 Pull Ups in a row’,
‘30 Push Ups in a row’ OR
‘5 HSPUs in a row’, as a prerequisite. You also need to master the
‘Hanging Windshield Wipers’ in order to ‘condition’ your ‘obliques’ for this skill.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Same as that of the Shoulder Flag. However, it involves a comparatively higher activation of forearms, biceps, triceps, deltoids, lats and external obliques.

BENEFITS:- This Skill boosts your oblique strength, straight arm strength and most importantly your ‘confidence’ and ‘self-esteem’. The ‘straight arm strength’ can have a good carryover to tougher skills like the ‘Back Lever’, ‘Front Lever’, ‘Planche’, ‘Maltese’, ‘Iron Cross’, ‘Inverted Cross’ etc.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n
MISTAKES\n\n

string.name: back_lever1
string.font:
Back Lever



The Back Lever is an Advanced Isometric Skill where our entire body is held ‘hanging horizontal’ to the ground from a horizontal support. Our entire body acts as the ‘lever’ where our arms act as the ‘fulcrum’ of the lever. Our lower body acts as the ‘load’ and our upper body generates the necessary ‘effort’ needed to balance the lower body load in order to maintain the entire body horizontal to the ground.


This Skill can be performed on any horizontal support like a Pull Up bar, parallel Dip bars, straight bars and Rings. As this is a Hanging Skill, our body is naturally in ‘stable equilibrium’ while performing this. So, performing it on any horizontal support won’t alter the difficulty of this skill.


This skill is termed as ‘Back’ Lever because our ‘arms’ acting as the fulcrum remain ‘behind our back’ the entire time. The ‘entire anterior chain’ of our body faces ‘towards the ground’ while performing this skill.


This skill requires ‘significant upper body strength’ (especially your ‘back’ and ‘lats’), ‘shoulder and elbow mobility’ to perform it safely and correctly. So, you must be able to perform
‘AT LEAST 15 Pull Ups in a row’ and
‘AT LEAST 10 reps of ‘skin the cat’ in a row’, in order to safely start training for this skill.


The Back Lever can be performed using a ‘Pronated’ and a ‘Supinated’ grip. The ‘Supinated’ grip version is slightly tougher than the ‘Pronated’ version as it puts more stress on your ‘elbow tendons’ and ‘biceps’.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Trapezius
 • Forearms
 • Triceps
 • Biceps
 • Anterior deltoids
 • Pectoralis major and minor
 • Rectus abdominis
 • Serratus anterior
 • External obliques
 • Lower back muscles
 • Glutes
 • Hamstrings
 • Quadriceps
 • Calves (if toes are pointed)

BENEFITS:- This Skill helps improve your ‘shoulder mobility’ and also improves your ‘overall upper body strength’. This move also strengthens your ‘lats’ to get ready for the HARDER ‘Front Lever’. Back Lever also strengthens your Core and posterior chain as well. This Skill also strengthens your elbow tendons and your ‘scapular protraction’ which can be a good carryover to Advanced Pushing Skills like the ‘Planche’, ‘Maltese’ and the mighty ‘Iron Cross’!\n\n

TUTORIAL

 Also remember to maintain a PPT (Posterior Pelvic Tilt) or a ‘hollow body’ position while performing this skill, instead of arching your back (Anterior Pelvic Tilt) also called as the ‘Banana Back’.

string.name: front_lever1
string.font:
Front Lever



The ‘Front Lever’ is an Advanced Isometric Skill that’s almost similar to a Back Lever, the only difference being that our ‘arms’ remain in ‘front of our body’ throughout the time. Also, the ‘entire posterior chain’ of our body faces ‘towards the ground’ while performing it.


This Skill requires a hell lot more ‘upper body pulling strength’ especially in the back and lats as it involves ‘Scapular Retraction’ instead of ‘Protraction’ as in the Back Lever. This move also puts a hell lot more stress on your ‘shoulder and elbow joints’, so you definitely need to have a ‘strong foundational pulling strength’ for training this skill safely and correctly.


You need to be able to perform
‘AT LEAST 20 Pull Ups in a row’ and
‘AT LEAST 5 Dragon Flags in a row’ as a MANDATORY PREREQUISITE. If you skip this prerequisite and just try to train the easier progressions, then you will only end up ‘plateauing’ or even worse, ‘injuring yourself’. The same is applicable to all other Advanced Skills. I have made the mistake of ‘Skipping the Basics’, and so I only ended up ‘plateauing’ at the easier progressions for over 4 months. So, PLEASE DON’T BE A JERK LIKE ME!! MASTER YOUR PULL UPS FIRST!!

font.div: Muscles worked:- Almost same as that of the Back Lever. However, it puts a lot more stress on our shoulder and elbow joints, our lats and on our Core.
BENEFITS\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

NOTE:- Please don’t forget to read the description of the above video. It contains some important points that you need to understand. I know it’s difficult to ‘let it sink in’, but unfortunately that’s the ‘HARSH REALITY’!\n\n
Do you need to ‘Completely RETRACT’ your scapula while performing a Front Lever??\n\n

string.name: manna1
string.font:
Manna



‘MANNA’ is an ‘Advanced V-sit’ where our legs make an angle of
180° with the horizontal. ‘Manna’ is undoubtedly one of the ‘most challenging’ Gymnastic Skills in existence. In order to hold our body in this position, we need our palms to be placed on the ground in a ‘Supinated’ position. Also in this Skill, your ‘scapula’ needs to be ‘Retracted’ instead of being ‘Protracted’ as in the case of L-sit and V-sit.

 You obviously 'master the V-sit first' in order to start training for this Skill.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Higher activation of the muscles as that of an V-sit. The triceps and posterior deltoids are activated a lot more due to ‘Scapular Retraction’.

BENEFITS:- The BENEFITS of V-sit are ‘amplified’ through the ‘Manna’. Also, this Skill is considered to be the ‘PINNACLE’ of ‘Hamstring Mobility’, ‘Hip Flexor strength’ and ‘shoulder mobility’ (extension). Mastering this skill BOOSTS your ‘self-esteem’ and ‘confidence’ like hell!!\n\n
TUTORIAL:-\n\n
Part 1\n\n
Part 2\n\n
Manna PROGRESSIONS\n\n

string.name: oac1
string.font:
One Arm Chin up (OAC)



The OAC or 'One Arm Chin up' is simply a chin up performed using only one arm of your body. This Skill is an extremely challenging strength Skill that requires tremendous amount of Pulling and grip strength.


This Skill emphasises mainly on your entire back, lats, biceps, forearms and your Core. Performing an OAC is similar to performing a ‘Weighted Chin up’ with +100% bodyweight as the extra load. So, you definitely need to be ‘Very Strong’ with your ‘Weighted Chin Ups or Pull Ups’ in order to start training for this Skill.


You must be able to perform
‘AT LEAST 20 Pull Ups in a row’ and a
‘One-arm hang from a bar or a ring for AT LEAST 60 Seconds’, before even thinking of training this Skill.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Activation of the same muscles as that of the ‘Two-arm chin ups’ with ‘Double Intensity’.

BENEFITS:- This Skill can significantly boost your Pulling and grip strength, which can be a good carryover to the slightly more difficult OAP (One Arm Pull Up). This move also strengthens your shoulder joints and elbow tendons to prepare for Skills that put a lot of stress on those joints like the ‘Hefesto’, ‘Entrada de Angel’, ‘Planche’, ‘Maltese’, ‘Iron Cross’, ‘Inverted Cross’, ‘Victorian Cross’ etc.


This move also places a 'huge emphasis' on your ‘Biceps’. So, you will definitely start experiencing a ‘Crazy Boost’ in your ‘Bicep Hypertrophy’! This skill additionally BOOSTS your ‘confidence’ and ‘self-esteem’ like hell!!
TUTORIAL\n\n
OAC Training Tips\n\n

string.name: oap1
string.font:
One Arm Pull up (OAP)



The OAP or 'One Arm Pull Up' is simply a Pull Up performed on a bar or a ring using only one arm of the body. This Skill is similar to the OAC. However it’s slightly more difficult than the OAC as more of the back strength is involved while performing this move, instead of the bicep strength, which is relatively easy. All the prerequisites and strength requirements are exactly the same as that of the OAC.

font.div: Muscles worked:- Activation of the same muscles as that of the ‘Two-arm Pull Ups’ with ‘Double Intensity’.
BENEFITS:- Almost the same as that of the OAC.\n\n
TUTORIAL\n\n

string.name: hefesto1
string.font:
Hefesto (German Hang Muscle Up)



The Hefesto or 'German Hang Muscle Up' is a Muscle Up that’s performed starting from a ‘Supinated German Hang’ and pulling ourselves up on the bar with our hands behind our back throughout this movement.


This is an Advanced strength Skill that requires ‘considerable shoulder mobility’, ‘bicep strength’, ‘forearm strength’ and a ‘very solid conditioning of the joints, tendons and ligaments of the elbows and shoulders’. This Skill is generally performed on Pull Up bars with a ‘False grip’.


You must be ‘very comfortable’ with the ‘Supinated German Hang’, ‘Supinated Korean Dips’, ‘Deep Pelican Push Ups’, ‘Chin ups’ and the ‘Supinated Back Lever’ before even thinking of attempting this Skill, as it’s EXTREMELY EASY for anyone to get ‘shoulder injuries’, ‘elbow tendinitis’ and ‘bicep tear’ through this INTENSE skill! Also make sure to properly WARM UP before training for this Skill.


Mandatory prerequisites:-

 • ‘Supinated German Hang’ for AT LEAST 60 Seconds

 • ‘Supinated Korean Dips’ for AT LEAST 10 reps in a row

 • ‘Deep Pelican Push Ups’ for AT LEAST 15 reps in a row

 • ‘AT LEAST 15 chin ups in a row’

 • ‘Supinated Back Lever hold for AT LEAST 10 Seconds’



These prerequisite movements will condition your shoulder joints, elbow joints, tendons and ligaments, biceps and forearms properly in order to safely start training for the ‘Hefesto’. If you skip the basics, then you will most probably end up like the guy shown in the following pic.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Deltoids
 • Forearms
 • Biceps
 • Triceps
 • Trapezius
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Pectoralis major and minor
 • Rectus abdominis
 • Serratus anterior
 • External obliques

BENEFITS:- This Skill strengthens your shoulder joints, elbow tendons, biceps and forearms like ‘crazy’, if achieved ‘slowly’ and ‘safely’! This also significantly improves your shoulder mobility. Also, just like the OAC and OAP, this Skill will ‘explode’ your ‘bicep hypertrophy’ like hell!\n\n
Tutorial 1\n\n
Tutorial 2\n\n

string.name: entrada_de_angel1
string.font:
Entrada de ángel (Angel Muscle Up)



Entrada de ángel (pronounced as ‘A’-n-th-raa-dh-aa | dh-‘a’| aa-n-kh-‘a’-l) aka ‘Angel Muscle Up’ is the 'Spanish' translation of the term ‘Entry of angel’ or ‘Angel entry’.


This Skill is termed so because our body makes the shape of an ‘angel’ while performing it on the Pull Up bar with a ‘False grip’. This Skill involves 5 phases:-

 i) Reversed grip hang

 ii) Reversed grip Pull Up

 iii) Shoulder spin (leading to elbows pointing inwards)

 iv) Wide grip Hefesto (transition phase)

 v) Wide grip Korean Dip

font.div: Due to a wider grip and ‘shoulder spin’ being used, this Skill is obviously 'tougher' than the ‘Hefesto’. This move requires ‘significant wrist flexibility’ while performing it safely. The other strength and mobility prerequisites are similar to that of the ‘Hefesto’.
‘Hefesto’ vs. ‘Entrada de ángel’\n\n
Muscles worked:- Similar to that of the Hefesto.\n\n

BENEFITS:- Similar to that of the Hefesto. This Skill however improves ‘wrist flexibility’ and ‘shoulder mobility’ to a greater degree. Due to a wide grip being used, this skill does help in the conditioning of your shoulder and elbow joints for the mighty ‘Iron Cross’.\n\n

TUTORIAL
 (Turn on English subtitles)
More training tips\n\n

string.name: planche1
string.font:
Planche



The Planche is an Advanced Isometric Calisthenic or Gymnastic Skill that involves keeping our ‘entire body straight and horizontal’ to the ground in mid-air, supported on the ground using only our straight arms.


Our palms in contact with the ground are just below our hips, which is the mid-line of our body. This Skill is the Advanced version of the 'Bent Arm Planche' where instead of our arms being ‘bent’, they are kept ‘STRAIGHT’ the entire time. This Skill is nothing but a ‘vertical mirror image’ of the ‘Front Lever’, but it’s still way more physically demanding that the Front Lever. Due to the extreme difficulty of this movement, even the ‘Straddle’ version of this Skill is considered as a good ‘Planche’.


This Skill can be performed on any flat surface, Parallettes, parallel bars, straight bars, Pull Up bars and Rings (most difficult). This Skill can be performed using ‘Pronated’, ‘Neutral’ and ‘Supinated’ wrist positions. When it comes to ‘BALANCING’, the difficulty increases from ‘pronated’ to ‘supinated’ wrist position. But as far as ‘STRESS ON THE WRIST’ is concerned, the difficulty decreases from ‘pronated’ to ‘supinated’ position.

font.div:
This Skill is essentially a 'Pushing Skill' rather than a Pulling or Hanging Skill like the front and Back Lever. So, being a ‘Pushing’ movement, this Skill obviously involves the activation of stabiliser muscles to maintain our balance at the top position due to ‘UNSTABLE equilibrium’.


This Skill is considered to be amongst the 'MOST CHALLENGING' Calisthenic Skills in existence. This Skill requires INCREDIBLE overall upper body Pushing strength, shoulder strength, wrist mobility, arm strength and Core strength apart from the strength required for balancing. This move also requires a solid overall conditioning of your shoulder joints and elbow tendons. So, you must obviously MASTER THE BASICS before diving into Planche training.

Mandatory prerequisites:-

 • AT LEAST 30 Dips in a row

 • Elbow Lever hold for AT LEAST 10 Seconds

 • Bent arm Planche hold for AT LEAST 5 Seconds

 • Two arm Handstand (unassisted) for AT LEAST 30 Seconds.

 • Supinated Back Lever for AT LEAST 10 Seconds.

Muscles worked:-

 • Anterior deltoids
 • Pectoralis major and minor
 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Trapezius
 • Triceps
 • Biceps
 • Forearms
 • Rectus abdominis
 • Serratus anterior
 • External obliques
 • Lower back muscles
 • Glutes
 • Quadriceps and calves (if toes are pointed)

BENEFITS:- The Planche helps you to build INSANE upper body strength, coordination, balance, shoulder strength wrist mobility. This Skill also help in BOOSTING straight arm strength, which can be a good carryover to slightly HARDER Gymnastic Skills involving straight arms like the ‘Maltese’, ‘Iron Cross’, ‘Inverted Cross’, ‘Victorian Cross’ etc. As this Skill is ‘extremely rare’, being able to achieve this Skill will surely BOOST your ‘confidence’ and ‘self-esteem’ like hell!\n\n
TUTORIAL:-\n\n
Part 1\n\n
Part 2\n\n
Part 3\n\n

string.name: maltese1
string.font:
Maltese



The Maltese or the 'Maltese Cross' is an Advanced Isometric Skill (not a dog breed!) also known as the ‘Wide Planche’ is similar to that of the ‘Planche’, the only difference is that our arms are placed ‘wide apart’ from each other, instead of being ‘shoulder width apart’ in the case of the ‘Planche’.


This wide placement of the arms places a lot more stress on the shoulder joints and elbow tendons, making this Skill HARDER than the Planche. The body literally makes the shape of an ‘Airplane’ while performing it. This Skill can be performed on the same equipment and wrist position as that of the Planche.

font.div:
Being able to perform a ‘Full Planche’ is itself a ‘PREREQUISITE’ for this Skill!!!

 So, it would be better to focus on achieving the ‘Planche’ first, before thinking of training this Skill, as it can be extremely easy for you to get injured while training this. Also make sure to properly warm up and stretch before starting your training.
Muscles worked:- Almost same as that of the ‘Planche’. However the wrist joints, shoulder joints and elbow tendons are placed at a greater stress.\n\n

BENEFITS:- The benefits of the ‘Planche’ are ‘amplified’ through this move. This Skill however, is closer to the mighty ‘Iron Cross’ and ‘Inverted Cross’ as far as the stress on the joints is concerned. Additionally, performing this Skill correctly makes you feel as if you are on the ‘flight mode’ xD!!\n\n

TUTORIALS:-


Once you have 'mastered' the ‘Full Planche’, you can start training almost the same progressions as that of the Planche, by slowly ‘widening the distance between your arms’.

Tutorial 1
 (Turn on the subtitles)
Tutorial 2\n\n

string.name: iron_cross1
string.font:
Iron Cross



An Iron Cross is an Advanced Isometric Skill performed on the Rings in which the body is suspended upright in mid-air while extending the arms laterally, forming the shape of the ‘Christian cross’. It is an ‘INCREDIBLY INTENSE’ move that requires extreme levels of arm strength, shoulder strength, Core strength, back strength (lats and traps) and upper chest strength.


It also requires a ‘VERY SOLID CONDITIONING’ in the shoulder joints, elbow tendons and wrist tendons for enduring the massive stress placed on them. This Skill can VERY EASILY cause ‘shoulder and elbow injuries’ due to lack of proper joint conditioning. The difficulty of this Skill increases if performed in an ‘L-sit’ position.

font.div:
PREREQUISITES:-

 • AT LEAST 15 ring Dips in a row

 • AT LEAST 10 Russian Dips in a row

 • AT LEAST 10 Bulgarian ring Dips in a row

 • Wide ring support hold for AT LEAST 30 Seconds

 • Supinated Back Lever hold for AT LEAST 15 Seconds

 • Front Lever hold for AT LEAST 10 Seconds

Muscles worked:-

 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Deltoids
 • Trapezius
 • Pectoralis major and minor
 • Forearms
 • Biceps
 • Triceps
 • Rectus abdominis
 • Serratus anterior
 • External obliques
 • Glutes, quads and calves (if toes are pointed)

BENEFITS:- This Skill is a great display of 'Brute Pushing strength' as it is the HARDEST to exert a ‘vertically downward force’ through our ‘straight arms’ in the ‘horizontal’ position. This Skill almost ‘vaccinates’ our elbows and shoulders from any further injury due to the extreme levels of conditioning acquired through it.


This Skill has a great carryover to other straight arm Skills in Gymnastics like the ‘Inverted Cross’ and the mighty ‘Victorian Cross’. Additionally, this Skill looks quite ‘majestic’ and ‘eye-catching’ when performed correctly.
TUTORIAL\n\n

TIPS

 As he has mentioned, the ‘Dips with Rings turned outwards’ are nothing but ‘Bulgarian Ring Dips’, which is a great conditioning exercise to prepare for this Skill.

string.name: inverted_cross1
string.font:
Inverted Cross



An Inverted Cross is an Advanced Gymnastic Isometric Skill performed on the Rings in an ‘Inverted Handstand position’, with the arms stretched straight out from the shoulders perpendicular to the body. Essentially it is an ‘upside-down Iron Cross’.

 This Skill too requires extreme levels of Core strength, balance, coordination, shoulder strength, straight arm strength, and obviously strong conditioning of the shoulder and elbow joints.

font.div: This Skill requires a hell lot more balance when compared to an Iron Cross, as you are in a ‘Handstand position’ and that too on the ‘UNSTABLE Rings’, which adds to its difficulty. So, an obvious PREREQUISITE to start training for this Skill would be to master the ‘Ring Handstand’. The other prerequisites are similar to that of an ‘Iron Cross’. It would also be safer to practise the Inverted Cross on the ground first, and then on the Rings.
Muscles worked:- Almost same as that of the Iron Cross. However, more stabiliser muscles are activated in this Skill due to being in the ‘Handstand position’, that too on the ‘unstable Rings’.\n\n
BENEFITS:- Almost the same as that of the Iron Cross.\n\n
Inverted Cross Training Tips:-\n\n
Part 1\n\n
Part 2\n\n

string.name: victorian_cross1
string.font:
Victorian Cross



The Victorian Cross is most probably the
TOUGHEST SKILL on the Rings as well as on the ground or Parallettes or parallel bars. It is an Advanced Gymnastic Isometric Skill which is essentially a Front Lever with ‘Arms at body height’.


This Skill is RARELY performed even by elite Gymnasts to its INSANE difficulty level!! This move requires incredibly strong shoulder, elbow and wrist joints, tendons and ligaments.


You should basically be able to perform almost all the Advanced Skills discussed till now (especially the ‘Impossible Dip’ and the ‘Front Lever’) as a PREREQUISITE before even thinking of attempting this Skill!!


This Skill requires high strength in ‘Scapular Depression’ (lats and chest), ‘Scapular Retraction’ (low and mid traps, rhomboids), ‘Shoulder Extension’ (lats, Teres major, rear deltoids, triceps long head), ‘Elbow Extension’ (triceps). It would be better to master this Skill on the parallel bars first, then on the Parallettes, then on the ground, and then finally on the Rings.

font.div:
Muscles worked:-

 • Latissimus dorsi
 • Pectoralis major and minor
 • Trapezius
 • Rhomboids
 • Lower back muscles
 • Rear deltoids
 • Triceps
 • Biceps
 • Forearms
 • Serratus anterior
 • Rectus abdominis
 • External obliques
 • Glutes
 • Quadriceps and calves (if toes are pointed)

BENEFITS:- This Skill is considered to be the ‘EPITOME’ of EXCELLENCE in ‘Artistic Rings Gymnastics’. Achieving this Skill will increase your chances of GETTING A MEDAL in the ‘Artistic Rings category’ in Gymnastics at the Olympic level!!\n\n
TUTORIALS:-\n\n
Tutorial 1\n\n
Tutorial 2\n\n

Hey there! What's going on?! I hope you're doing great!

 I'm ABHISHEK SAWANT,
the AUTHOR and
DEVELOPER of this App.
I\'m 21, (born in Sept 1998), and I\'m currently in the
8th and Final Semester (April 2020), pursuing my
B.Tech in
Mechanical Engineering from
Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore, INDIA. You may be wondering:-

\"How the hell can someone from \'Mechanical\' branch develop an \'Android App\'??!!\"\n\n
Well, that\'s the speciality of \'Mechanical\' Engineers. They\'re multi-talented xD! All jokes aside, this ISN\'T a very complex app. So, developing this one would be a \'cakewalk\' for \'Experienced\' App Developers. But as I had NO prior app development experience, this was a bit challenging for me. Despite being in the \'Mechanical\' branch, my inclination towards \'CODING\' increased a lot since my
4th semester. So, naturally I ended up DEVELOPING this app due to my interest in both CODING and FITNESS.\n\n

I started my \'Fitness Journey\' from December 2016, a time when I could manage ONLY \'4 Push Ups\' in a row xD!! From then onwards, I consistently worked on my weaknesses for \'3 years\' and ended up getting to a decent level of strength and fitness (13 Pull Ups in a row, 30 Push Ups in a row, 20 Dips in a row etc.). It was challenging in the beginning, but slowly as I got stronger, I started developing a passion for FITNESS and \'CALISTHENICS\' (aka bodyweight training). I\'ve NEITHER hired a \'PERSONAL FITNESS TRAINER\' (as I couldn\'t afford one), NOR have I ever used any \'FITNESS APPS\' (as almost all Fitness apps out there are totally USELESS) throughout my fitness journey. Eventually, because of that, I ended up making a hell lot of avoidable mistakes which was a complete waste of time and energy.\n\n
You might be wondering:-

This should have been an \'About Me\' section instead of an \'About Us\' section!! When the hell is this guy going to introduce his other groupmates??!!\n\n
Well, it would be UNFAIR to say that NOBODY ELSE was involved in helping me PROGRESS in my fitness levels as well as in DEVELOPING this app. It was CERTAINLY IMPOSSIBLE for me to achieve all this without the \'QUALITY HELP\' and \'ADVICES\' from all the
\'Online Fitness Experts\' and
\'App Developers\' who have managed to find time to help and share their VALUABLE ONLINE CONTENT to the public through

I would like to SINCERELY THANK all of them from the \'Bottom of My Heart\'.\n\n
Not just them, but I would also love to give CREDIT to my

FAMILY, FRIENDS and ALL OTHERS who have 'constantly supported me' to follow my passion :)


Undoubtedly, this was a COLLECTIVE EFFORT :)

You can also check out my Facebook Account and follow us on Instagram (by clicking 'FOLLOW US' menu tab) if you're interested.
The reason why I've mentioned follow 'us' is because irrespective of whether you follow 'me' on Instagram or not, you will defintitely get access to the 'Fitness and Calisthenics Experts' through my 'FOLLOWING' list (as my account ISN'T private). So, if you don't feel like following me, you can atleast follow them for getting a daily dose of 'QUALITY' Fitness Content.


Thanks a lot for your PATIENCE, I really DO APPRECIATE IT :)

The Ultimate Goal of this App is to spread 'Awareness' regarding the 'CORRECT' ways of pursuing a 'Fitness Lifestyle' rather than the 'FASTEST' ways of pursuing it. This App focuses on building a PROPER ATTITUDE towards 'Fitness, Nutrition and Resistance Training', which can CERTAINLY help you stay consistent with it for your lifetime!


Most of the Fitness Apps out there mainly focus on either 'dictating' some random
\'fat burning\' or \'muscle building\' exercises or \'recommending\' some random
\'Weight loss\' diets which make \'Fake Promises\' and \'Guarantee\' you

6-pack abs or huge arms, legs, chest, butt etc. within a span of \'DAYS\' or \'WEEKS\'. Individuals following such \'FAKE ADVICES\' from these apps eventually end up cooking a \'great recipe\' for FAILURE and INCONSISTENCY.\n\n
I\'m sorry to break it to you, but

you just CAN\'T TRANSFORM YOURSELF within a span of \'DAYS\' or \'WEEKS\'. It takes \'YEARS\' of \'Consistent Efforts\' to SAFELY and PERPETUALLY make significant changes to your body. That\'s unfortunately the \'Harsh Reality\'! PERIOD!\n\n
Another reason why this app is UNIQUE and DIFFERENT from others is the inclusion of
DON\'Ts of Fitness in addition to just the DO\'s which almost all the other apps \'dictate\'. Also, almost all the other apps don\'t address the

\'Real Intention\' behind following the DO\'s. That\'s exactly why this app has been named as a \'GUIDE\', rather than a \'MANUAL\'. Although a manual does include the DON\'Ts, but it doesn\'t necessarily include the reasons behind them.\n\n
This app has included various
\'Nutrition and Fitness MYTHS\' that have been debunked. It includes some
\'Anatomy Basics\' to improve your overall body awareness.

\'Introduction to Resistance Training\' section helps you to get a good overall idea of the \'Basics\' of different resistance training types.\n\n
The app also covers the \'most important and sufficient\' resistance training exercises in the gym. It also includes the

\'Gym Etiquette\' section to help you avoid the general mistakes most people commit in the gym.\n\n
One of the best sections in this app is the

\'Words of Wisdom\' section, that focuses on giving high quality fitness advices to change your overall \'attitude\' towards fitness \'perpetually\'.\n\n
This app is also HEAVILY INCLINED towards

CALISTHENICS aka bodyweight training. If you think you are at an Advanced level in fitness, give \'Calisthenics\' a try, and I PROMISE YOU, you will be INSTANTLY HUMBLED!! This app has divided Calisthenics into 3 difficulty levels. So, PLEASE make sure that you master all the exercises in each level before moving on to the next. \'Freestyle Calisthenics\' however DOESN\'T necessarily require you to master the \'Advanced\' level.\n\n
This app also covers the
\'injury management\' section which can help you to quickly, safely and efficiently recover from common fitness related injuries.\n\n

Most importantly, please thoroughly go through all the sections of this app SERIALLY like reading a NOVEL (as this app contains information equivalent to 298 pages of an MS WORD file!), instead of reading different sections in a random order. If you RUSH through the app, then you will only end up getting CONFUSED. Don\'t expect to understand what\'s happening in the Fifth chapter of a novel, if you skip the earlier chapters. I\'ve spent CONSIDERABLE TIME
(5 Months) to make this app just to make sure you get access to the BEST possible Fitness content. So, kindly be PATIENT and take this app SLOWLY, if you want to REALLY REAP all it\'s BENEFITS.\n\n
Note that all the images in this app are \'Horizontally Scrollable\', but not \'Resizable\'.\n\n

Also, please DON'T rate this app WITHOUT thoroughly going through it from start to end.


In short, this app contains everything that I wish I personally knew when I started my fitness journey. string.name: heel_pain_intro1
string.font:
Introduction to Heel Pain



It’s a physical discomfort on the back or the underside of the heel that may make walking uncomfortable or difficult.


Heel pain can have causes that aren’t due to underlying disease. Examples include poorly fitting shoes, wearing high heeled shoes, prolonged period on feet, overuse such as long walks or marathons, sprains, strains or trauma.

font.div:
There are 5 major types of Heel Pain that most people experience:-

 • Plantar Fasciitis

 • Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome

 • Achilles Tendinitis

 • Calcaneus Stress Fracture

 • Bruised Heel

string.name: plantar_fasciitis
string.font:
Plantar Fasciitis



It’s an inflammation of a thick band of tissue that connects the heel bone to the toes.

 The inflamed tissue runs across the bottom of the foot.

 Symptoms include stabbing pain near the heel. Pain might be worse in the morning and with prolonged standing, running or jumping.

 Treatments include physiotherapy, stretching exercises, shoe inserts, pain relievers, steroid injections and surgery.

string.name: tarsal_tunnel
string.font:
Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome



Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a compression, or squeezing, on the posterior tibial nerve that produces symptoms anywhere along the path of the nerve running from the inside of the ankle into the foot.

 Tarsal tunnel syndrome is similar to carpal tunnel syndrome, which occurs in the wrist.

string.name: achilles_tendinitis
string.font:
Achilles Tendinitis



It’s an injury of the Achilles tendon, which connects the calf muscle to the heel bone.

 It's common in runners and middle-aged people who play sports only on the weekends.

 Heel pain and tenderness are key symptoms.

 Treatment usually involves at-home care under a doctor's supervision, such as rest and pain relievers.

string.name: calcaneus_stress_fracture
string.font:
Calcaneus Stress Fracture



A calcaneal stress fracture is a hairline crack or fracture in the heel bone (calcaneus). It is an overuse injury which was seen mostly in soldiers marching long distances carrying heavyweights. However, they are also seen in long-distance runners, ballet dancers and sports involving jumping.

string.name: bruised_heel
string.font:
Bruised Heel



A bruised heel is an injury to the fat pad that protects the heel bone. It's also known as policeman's heel. You can get a bruised heel from the repeated force of your foot striking the ground, like if you run or jump a lot. It can also happen from a single injury, such as jumping from a big height onto your heel. It most commonly occurs while using skateboards.
